IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic infection with the human pathogen, Helicobacter pylori (Hp), is a major risk factor for several important diseases, including stomach cancer. The only protein toxin secreted from Hp, which is called the Vacuolating Cytotoxin, assists the bacterium in establishing infection within the stomach and contributes to the severity of gastric disease. Studies to identify the detailed mechanism by which this toxin interacts with and enters gastric cells will, not only provide additional insights into how Hp infection leads to gastric disease but will also provide necessary clues for future work to mitigate the effects of the toxin during bacterial infection within the human stomach, using structural-based drug design, building upon knowledge obtained from completing the studies proposed in this application.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Prenatal screening secures the earliest window of opportunity for proper management and treatment of congenital heart diseases; however, both false positive and false negative diagnoses frequently occur primarily because of the low resolution of the fetal imaging technique. Personalized flow modeling has been widely used to augment medical imaging modalities for adult and pediatric heart diseases; however, no models have been developed for fetal circulation. This project will develop the first validated computational flow model for fetal circulation and focus on the aorta, which could contribute to shifting the translational paradigm for understanding hemodynamics and etiology, improving diagnosis and prognosis, and examining the safety and efficacy of therapies for coarctation of the aorta and other congenital heart diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Advanced age-related macular degeneration (AMD) in the form of geographic atrophy (GA) is a retinal disease that is a leading cause of severe vision loss worldwide. We are developing artificial intelligence (AI) based techniques to collaboratively build GA risk models using multi-institutional data cohorts with a diverse sub-population. Distributed deep learning will be used to build robust models to improve clinical management of AMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maximizing the therapeutic effects of transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) interventions on poststroke motor function requires that these interventions be delivered during poststroke brain states during which TMS best activates the residual corticospinal tract and enhances its neural transmission. In this project, we will use machine learning to identify personalized EEG brain states that predict strong and weak residual corticospinal tract activation in chronic stroke survivors (Aim 1) and develop a real-time EEG analysis algorithm that accurately delivers TMS during personalized EEG brain states in neurotypical adults (Aim 2). Results will provide the mechanistic rationale, methodological foundation, and preliminary data for future personalized brain state- dependent TMS interventions that target the residual corticospinal tract after stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is an aggressive cancer of the bone marrow and outcomes in non-Hispanic blacks are worse than in non-Hispanic whites. The reasons for the difference in outcomes is not known and the lack of preclinical models from non-Hispanic blacks makes studying the problem difficult. The ultimate goal of this project is to generate new preclinical models of AML from cells derived from non-Hispanic blacks to better understand the differences in response to therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Uncontrolled blood vessel growth and inflammation in the eye lead to vision loss in premature babies, diabetes, and age-related macular degeneration. Identifying alternative targets for regulating retinal damage will enable the development of complementary or alternative therapeutic strategies. The proposed work will investigate an understudied atypical proinflammatory pathway in the eye and test the capacity of innovative strategies to reduce disease-causing responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed studies are relevant to public health as they may provide new proof-of-concept evidence for the role of Staphylococcus aureus in aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD). These studies would char- acterize the role of eicosanoids and mast cells in AERD that may lay the groundwork for discovery of novel diagnostic markers and therapeutic strategies to target S. aureus or mast cells to improve health outcomes in AERD patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research is relevant to public health because defective uterine environment during early preg- nancy is a key factor for two important public health problems, infertility and early pregnancy loss. This pro- posal aims to decipher how uterine immune environment is regulated by uterine epithelial estrogen receptor α during early pregnancy to make the uterus conducive for sperm passage and preimplantation embryos. The understanding of mechanisms in regulating uterine immune environment during early pregnancy is critical for developing diagnostic and therapeutic approaches to detect and treat infertility and early pregnancy loss asso- ciated with defective uterine environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The use of checkpoint inhibitor drugs has altered the therapy of cancer, leading to cures in untreatable diseases. However, by reinvigorating the immune system, these drugs are also associated with immune- mediated adverse events that resemble spontaneous autoimmunity, are poorly understood, and limit the use of potentially lifesaving treatments. The goal of this proposal is to improve our understanding the biology of the T cells that cause these adverse events.

PHR: Narrative Although the presence of antibodies to dsDNA is a unifying feature among patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), not all anti-dsDNA antibodies are pathogenic. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative: This project will image the fiber pathways that form the circuitry of the human brain with cutting-edge diffusion MRI and optical imaging technologies ex vivo. We will use the microscopic-scale optical imaging data to guide the development of more accurate tractography algorithms for reconstructing brain pathways from mesoscopic-scale diffusion MRI. As the latter is the only technique that can image the circuitry of the human brain non-invasively, improving the accuracy of methods for analyzing diffusion MRI data will benefit the wide range of neurological and psychiatric applications where this circuitry is implicated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Whereas innate responses to stress provide many important physiological mechanisms to help cope with the demands of daily challenges, the prolonged or repeated exposure to stress is associated with several psychopathologies and physical disorders. The current application seeks new information about a brain region, the rostral region of the posterior hypothalamic nucleus, that is centrally situated to integrate multiple sources of information, coordinate multiple stress-related responses, and that may significantly contribute to reduce the impact of repeated stress. This novel hypothesis could provide a breakthrough in the understanding of this normal, but ill-defined, stress adaptive process, which could suggest new avenues for the treatment of mood and anxiety disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While a large proportion of early-onset glaucoma cases have a genetic basis, only 12 genes have been described so far for primary forms of the disease, compared to hundreds for retinal dystrophies. We have recently shown that a powerful and unbiased state-of-the-science Forward Genetics approach can be used to identify novel gene-phenotype associations that are crucial to retinal health, and we propose now to exploit this strategy to identify and characterize genes, and pathways involved in the development of early-onset glaucoma. Our long-term goal is to leverage research results from our Forward Genetics studies to develop better clinical screening tests for genes associated with early-onset glaucoma, and to discover novel diagnostic and therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Topoisomerase II (Top2B) plays essential roles in the transcription of developmentally regulated genes and synaptic activity-dependent genes. Top2B mutations at the catalytic core are related to neurodevelopmental delay and autism spectrum disorder, while at the C-terminal domain (CTD) cause hearing loss. Our proposed research will investigate how the mutation reported in patients as well as the phosphorylation induced by neuronal activity, modulate the function of Top2B.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Anker, Jeffrey N. Project Narrative This research project develops an implanted X-ray visualized immunosensor to noninvasively measure local antigen concentrations through tissue. This platform technology has a wide range of preclinical research and clinical diagnostics/monitoring applications. To show proof of principle, we will develop an infection biomarker sensor (α-defensin) and test in both a human cadaveric prosthetic hip model and a live rat peritoneal dialysis model. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative SARS-CoV-2 infection during pregnancy is associated with obstetric complications and placental abnormalities, but little is known about the resulting long-term impact on the neurodevelopment health of children. The proposed work will characterize early childhood neurodevelopmental outcomes following maternal pregnancy-associated SARS-CoV-2 infection in the context of placental abnormalities, both broadly and in key areas of self-regulation and communication. This research would answer an important clinical and public health question that can 1) lead to near-term improvement in developmental care and 2) inform future mechanistic and therapeutics research to reduce harm from SARS-CoV-2 infection during pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: In vitro stem cell derived human organoids face challenges to faithfully recapitulate human biology due to limited efficiency and robustness during engineering as well as immaturity of their developmental status. In this proposal, we will use genetically programmed organoids to study cellular decisions and devise strategies to engineer tissue cell composition and function. Our approach will generate a new paradigm for engineering stem cell derived multicellular system.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ulcerative Colitis (UC) and Crohn’s disease (CD), the two major types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), are chronic diseases with recurrent symptoms and significant morbidity. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As in many other cancers, during colorectal cancer progression, the protein and sugar-rich scaffolding—known as the extracellular matrix—around the tumor cells stiffens, leading to worse outcomes; this increase in stiffness is particularly notable in metastatic tumors. How these stiffening events lead to increased cell division, movement and signaling is not well understood. Our proposal seeks to look at how matrix stiffness impacts the RhoA pathway, a known mediator of mechanical tension that is often disrupted in colon cancer, via a novel gel material that can both harden and soften on demand with the goal of deciphering the role of matrix mechanics and how they may be targeted in future treatment regimes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative  The health outcomes of using a prosthesis and orthosis depend on the physical interface between compliant human tissue and the rigid or padded structures of the device. There is a fundamental gap in knowledge about how to characterize interface pressures outside the clinic and the laboratory without expert sensor calibration and placement. This project will enable the accurate measurement of interface pressure for more than 16 continuous hours without expert supervision to provide quantifiable data for the design of comfortable prosthetic sockets and orthoses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Rhythm  and  timing  are  essential  to  successful  spoken  communication  but  difficulties  in  rhythm  and  social  communication skills are frequently observed in autism. Building on our prior findings demonstrating sensitivity  to speech rhythms as manifest in entrainment of speech rate in conversing typically developing individuals, here  we  assess  rhythm  skills  as  a  mechanism  underlying  speech  rate  entrainment  in  autistic  individuals,  the  moderating  role  of  social  agreement,  and  their  relationship  with  conversational  outcomes.  This  research  will  provide  a  foundation  for  linking  rhythm,  social  factors,  and  communication  with  the  potential  to  impact  frameworks for understanding communication and interactional success in autism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project aims to determine the roles of enzymes that regulate histone methylation in stabilizing the neuronal network. Impaired methyl histone regulation characterizes many human neurodevelopmental disorders such as intellectual disability and autism, in which the neuronal network is less stable. Thus, obtained knowledge through the proposed research will provide a foundation for an evidence-based approach for future therapeutic intervention of these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE A comprehensive assessment of dietary and serum levels of Advanced Glycation End products (AGEs) in older adults with type 2 diabetes will determine if AGEs are associated with incident dementia, cognitive decline, and neuropathological indices of cerebrovascular and Alzheimer's disease (AD). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: NARRATIVE: Gastrointestinal (GI) functions affect overall health and wellbeing and GI motility disorders are common patient complaints and significantly impacts quality of life and productivity with unmet medical need. The function of the enteric nervous system (ENS), the “second brain” in the gut, is essential to GI homeostasis and ENS defects cause GI dysmotility. The current proposal aims to understand the sensory biology in the ENS using unique neurogenetic technologies and identify specific intrinsic primary sensory neurons (IPANs) as new therapeutic target for the treatment of motility-related GI disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Impaired brain energy metabolism is an increasingly recognized and targeted component of Alzheimer’s disease (AD), yet methods to assess energy manipulation in the brain are limited. This project will develop techniques to measure brain energy metabolism using 3T 1H/31P magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) and use these new measures to investigate the ketogenic diet's (KD) ability to manipulate brain energy metabolism in aging and AD. The potential impact of this study is significant as our measurement techniques with 3T MRS can be shared across the NIA’s network of Alzheimer’s Disease Research Centers (ADRC), finally allowing for large-scale investigation of brain metabolism mechanisms in humans and potentially leading to new drug and behavioral intervention discovery to prevent and treat AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the most common type of dementia and one of the leading causes of mortality worldwide. However, available medications provide short-term symptomatic effects but do not cure the disease elluminating an urgent need in discovery and targeting new therapeutically actionable mechanisms underlying the disease. To address this unmet medical need, this project will define the protein-protein interaction between p38 and MK2 as a new target mechanism to control neuroinflammation, the major AD hallmark, and provide the first small molecules to control this pathogenic axis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Methods for developing new antibiotics are urgently required to address the growing rise of antibiotic resistance mechanisms. We propose to leverage our recent advances in computational peptide design and integrate them with high-throughput chemical synthesis to develop inhibitors of a validated antimicrobial target – the type 1 bacterial signal peptidase. The computational and experimental methods developed in this project will be broadly applicable to developing superior analogs of naturally-occurring antibiotics and rationally designing new classes of antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed work is a proof-of-concept study in vivo for the development of a novel gene therapy for melanoma. Functionalized lipid nanoparticles can transfect melanoma cells selectively in mice, and deliver a gene that causes melanoma cells to express a-Gal, which is antigenic. This makes the melanoma cells susceptible to destruction by anti-a-Gal Ab-mediated mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with living with a vision impairment (VI) are not immune to problems engaging in routine physical activity and exercise necessary for health benefits and in fact, research shows that this vulnerable population is disproportionally at greater risk for physical inactivity, sedentary behaviors, and subsequent chronic health complications (e.g., obesity; hypertension; cardiovascular disease) compared to those with adequate vision. To urgently address this health disparity, an evidence-based physical activity behavior change intervention will be modified and evaluated to motivate and empower people with a VI to gradually increase physical activity behaviors to levels associated with health benefits and the prevention of secondary health conditions. Individuals with a VI will improve physical activity duration and intensity which will positively impact their everyday functioning, emotional well-being, sleep quality, vision-related quality of life, and social participation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to design and evaluate a front-end, analog application specific integrated circuit (ASIC) that translates the ultra-fast timing performance of a gold-standard, benchtop readout chain for silicon photomultipliers (SiPMs) into an implementation that is tractable for large scale imaging systems (thousands of channels of electronic readout), to advance time-of-flight positron emission tomography imaging. This electronic readout chain leverages a first-ever implementation of a capacitance compensation scheme into an SiPM readout ASIC, thereby mitigating the large device capacitance exhibited by SiPMs and providing a pathway for realizing benchtop timing performance for SiPM-based detectors in large scale imagers and experiments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Population establishment and spread of Anopheles stephensi mosquito in Africa pose major challenges for malaria control and elimination in Africa. Sensitive surveillance of An. stephensi is critical to its early detection and control. The new serological surveillance tools to be developed by this project will distinguish the exposure of invasive An. stephensi from the native African malaria vector species, and thus greatly support the surveillance and control of An. stephensi in Africa.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Mark Ilgen, Ph.D. is a productive Department of Veterans Affairs Health Services Researcher who is recognized nationally as a leader in the area of Addiction Health Services Research and is dedicated to improving care for Veterans with Substance Use Disorders (SUDs). His work is designed to enhance positive treatment outcomes and reduce potential adverse events for Veterans with SUDs, particularly for those who have comorbid pain or who are at increased risk of suicide. The proposed Research Career Scientist Award will support his continued research to enhance care for Veterans, as well as an expanded role in mentorship and training of early career scientists as the next generation of VHA health services researchers and leaders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE for ARTFL LEFFTDS Longitudinal FTLD PROGRAM The ARTFL LEFFTDS Longitudinal Frontotemporal Lobar Degeneration (ALLFTD) protocol represents an expanded and integrated program involving seven cores and two projects with the intent of increasing data/samples/scans for investigative research in familial and sporadic FTLD, and ultimately promoting the development of effective therapies. The proposed project will enroll 2100 participants across 19 sites in the US and Canada, and by using the infrastructure built during the Advancement of Research and Treatment in Frontotemporal Lobar Degeneration (ARTFL) and Longitudinal Evaluation of Familial Frontotemporal Dementia Subjects (LEFFTDS) protocols, the ALLFTD cores will generate data that will be uploaded to the National Alzheimer’s Coordinating Center (NACC), biofluid samples that will be transferred to and processed at National Centralized Repository for Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (NCRAD), and imaging data that will be transferred to the Laboratory of NeuroImaging (LONI) - thereby providing data to qualified researchers worldwide. The cores will also contribute data and expertise to the projects, which will focus on asymptomatic/minimally symptomatic familial FTLD (Project 1) and overtly symptomatic familial and sporadic FTLD (Project 2).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We utilize an innovative multimodal neuroimaging approach to better understand how sleep disturbances and brain networks that regulate emotion may underlie the clinically distressing and economically relevant problem of neuropsychiatric symptoms in those with mild cognitive impairment and Alzheimer’s dementia. The findings will provide a foundation for developing sleep based, mechanism-focused preventative strategies and treatments for neuropsychiatric symptoms in Alzheimer’s dementia that are personalized for the individual.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: The COVID-CT Registry is a study to determine if coronary artery disease patients with a history of COVID-19 infection in New York City have more inflammation, resulting in faster development of plaque in their coronary arteries. CAT scans of the heart’s arteries will be used to measure inflammation, stenosis (narrowing of the blood vessels), and plaque (cholesterol deposits) which are all associated with major cardiac events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Tuberculosis (TB) continues to be a major global health problem with 9 million new cases per year resulting in 1.7 million deaths. There will be no lasting reduction of TB morbidity and mortality without rapid and cost-effective therapeutics. The goal of this proposal is to accelerate TB research through the completion and distribution of reagents that allow for precise null gene deletions in Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative agent of TB. These valuable resources will be available to the international TB research community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Aging decreases mammalian intestinal stem cell (ISC) numbers, function, and regenerative capacity; however, how age-related changes in stromal niche cells contribute to ISC aging remains unknown due to the lack of experimental tools. Here, we develop new heterotypic organoid co-culture systems and novel mouse models to investigate how stromal niche cell aging influences the biology of ISCs. We will further interrogate how short- term dietary methionine restriction can modulate the stromal niche cells to enhance ISC function and intestinal regeneration in aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are no biomarkers that are currently used in the management of high-grade gliomas. Therefore, patients are often required to undergo invasive biopsies or surgical resection to differentiate disease progression from treatment related changes, quantify disease burden and track the molecular evolution of these difficult to treat cancers. We will generate a multi-analyte assay based on released tumor DNA in the cerebrospinal fluid to generate personalized biomarkers capable of tracking disease and providing insights into the tumor genotype, thereby allowing clinicians to make more informed decisions in real-time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the leading cause of dementia and a growing health concern associated with brain vascular pathologies. Brain endothelial cells maintain proper structure and function of vasculature, but they become dysfunctional in AD contributing to cognitive impairment and deposition of pathological proteins in the brain. This project aims to understand how APOE, the strongest risk gene for developing AD, impacts the protein changes in endothelial cells in AD individuals and AD mouse model with the ultimate goal to identify new therapeutic targets and biomarkers for treatment of this devastating disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although neuropsychiatric symptoms (e.g. aggression, psychosis, anxiety, apathy, depression, and sleep disturbances) occur in ~85% of Alzheimer disease patients and are associated with accelerated decline, increased cost, out-of-home placement, and greatly increased suffering of patients and families, our understanding of their etiology is still inadequate, with treatments often being ineffective and even associated with serious adverse effects (including increased mortality). This knowledge gap is particularly egregious in underserved racial and ethnic groups such as Hispanics and African-Americans. We propose to expand the racially and ethnically diverse ADSP-FUS and related resources to include harmonized neuropsychiatric symptom data allowing researchers to assess a variety of additional critical hypotheses, and to utilize these harmonized data to identify ancestry-specific genetic determinants, molecular pathways, and polygenic effects underlying neuropsychiatric symptoms in Alzheimer disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative COPD/emphysema, the third leading cause of death in the United States, is a chronic inflammatory lung disorder usually triggered by long-term cigarette smoke exposure. Although many therapies reduce the symptoms of COPD, no interventions exist which arrest or reverse the extensive architectural and functional damage that punctuate the disorder. In this proposal, we examine the mechanisms by which impaired hepatocyte growth factor receptor activity contributes to COPD development and whether enhancing the activity of this receptor and its pathway effects will attenuate acquired lung injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disorders of the blood and bone marrow are of great public health significance. The transcription factor GATA2 is responsible for emergence of the blood and bone marrow during development and maintenance of the bone marrow stem cell compartment in adults, while germline mutations in GATA2 predispose to immunodeficiency and bone marrow failure. Understanding the factors that interface with GATA2 to regulate its functions on chromatin will help us elucidate its role in promoting a healthy bone marrow and inform future therapies for conditions involving the blood and bone marrow.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Uterine angiogenesis is an underlying event of embryo implantation and endometrial decidualization to nourish the embryo until it forms a functional placenta. The proposed study will uncover the indispensable role of fibrillar collagen in endometrial decidualization and angiogenesis during early pregnancy. The outcomes will improve our understanding of decidualization and angiogenesis and will provide opportunities to develop tools for the prevention of adverse pregnancy outcomes such as early pregnancy loss in women.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While significant advances in global health have been achieved in recent decades, serious disparities in health outcomes persist, especially among children, adolescents and their adult caregivers. The proposed research training program in global health disparities research, entitled “Addressing the Research Capacity Gap in Global Child, Adolescent & Family Health Disparities Utilizing Implementation and Data Sciences among Vulnerable Populations in Resource-limited Settings (ACHIEVE)”, focuses on increasing dissemination and implementation (D&I) and data science research capacity in order to address global health disparities affecting children, adolescents and their adult caregiving families; and is designed for Medical Doctors and Post-Doctoral trainees from diverse backgrounds in the United States (including underrepresented minorities) and sub-Saharan Africa. The ultimate goal of the ACHIEVE program is to support the development of a cadre of early career researchers applying D&I and data science research methods to ensure that research on evidence-based practices, interventions, and policies are effectively translated to and used in real-world settings heavily affected by health disparities impacting children, adolescents, and the adults who raise them in low and middle-income countries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prevalence of Alzheimer’s disease and related disorders (ADRD) and the associated societal and economic burden is expected to rise as baby boomers enter old age. This problem is particularly salient in African Americans and Latinx who are at higher risk for ADRD than similarly aged non-Latinx Whites. The proposed study will identify biological and social factors that increase and modify risk of ADRD and account for racial/ethnic disparities among middle-aged adults, when ADRD-related pathology begins to manifest in the brain and when intervention may delay or prevent onset.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: NARRATIVE Many individuals persist in personal behaviors or lifestyle (substance abuse, physical inactivity/obesity) that significantly increase risk for chronic disease and premature death. This relationship between personal behavior and disease risk is firmly established, but much remains to be learned about why certain individuals are more likely to engage in risky behaviors and how to promote behavior change.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This multidisciplinary Program Project Grant (PPG) assesses the role of accumulating pathologic transactive DNA/RNA binding protein ~43 kD (TDP-43) in frontotemporal degeneration (FTD) and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (FTD-ALS) spectrum disorders and aging including limbic-predominant age-related TDP-43 encephalopathy (LATE) from the unique perspective of the breakdown of neural networks at molecular, microscopic and macroscale levels in humans, consistent with the highest priorities for FTD at the 2019 Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Disorders (ADRD) summit. In five novel, independent but synergistic Projects and five Cores that support each of the Projects, we hypothesize that our novel, well-integrated, network perspective will fill major gaps in knowledge by elucidating mechanistic insights into the pathophysiology of abnormal TDP-43 and the associated pattern of progressive disease, and offer fresh perspectives on the identification of accumulating TDP-43 pathology during life and its role in longitudinal clinical decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance Persistent post-surgical pain negatively impacts a large number of breast cancer survivors. There are currently no established interventions to help reduce the burden of this persistent post-surgical pain and its negative consequences. New interventions are needed to reduce suffering and improve the quality of life of breast cancer survivors with persistent post-surgical pain. This study tests a novel pain coping skills training intervention that was designed specifically for survivors with persistent pain after breast cancer surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Maquat-lab research focuses on RNA metabolism in human health and disease. The lab's view is that understanding the molecular mechanisms of normal gene expression and what goes wrong with these mechanisms in disease are critical for the development of effective therapeutics. Disease states to be examined include fragile X syndrome, which is the most common single-gene cause of intellectual disability and autism, and a runaway innate immune response, which can lead to a cytokine storm in cases of bacterial or viral infections, including COVID-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria continues to be one of the largest public health concerns globally, yet an effective vaccine has not yet been realized. One reason is that the malaria parasite is far more complex than viruses or bacteria and has been evolving means to evade our immune system for millennia. Here, we propose a rethinking of malaria vaccine development using completely novel immune mechanisms that target novel parasite proteins with the goal of developing a highly protective vaccine capable of being used across highly diverse populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Bystander-approaches to sexual violence prevention are increasingly common on college campuses, yet there is a need for research to understand the real-world situational factors that promote bystander behavior. The current study will use weekend morning reports to answer key questions about the within-person effects of alcohol intoxication and situational context on bystander behavior in social drinking contexts. Results from morning reports and focus groups will be valuable for the refinement of situational models of bystander behavior and the improvement of empirically-informed bystander-focused sexual violence prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Drug addiction is associated with long-lasting changes in brain function that cause relapse vulnerability, even after extended drug abstinence. The proposed experiments will provide insight into the role that a subset of interneurons in the nucleus accumbens, responsible for the release of nitric oxide, play in mediating the synaptic plasticity underlying cocaine seeking behavior. The proposed research has the potential to reveal novel neurobiological mechanisms of cocaine addiction, and will contribute to the development of novel therapeutic options aimed at reversing cocaine-induced alterations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neutrophils play a critical role in maintaining tissue homeostasis but can also contribute to the progression of diverse diseases (e.g. chronic infections, cancer, cardiovascular disease, autoimmune disease, fibrosis). Modulating neutrophil recruitment or function is a promising strategy for treating these diseases but we must first understand how neutrophils integrate diverse proinflammatory signals into a specific and directed response. This proposal will use a physiologically relevant microfluidic model to identify key signaling molecules that regulate the neutrophil response, providing future therapeutic targets for modulating the neutrophil response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In settings with limited resources, understanding the potential benefits and costs of various interventions to promote tobacco cessation in HIV care is critical for clinical and public health policy decisions. This project will combine an integrated cost-effectiveness model of tobacco, HIV, and tuberculosis care with tobacco-related findings from a population-based cohort in South Africa to project clinical and economic outcomes and cost- effectiveness of tobacco cessation interventions embedded within HIV care. The overall goal is to promote an evidence-based approach to decisions around the integrated health care and services for the overlapping tobacco, HIV, and tuberculosis epidemics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Public Health Narrative  This project will contribute much-needed knowledge on the role of physical activity in reducing alcohol use, depressive symptoms and negative mood, and increasing fitness in women with depression and alcohol use disorder (AUD). We expect that the results of this study will establish the LPA+Fitbit intervention as efficacious for women with AUD and depression in early recovery. If the efficacy of the LPA+Fitbit intervention can be established, depressed women with AUD will have a valuable adjunct to traditional alcohol treatment that is acceptable, flexible and employs an alternate coping strategy during early recovery, when relapse risk is highest.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Overall The Duke/University of North Carolina (UNC) Alzheimer’s Disease Research Center (Duke/UNC ADRC) is a collaboration of leading researchers in aging and Alzheimer’s disease. The Center’s primary objective is to catalyze and support research and innovation that will ultimately reduce the prevalence and impact of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Proper expression of information in genes is absolutely critical for correct cellular function; defects in any of the reactions involved in gene expression can have catastrophic consequences for the cell. Genes contain long stretches of interrupting information (introns) that must be removed by the cellular machinery in order for that information to be properly expressed, a process called RNA splicing; mutations that cause defects in these mechanisms are a leading cause of a variety of human diseases—from neurodegeneration and blindness to all known cancers. The focus of our work is to understand the molecular details underlying RNA splicing and its regulation, as this is a crucial step toward understanding the etiology of human diseases and, ultimately, for developing tools to treat them.

PROJECT_TITLE: Mechanisms of messenger RNA splicing and RNA processing regulation
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Maximizing Investigators’ Research Award A Study Section[MRAA]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: In this proposal, we will study how parental (H3-H4)2 tetramers, the primary carrier of epigenetic modifications, are assembled into nucleosomes following DNA replication, the first step in the inheritance of higher-order chromatin structures. Moreover, we will determine how deficiencies in this process lead to reactivation of endogenous retrovirus (ERVs), which is linked to increased response of cancer cells to immunotherapy. Therefore, the proposed studies will not only provide an unprecedented insight into epigenetic inheritance, a critical but poorly understood cellular process, but will also shed light on an epigenetic mechanism for boosting the response of cancer cells to immunotherapy.

PHR: Project Narrative A genetic abnormality is thought to underlie a substantial portion of CHD, but the identity of the abnormalities has not been identified in 50% of affected patients. This proposal seeks to apply state-of-the-art genomic technology to a large cohort of CHD patients recruited to the PCGC program and identify the genetic cause of CHD, and then to link the genetic findings to actionable outcomes to improve care of patients with CHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Almost all our everyday actions, such as driving a car or riding a bike, necessitate flexible multi-tasking. While considerable work has examined how the brain’s distributed motor network controls consistent movements in an invariant environment, the mechanisms that allow for flexibility in movement control remain unknown. In this project, I study the flexible production of multiple distinct reaching movements in mice to uncover fundamental principles by which the brain’s distributed motor system governs flexibility in movement control and shed light how these mechanisms can dysfunction in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is common among patients in the intensive care unit (ICU) but very few ICU survivors with AUD are effectively connected to alcohol treatment programs. The goal of this project is to facilitate the entry of ICU survivors with AUD into alcohol treatment by creating, refining, and piloting a peer-narrated virtual tour of an alcohol treatment program which would immediately and virtually transport a patient to a treatment facility while hearing the narrative of a peer in recovery. After rigorous development and testing, the end result will be a video patient decision aid for ICU survivors with AUD that can be expanded to various treatment options in the Denver area for a larger pragmatic effectiveness trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Understanding causal relationship between one's own actions and external events is human competence critical for building veridical representation of, and selecting desired actions in the complex world. The proposed research takes an integrative approach that combines innovative behavioral paradigm with multi-scale neural recordings, perturbations and computational modeling, to test novel hypotheses regarding the role of heterogeneous dynamics of memory in the primate prefrontal cortex in causal inference. Causal reasoning is often disrupted in the patients with psychiatric disorders and the results from the proposed study will contribute to understanding not only the foundation of human high-order cognition, but also the prefrontal pathophysiology of psychiatric symptoms.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE SUMMARY Osteoporosis is a major disease of aging that has origins in childhood since failure to achieve optimal bone accretion during growth results in suboptimal peak bone mass and bone fragility in older adulthood. Osteoporosis has a strong heritable component, and pediatric studies may be more effective in distilling the genetic component in this complex disease, because duration of environmental exposure has been less. Utilizing existing data from the NICHD Bone Mineral Density in Childhood Study, we will use advanced techniques to extract new information about bone quality and structural strength, and bone-related body composition, and apply high resolution `3D Genomics' and CRISPR based techniques to pinpoint causal genetic variants and corresponding effector gene(s) to deepen our understanding of bone accretion during this critical phase of the life cycle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Scientific evidence suggests racially and ethnically diverse women who use drugs are disproportionately impacted by HIV transmission risk and intersectional stigma and have low levels of pre-exposure prophylaxis awareness and uptake. Mobile health (mHealth) interventions and interventions that target intersectional stigma have the potential to increase HIV prevention service engagement, but few mHealth interventions tailored specifically toward racially diverse WWUD have been developed. The proposed training and research aims would address this gap by developing an mHealth intervention targeting HIV prevention service engagement and intersectional stigma among racially and ethnically diverse WWUD, and would uniquely position me as one of few health behavior interventionists specializing in intersectional stigma and mHealth interventions for WWUD within the Division of Infectious Diseases and Global Public Health at the University of California San Diego (UCSD).

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ongoing international effort to generate a loss of function knock-out (KO) allele for every gene in mouse is well underway. However, 12% of homozygous knock-out mice will be embryonic lethal prior to E9.5 and there is no current plan to analyze them. During the first award period we have capitalized on the immense resource that these knock-out alleles provide by characterizing more than 100 novel early embryonic lethal phenotypes. Here we propose to continue our streamlined assessment of up to 150 knock out alleles. These studies will enhance our understanding of the initial stages of development of early cell lineages, multiple organ progenitors as well as advance our understanding of human disease by identifying specific gene functions during critical developmental events. Our proposal fills the existing gap in phenotyping efforts and will maximize the productivity of the IMPC and KOMP efforts in generating KO alleles at every gene.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Darwinian evolution drives the emergence of resistance to targeted therapy in cancer. We propose to use results from our in vitro evolutionary game assay to parameterize a computer model to allow us to predict 3-dimensional dynamics on clinically relevant timescales. Further, we will extend our assay to function in vivo, allowing the community to test mathematically derived evolutionary therapy hypotheses in preclinical models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Therapeutic nucleic acids have recently gained FDA approval for their ability to silence genes and correct mRNA splicing events, showing their promise for treating traditionally difficult to target disease pathways. Despite their great potential for clinical applications, efforts to develop broadly applicable strategies for their cellular delivery have been limited due to the charged nature of nucleic acids that limits both their cellular uptake and accessibility to their mRNA targets. Here we propose the synthesis of a new class of chemically tunable nucleic acid surfactant conjugates as an innovative way to improve nucleic acid cytosolic delivery along with novel fluorescent surfactant probes that can help us quantify their delivery to enable this promising class of biomolecules to achieve greater clinical application.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative Delivery of chemotherapeutic agents to the brain and brain tumor by systemic administration is a challenge because of the presence of the blood-brain barrier. We will explore novel antibody-based agents with improved blood-brain barrier penetration efficiency. We expect that completion of this study will lay the foundation for a new class of antibody agents for brain diseases including brain cancer with enhanced therapeutic efficacy and safety profiles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project narrative Depression is highly prevalent in intractable epilepsy patients undergoing invasive electrophysiological monitoring, which provides a unique opportunity to study highly detailed, multi-areal brain activity across depression states. We propose to combine distributed intracranial electroencephalography recordings, reinforcement learning of decision-making and machine-learning approaches to study how reward and mood processing is affected across multiple brain areas in depression. We will use the resulting models of the neurobehavioral basis of depression to develop new patient-tailored invasive neurostimulation therapeutical strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Pregnant women are 10 times more likely to be infected with the food-borne pathogen Listeria monocytogenes than non-pregnant adults, and fetal death occurs in 20-60% of cases. This proposal aims to understand the mechanisms by which the bacterial virulence factor InlB enhances L. monocytogenes invasion of the placenta and transmission from mother to fetus. The knowledge gained from this proposal may eventually lead to improved strategies for treating L. monocytogenes infections and a better understanding of vertical transmission in other infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disparities in HIV and stimulant use outcomes observed among sexual minority men (i.e., non-heterosexual men) are believed to be driven by minority stress (i.e., stigma-related social stress). We aim to conduct a series of studies, guided by the Biopsychosocial Minority Stress Framework, that test the mechanisms through which minority stress may impact HIV viral load among sexual minority men with HIV who use stimulants. Further, we will examine whether the observed effects of minority stress are greater among racial/ethnic minority participants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our research program aims to equip biomarker and medical researchers with statistical tools that can enhance the power and rigor of scientific effort aiming to translate knowledge gained from laboratory studies into medical practice. In this cycle, we will address the challenges in outcome ascertainment from prospective cohort studies and propose methods for deriving and validating dynamic surveillance regimens for disease monitoring with multiple biomarkers. The applicability of the proposed methods will be tested in a wide range of practice settings in cancer biomarker studies and integrating our research into clinical settings will help improve survival outcomes and reduce the burden of diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A large percent of people (10-20%) suffers from loss of libido, likely caused by dysfunction of the neural circuit that controls sexual behaviors. The current project will shed light on the cellular and molecular mechanisms of how mating experience drives a neural plasticity and in turn modulates male mating behaviors. As such then, it may suggest potential avenues for investigating aberrant neural circuit wiring that leads to low libido, and molecular and cellular targets for restoring human libido.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The NIH Bridges to the Doctorate Training Program at SFSU is a joint project between the Hispanic Serving Master’s institution, San Francisco State University (SFSU), and the pre- eminent PhD granting institution, the University of California San Francisco (UCSF). It prepares a diverse population of master’s students at SFSU to enter into top ranked biomedical Ph.D. degree programs such as UCSF, with the skills to successfully complete their Ph.D. degrees, en route to careers in the biomedical research workforce. The partnership between SFSU and UCSF addresses the need to diversify the scientific research community at the Ph.D. level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Periodontal disease is one of the most common diseases afflicting the oral cavity and leads to periodontal destruction as well as tooth loss; while current treatments aim to mitigate symptoms and prevent further disease progression, they do not truly repair the already lost or damaged periodontal tissues. Bone sialoprotein (BSP) is an extracellular matrix protein found in mineralized tissues of the skeleton and dentition, including tissues of the periodontal complex (i.e., cementum and alveolar bone). The proposed studies will elucidate how BSP modulates periodontal development and repair through its functions in key cells for periodontal function: cementoblasts, osteoblasts, and osteoclasts, which will ultimately facilitate the development of reparative therapies for periodontal tissues.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Iron and folic acid supplementation may reduce the high risk of stillbirth, preterm delivery, low birthweight and other adverse pregnancy outcomes in resource-limited countries such as Botswana. The goal of the proposed research is to identify and evaluate interventions to provide supplementation to pregnant women that address key barriers to successful supplementation and reach populations that would benefit most from intervention. The results of this work will inform supplementation strategies in Botswana and other resource-limited countries and larger-scale intervention studies to provide supplementation to women in Botswana.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/ PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP) is a leading cause of premature death in people with chronic uncontrolled epilepsy, and targeted prevention strategies currently do not exist. Studies of patients with epilepsy who died while being monitored in hospital epilepsy units reveal that most SUDEP is due to post-convulsive breathing arrest. Our project identifies neuromodulation approaches for breathing rescue that will aid in the design of preventive SUDEP interventions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While it has been thought that individuals with severe spinal cord injuries will not recover the ability to functionally move their lower extremities, spinal cord stimulation has emerged as a promising intervention challenging this long-held assumption. While spinal cord stimulation allows for restored voluntary movement after spinal cord injury, there is a lack of mechanistic understanding regarding how it works and why some individuals respond better than others. Thus, the overall objective of this proposal is to apply neuroimaging biomarkers to generate fundamental knowledge regarding responsiveness to spinal cord stimulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Acute kidney injury (AKI) is a common and often devastating complication following cardiac surgery, in critical illness, and in other clinical settings, and no pharmacologic therapy reliably prevents or treats AKI. Abundant data suggest that iron excess plays a key role in AKI, particularly in the setting of cardiac surgery. We propose a 3-center, double-blind, randomized controlled trial (n=300) to test whether administration of the iron chelator, deferoxamine, prevents AKI following cardiac surgery in adult patients at high risk of AKI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A fundamental goal in neuroscience is to understand how neural circuits process sensory information to allow for adaptive behavioral responses; this project investigates how neural circuits in the mammalian olfactory system transform olfactory sensory inputs and how this transformation is shaped by the sampling behavior of the animal. Because the sense of smell presents unique problems to the nervous system in terms of stimulus detection and recognition of complex stimuli, understanding how the brain solves these problems will likely lead to general insights into how the brain processes information. These insights could be important in developing improved prosthetic sensory organs and improving therapeutic approaches to sensory system deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D) is a significant public health problem affecting ~30 million people. Obesity, insulin deficiency and hyperglycemia all precede the diagnosis of T2D and are long known to promote inflammation and ultimately lead to microvascular complications in adults. More recently, research has identified brain-related complications in adult-onset T2D, including reduced regional brain structure and function, impaired cognition, and increased lifetime risk for Alzheimer’s disease. Alarmingly, an increasing number of children and adolescents are being diagnosed with T2D, likely due to the growing prevalence and earlier onset of obesity. Youth-onset T2D appears to have a more aggressive course than adult-onset T2D, with early onset and rapid increase in complications. In addition, a few small studies of youth-onset T2D have reported robust differences in regional brain structure and cognition, suggesting that brain effects may follow the same aggressive course as the more typical complications. Unfortunately, little is known about the risk factors associated with alterations in brain structure and function in youth with T2D. To address this critical gap in knowledge, we propose to study youth across the spectrum of obesity and metabolic dysfunction. This approach will allow us to disentangle the relationship of key features of T2D risk (e.g. obesity, insulin resistance, insulin deficiency and dysglycemia) to intermediate changes that pose a risk for the brain (e.g. inflammation) and reduced brain structure and function associated with T2D in youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The approval of novel cancer therapies by healthcare agencies is contingent on endpoints that aim to capture clinical benefit, determined in part by radiologic assessment of treatment response. However, currently used metrics may not always capture treatment success or failure. The insights from this study will lay the groundwork for integrating advanced imaging and plasma circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA)-based biomarkers in the future that may be used by regulatory agencies around the globe for the purpose of assessing and approving novel precision therapies and ultimately allow the possibility for personalized precision medicine.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The way an individual responds to cues associated with rewards may be a key determinant in vulnerability to addiction and relapse. We will utilize an animal model to identify critical components of the neural circuitry that that contribute to individual differences in cue-reward learning and relapse propensity. The findings from these studies will enhance our understanding of the pathophysiology of substance abuse and could lead to novel targets for the treatment of addiction and related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Airway tree size varies in the general population and is associated with much higher risk of death from diseases linked to smoking and other noxious pollutants. This research grant renewal builds upon prior work to establish the early life-origins of airway tree size, investigate candidate mechanisms that link airway tree size to tobacco smoking-related susceptibility, and define resilient airway tree size using clinical outcomes. These aims represent key gaps in knowledge toward understanding and ultimately targeting mechanisms of resilient lung development and maintenance across the lifespan to prevent disease and improve health in the 21st century.

PHR: Relevance to Public Health: Defect in trophoblast lineage development results in early pregnancy loss or leads to pregnancies that are associated with pre-term birth, intrauterine growth restriction and preeclampsia, which cause serious adverse effects on maternal and infant health. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Southern California consists of 10 contiguous Counties and is home to 10.8 million Latinos (representing 45.2% of the population) who are disproportionally affected by multiple and co-occurring chronic diseases, namely obesity, type 2 diabetes, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, and dyslipidemia. This disparity begins to develop early in life, occurs within families, is magnified by inter-generational transmission, and is driven by multi-level factors including diet, cultural values, social determinants, economic factors, and environmental-level factors like access to healthy foods and other chemical exposures such as air pollution. Our overall goal is to understand how the complex inter-play between these multi-level factors contribute to multiple chronic disease disparities in Latinos across the life course, and to develop and evaluate the acceptance, delivery, and clinical efficacy of family- based, culturally sensitive solutions by establishing the Southern California Center for Chronic Health Disparities in Latino Families and Children (SCC-CHDLFC).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research aims to identify the neural and genetic markers of laryngeal dystonia (LD), which is a task-specific form of isolated focal dystonia characterized by involuntary spasms in the laryngeal muscles during speaking. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is expected to have an ultimate positive translational impact on establishing the enhanced criteria for improved clinical management of LD, including its early detection and accurate diagnosis. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will help reduce the burden of human disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite being a primary site of infection, the human female genital tract remains largely uninvestigated in the setting of hyperacute and acute HIV infection. Utilizing unique samples obtained from the Females Rising through Education, Support and Health (FRESH) cohort, I propose to investigate both the immune response and viral dynamics that occur in the female genital tract following natural HIV exposure by leveraging RNA sequencing, microscopic imaging, and cytokine analysis techniques. This will provide new insight into HIV pathogenesis, allow for the validation of existing experimental models, and help to accelerate the development of therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative The Louisiana Department of Agriculture and Forestry (LDAF) project entitled “Enhancing the LDAF FSMA Produce Safety Program for Continued Implementation of the FDA Produce Safety Rule Utilizing Path C (State Authority)” is intended to continue previous work completed under cooperative agreement PAR-16-137 that facilitates long term implementation of the FSMA Produce Safety Rule. This work will be accomplished by: 1.Establish and maintain Project Plan and Assessment documents to guide the development of the program. 2.Establish and maintain the foundational resources, including, but not limited to, personnel, supplies, training, authority, and agreements, needed to fulfill the project plan. 3.Provide opportunities for education and outreach on the Produce Safety Rule and LDAF’s produce regulatory program to produce farms, prioritizing covered farms. 4.Maintain a complete and accurate inventory of produce farms. 5.Maintain an inspection program that focuses on quality and national consistency. 6.Maintain a compliance and enforcement program that focuses on quality and national consistency. 7.Establish and maintain a process for responding to produce-related events that are likely to result in a produce-related illness, injury or outbreak. The overall goal of this project is to strengthen the existing LDAF FSMA Produce Safety Program.This will encourage the safe production of fresh fruits and vegetables and promote high rates of compliance with the requirements of the Produce Safety Rule.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Path C Enhancing the LDAF FSMA Produce Safety Program for Continued Implementation of the FDA Produce Safety Rule

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disease-free survival (DFS) is only achieved in 20-30% of patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML), with relapsed or recurrent AML attributed to the drug resistant leukemic stem cells (LSCs) and drugs targeting LSCs are now of interest to achieve long-term DFS. Our studies in human AML specimens have revealed that the metabolic regulator 5' AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) is preferentially activated in LSCs and is critical for their viability. Therefore, we propose to develop AMPK targeted agents that may eliminate or sensitize LSCs, reducing their propensity for drug resistance and improving the efficacy of treatments such as venetoclax which may translate into durable DFS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Preeclampsia, a cardiovascular and immune mediated disease in pregnancy, is the leading cause of maternal- fetal morbidity and mortality world-wide. The current proposal aims to prevent preeclampsia using a powerful, novel personalized medicine approach: cellular immunotherapy. If the cellular therapy is successful in preventing preeclampsia, the proposed project has the potential to positively impact the immediate and long-term cardiovascular health of women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) is widespread throughout the entire African continent and in some endemic areas over 50% of the population is exposed by adulthood. Activity of the innate immune system is key to mitigating the severity of disease and the virus has actively evolved ways to abrogate innate immune function. In this project we will define how biologically relevant primary human cells recognize and respond to RVFV infection, determine which innate signaling pathways function to provide protection from disease, and define the contribution of hematopoietic cell infection to in vivo pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Safe and healthy relationships are a critical aspect of adulthood yet can be inaccessible to adults with social challenges such as autism spectrum disorder. There is a significant and unmet need for assessment tools that objectively measure relationship behaviors to support effective development and evaluation of useful interventions in this domain. To achieve this, we aim to test the feasibility, sensitivity, and validity of a novel battery of performance-based behavioral, eye tracking, psychophysiological measures for adults with and without autism spectrum disorder.

PHR: Project Narrative Age-related neurodegenerative diseases like glaucoma have no cure and are a significant public health burden. Our research has shown that glaucoma is associated with loss of cellular energy that is amenable to metabolism-based intervention. Findings from this study will inform the development of novel therapeutics that manipulate cellular metabolism to prevent or slow the progression of glaucoma.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This is a unique randomized clinical trial in Africa comparing the two best surgical options - shunt versus endoscopic - for treating post-infectious hydrocephalus, the dominant cause in African infants. Our 1-year results demonstrated that there was no disadvantage to using the more sustainable endoscopic approach over the older standard of shunt insertion, made the surprising discovery of brain growth arrest before and brain growth catch-up after treatment, and the further discovery of brain growth stagnation during the second year of follow up despite adequate control of intracranial pressure. This present project seeks to follow this unique cohort to 10 years of age, to definitively establish whether endoscopic treatment is more sustainable for infants in the developing world, establish low field MRI as a sustainable imaging technology, and establish the capacity of both the medical and engineering sites in Uganda as research and development centers for Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Non-coding RNAs are known to carry out essential cellular functions and play important roles in cancer, but they are less understood compared to protein-coding genes. We propose to develop new analytical approaches and search genome-wide for novel cancer-driving non-coding RNAs in large-scale cancer genome and transcriptome sequencing data. We expect to discover new cancer drivers, biomarkers and potential drug targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Caspase-1 plays a key role in the innate immune response to bacterial and viral threats, and disruption of caspase-1 regulation is associated with various immune-mediated disorders and cancer. Caspase-2 has also been linked to the innate immune system and is known as a tumor suppressor. Because the mechanism of caspase-1 and caspase-2 activation are not well known, the goal of this research is to uncover the mechanistic basis of caspase-1 and caspase-2 activation, which can lead to the development of therapeutics for immune related disorders and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Mechanisms of Ovarian Endocrine Disruption at Single-Cell Resolution Developmental exposures to endocrine disrupting chemicals (EDCs) such as dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane (DDT) are associated with reproductive disease and impaired fertility across species. Yet, exact molecular mechanisms explaining how environmentally relevant exposures during key windows of ovarian differentiation elicit long-term effects on female fertility remain unclear. The proposed work pairs a translational fish model with cutting-edge single cell transcriptomics to define long-term functional and molecular consequences of DDT exposure on cell types and gene regulatory networks in the developing ovary.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In addition to their debilitating impact on health and well-being, multiple chronic conditions such as diabetes and hypertension account for 90% of Medicare spending. This project will test the ability of voice-controlled "smart" technology to deliver an already proven electronic health system (Elder Tree, or ET) for these patients; specifically, we hypothesize that older patients using ET on a smart display and speaker combination will experience even greater improvement in health factors including physical function, pain, depression, medical symptoms, loneliness, and healthcare use than will patients using ET on a laptop, because voice technology enables such easy use, thereby increasing use of the system. The proposed study will have far-reaching implications for the use of voice-assisted technology for the broad spectrum of eHealth interventions currently becoming available.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  This project is relevant to public health because we will collaborate with the NHLBI and the HeartShare Network to generate new knowledge regarding unique subtypes of heart failure with preserved ejection fraction and underlying mechanisms to ultimately improve patient outcomes. Specifically, the CHIcago Center for Accelerating nextGen Omics, deep phenotyping, and data science in Heart Failure (CHICAGO-HF) proposes to contribute to the development of retrospective and prospective cohorts of patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction and controls. We aim to strengthen the Network through our considerable experience and expertise in epidemiology, informatics, magnetic resonance imaging, and artificial intelligence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals who cannot use speech and use augmentative and alternative communication (AAC; pointing to pictures, using a speech-generating device) have limited opportunities in phonics-based literacy instruction. Acquiring even basic literacy skills can lead to increased employment opportunities, improved safety and well- being, and enhanced social engagement. This project aims to investigate the efficacy, feasibility, acceptability, and adoptability of a technology-mediated phonics-based literacy intervention (ALL; Accessible Literacy Learning) to increase six basic literacy skills of individuals who use AAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: While membrane proteins are important, constituting ~23% of the human proteome and more than 60% of current drug targets, little is known about how the cooperative action among different types of membrane proteins can be coordinated at the cell surface to precisely control the sensitivity and specificity of the downstream signaling. Our recent discovery has revealed a novel molecular mechanism by which a recently discovered spectrin-actin- based membrane skeleton structure can coordinate the interactions among major types of membrane receptors in neurons, giving rise to the downstream intracellular signaling. The goal of this proposed research is to reveal the distinctively physical molecular mechanisms by which this spectrin-actin-based membrane skeleton brings the selected groups of membrane proteins in proximity to form signaling protein complexes at the cell surface, and the results from the proposed research will not only deepen our understanding of how the subcellular compartmentalization of signaling proteins can be spatiotemporally controlled to dictate a specific signaling outcome, but also potentially inspire new strategies for the therapeutic intervention of human diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative Overconsumption of sodium is a serious risk factor of cardiovascular and cognitive malfunction. This project will examine the brain circuit that mediate sodium appetite and consequent ingestion. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will provide insights into the function and dysfunction of sodium regulatory mechanisms that optimizes dietary sodium intake.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adults with serious mental illness (SMI) have a disproportionate rate of involvement with the criminal justice system and are at high risk of recidivism, but there are no clinical interventions available in community mental health settings that specifically address criminogenic risk factors. The proposed study will finalize the development of a criminogenic focused intervention for use with people with SMI in community mental health settings and test it in a pilot randomized controlled trial. We will also gather critical input from a variety of mental health and criminal justice system stakeholders to aid in the design of implementation strategies to expediate and optimize its scalability and sustainability in community settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Childhood obesity remains highly prevalent in the United States and is a major contributor to chronic disease, but multiple socioeconomic and geographic barriers exist for children that impact access to care. Telehealth is an approach that can improve access and participation but known telehealth barriers must be examined and addressed prior to implementation. This career development award will examine telehealth approaches for childhood obesity to understand multi-level factors that impact access and participation in care and adapt a pediatric weight management program for telehealth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The overarching goal of this translational research project is to develop a new immunotherapeutic nanoparticle for intrapleural administration, aimed at mitigating the immune cold environment in malignant pleural effusion (MPE) to enhance therapeutic efficacy of anti-PD-L1 immune checkpoint blockade (ICB). Intrapleural delivery of antigen presenting cells (APCs)-targeted nanoparticle loaded with STING agonist (LNP-STING) is expected to elicit APC-mediated immune sensing of tumor antigens and cross-priming of effector T cells, thus setting a stage for favorable response to anti-PD-L1 ICB. We will test the combination immunotherapy of intrapleural LNP- STING plus anti-PD-L1 in vivo in a mouse model of MPE, and ex vivo with clinical MPE samples, and importantly, gain insights into the immunobiological mechanisms of LNP-STING interacting with the complex tumor microenvironment in MPE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Histone monoaminylation (i.e., H3 serotonylation and dopaminylation), in which the neurotransmitters are modification donors, is a newly identified epigenetic marker that plays an important role in regulating neuronal transcription. By applying chemical biology approaches, we recently discovered that the dynamics of histone monoaminylation (including installation, removal, and replacement) are regulated by a single enzyme, transglutaminase 2 (TGM2), and thereafter identified an unreported epigenetic marker (i.e., H3 histaminylation) that promotes neural rhythmicity. Our proposed research program will provide a chemical biology toolbox for investigating histone monoaminylation and elucidate its impacts on chromatin structure and function, which will build new pathophysiological connections between neuroscience, epigenetics, and psychology.
