IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Kidney disease is a common and devastating complication of diabetes, and represents a major public health problem worldwide. We have discovered inherited factors that influence risk of this complication in type 1 diabetes; in this cycle we propose to expand our approach to type 2 diabetes, increasing sample size seven-fold to augment the opportunities for genetic discovery. In addition, by combining and integrating data from several complementary approaches (genomics, epigenetics, gene expression analysis and functional studies in model systems) we hope to identify genes and biological processes that impact the development of diabetic kidney disease, and may help guide the development of improved treatments and preventive measures.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: KDA Produce Safety Program  Project Narrative The relevance of this project to public health is to minimize the risk of serious adverse health consequences or death from consumption of contaminated produce through the application of science-based minimum standards for the safe growing, harvesting, packing, and holding of produce raw agricultural commodities grown for human consumption as contained in 21 CFR Part 112. This project will allow KDA to continue to build a robust, verified farm inventory which will be shared with our federal partners. Through both the application of a robust Education/Outreach and Inspection/Compliance/Enforcement program, as promulgated in Kentucky’s Produce Safety Statute (KRS 260.765 to 260.772.) and Produce Safety Administrative Regulation (302 KAR 60:010), the KDA Produce Safety Program will ensure that both covered and exempt growers of covered produce understand and, where applicable, apply the regulatory mandates and produce safety best practices to reduce produce- related illnesses and ensure a safe, wholesome food supply for the Commonwealth and abroad.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Path C The FDA's Cooperative Agreement Program for States and Territories to Implement a National Produce Safety Program (U2F) Clinical Trials Not Allowed

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dengue viruses has been identified in 128 countries, exposing nearly 4 billion people, over half the world's population, to risk of dengue disease. There is an urgent need to make safe and effective dengue vaccines available, particularly in areas where dengue is endemic. This study will use a specialized vaccine-challenge trial design to test the safety and efficacy of the NIH's lead dengue vaccine candidate, TV005, in dengue- endemic Bangladesh as the critical next step in product development of this promising vaccine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women who use drugs in Tanzania shoulder a disproportionate burden of the HIV epidemic in Tanzania. Mental disorders, including depression, anxiety, and post-traumatic stress disorder, are high among women who use drugs and are known barriers to HIV prevention, including pre-exposure prophylaxis for HIV (PrEP). The study will adapt and pilot motivational interviewing for PrEP engagement and the Common Elements Treatment Approach, a transdiagnostic psychotherapy intervention for the treatment a range of mood and anxiety disorders, for delivery by paraprofessionals in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, to optimize PrEP engagement among women who use drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For productive infection, human viruses control the function of organelles by rewiring the membrane contact sites (MCS) that facilitate dynamic organelle-organelle networks, which we uncovered occurs across viral infections. We further discovered a new, infection-induced mitochondria-ER encapsulation, which we propose addresses the paradox of how certain viruses promote cellular respiration despite inducing mitochondrial fragmentation. This proposal will establish how mitochondria-ER encapsulations inhibit host responses and facilitate metabolic reprogramming to meet the energetic needs of virion production, of which the molecular determinants have broad implications for viral pathogenesis and metabolic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The goal is to revolutionize physiological measurement of vocal fold vibration and establish linkage with perceptual measurement of voice quality in connected speech. This research will advance scientific knowledge of the effects of coarticulation on phonatory onset/offset, and peri-phonatory vibration and establish their relations to perceived voice quality. Computational modeling of voice quality perception and machine learning will harness the large data sets associated with high-speed videoendoscopic imaging in connected speech to identify physical measures that ultimately may lead to better assessment and management of voice disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Recent advances in scientific research have allowed more in-depth data collection from epidemiological studies of infectious diseases, but predicting outcomes of interest with available data sources in a timely manner remains a grand challenge. This proposal aims to refine predictive models for several neglected and emerging infectious diseases by incorporating new mechanisms better handling missing data and time- dependent information. The methodological development and prediction tools resulted from this project will have a broader long-term impact beyond the scope of the infectious diseases covered in the current proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will equip teens with the skills to produce high quality, compelling health video content for the PBS NewsHour, local PBS stations and Student Reporting Labs (SRL) audiences, which will increase youth engagement with health sciences, including exposure to health science careers, through project-based learning resources that leverage storytelling and journalistic integrity. Building from previous SEPA research findings that showed success in a select number of journalism classes that produced health stories, SRL is ready to take our programming to the next level by working with STEM program leaders, educators and teens to create peer-to-peer STEM health reporting and educational resources supporting health literacy for a wide range of classrooms and STEM programs, focusing intentionally on strategies to include groups under-represented in STEM fields. This project will ultimately support hundreds of STEM educators and programs with the tools to communicate the value of health science, rebuild trust and introduce teens from diverse backgrounds to pathways for meaningful, lifelong engagement with health science issues, both as informed citizens able to combat misinformation and as the next generation of health professionals, in careers and contexts unimaginable today.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) Perception, cognition and action require the coordination of neurons spanning the entire brain, including the cortex and subcortical regions, and numerous brain disorders involve some form of impairment of that communication and coordination. To better diagnose and treat brain disorders, it is crucial to understand the basic mechanisms by which neural circuits interact across the brain and how those interactions give rise to cognitive processes and behavior. The proposed research investigates how cortical and subcortical circuits give rise to the state of arousal, and how intervention in those circuits can modulate that internal state and influence behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The goal of this research is to evaluate whether repeated spaced retrieval practice promotes word learning to a greater extent than repeated study without retrieval prompts in children with autism spectrum disorders (ASD). This study will assess multiple aspects of word learning including word form (phonological information for each novel word), word meaning (semantic information associated with each novel word), and generalization of newly taught words. This comprehensive assessment of word learning is particularly important for the ASD population because they have deficits in word learning, with particular challenges with semantic learning and generalization; therefore, identification of effective teaching strategies (i.e., retrieval practice) will have important implications for theories of language learning in children with ASD and will yield meaningful clinical/educational implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will develop an ultrasound-mediated sensitizing pretreatment to improve the outcomes of radiation therapy of solid tumors. Specifically, we will use sensitizing nanobubbles excited by ultrasound to locally prime tumors before external beam radiotherapy, reducing the radiation dose and leading to compete tumor regression. We will test the approach in treatment of prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1 (MEN1/MENIN) has emerged as an important drug target for subsets of aggressive acute leukemia due to successes in clinical trials of small molecule MENIN inhibitors. In this proposal we aim to further understand the mechanism by which these inhibitors produce a therapeutic effect by studying a newly discovered E3 ligase involved in drug dependent MENIN protein degradation which appears to be essential for therapeutic activity. Inspired by our preliminary data that lower MENIN protein levels are essential for MENIN inhibitor sensitivity we further aim to develop a new therapeutic strategy of small molecule MENIN protein degraders that can rapidly and more deeply deplete MENIN protein, all with the intention of improving outcomes for patients with acute leukemias and furthering the understanding of the function of this emergent drug target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the recent approval of targeted agents such as acalabrutinib (A), venetoclax (V), and obinutuzumab (O), outcomes for patients with high risk, TP53-aberrant chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) remain suboptimal. This project aims to evaluate, through a phase 2, investigator-initiated clinical trial, whether a triplet combination regimen of AVO is effective as time-limited therapy for previously untreated patients with high risk CLL. We will utilize innovative functional laboratory tests such as BH3 profiling and high-throughput kinase activity mapping, as well as genomic analyses, to study samples from the patients on the trial to predict which patients will respond best to the AVO regimen and what resistance mechanisms emerge in patients treated with this novel regimen.

PHR: Project Narrative Although telehealth has been widely implemented during the COVID-19 pandemic, real- world data remain limited regarding the disparities in perinatal telehealth uptake among vulnerable pregnant women and the associated health disparities. Understanding the role of telehealth uptake in mitigating the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic on minority pregnant women and those in rural communities is essential to developing necessary policies for equitable adaptation of telehealth for maternity care. Our study will address vital gaps in evidence regarding the consequences of the pandemic, distinct state telehealth policies, and telehealth uptake on the four aspects of maternity care: access, quality, outcomes, and expenditures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC) are the main etiologic agent of urinary tract infections in humans that result in enormous health and social costs across the globe. There is now evidence that UPEC strains routinely colonize food animals serving as a likely link between food-animal E. coli and human UTIs. This longitudinal study will define domestic animal host features of UPEC and model human exposures to uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC) in poor communities of Northwest Ecuador to understand the drivers of exposure to UPEC among households.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative About 2.5% of the US population is affected by alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD), which represents the 8th most common cause of mortality. Currently there is no FDA approved therapy available for the treatment of ALD. This project will examine phosphodiesterase 4 (PDE4)-mediated pathogenic pathways in ALD. The findings of this project will lead to the development of novel therapies targeting PDE4 for treatment of ALD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The project seeks to define the full ligand space monitored by the large gene family of plant cell surface receptor kinases. Plant receptor pathways will be used for orthogonal control of mammalian signaling pathways with applications in biotechnology and medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a progressive and ultimately fatal disease with limited treatment options due to poorly understood pathogenic mechanism and highly variable clinical course. This proposal aims to apply PET-MR imaging to quantify molecular abnormalities in the lungs of IPF patients and determine if such measures can predict the pace of disease progression and determine whether the patient is responding to anti- fibrotic therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) have potent activity against HIV infection but their clinical use is limited by significant adverse drug reactions (ADR). In the present proposal we seek to determine the contribution of dysregulated lysosomal signaling to NRTI ADR, profile and select compounds for NRTI ADR- free properties, and then functionally test whether those candidates present with less ADR in preclinical models of HIV infection and toxicity. The proposed research is relevant to public health because we anticipate that this research project will provide a foundation for the development of safe and effective NRTI for better treatment and quality of life in patients undergoing HIV therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma, a lethal primary brain tumor, has limited treatment options; the current standard therapy with combined chemotherapy (with a drug called temozolomide) and radiation therapy results in a median survival of only 16-18 months highlighting the urgent need for novel therapies. In a search for drugs that can overcome resistance to chemotherapy and radiation therapy, we have identified that blocking the activity of heat shock protein 90 (Hsp90), a protein complex that is critical for tumor cell survival and treatment resistance, using a novel drug called Onalespib which we have shown can cross the blood brain barrier, can make glioma cells more sensitive to temozolomide and radiation therapy, slow down glioma growth in animals and extend their survival. Building on these promising results, we will conduct a trial that will assess the clinical benefit of blocking Hsp90 using onalespib along with chemoradiation in brain tumors and which bears promise of providing a new treatment option for patients with glioblastoma as well as providing valuable new information related to whether onalespib can block its targets in tumor tissue that can benefit studies in other cancers which are exploring the effects of Onalespib.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will contribute to our understanding of the basis of language impairments among individuals at high risk for neurodegenerative disorders, as well as links between language, executive functions, and quality of life. This study will examine language production in a cross- sectional sample of adult males and females with the FMR1 premutation and healthy matched controls, and in relation to a key cognitive domain among premutation carriers - executive function. Given the prevalence of the FMR1 premutation (females: 1/~150, males: 1/~470), this work has the potential to expand our understanding of candidate language markers associated with an FMR1-associated neurodegenerative condition (i.e., FXTAS) and the phenotypic scope of the FMR1 premutation, thus informing links between genetics and language.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Staphylococcus bacteria are the primary cause of healthcare-associated infections in neonatal intensive care units and the leading cause of skin and soft tissue infections worldwide, necessitating novel treatments that enhance early-life immunity. Although innate lymphoid cells and innate-like T cells comprise a substantial effector population in neonatal tissues, their contributions to immunity during this period remain poorly understood. Combining state-of-the-art approaches from immunology, genetics, and bioinformatics, this project will further our understanding of early-life immunity and lead to the development of novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: OVERALL Narrative METALS The University of New Mexico Metals Exposure and Toxicity Assessment on tribal Lands in the Southwest Superfund Research Center (METALS) will continue strong partnerships with Indigenous partners from Navajo Nation and Laguna Pueblo to understand community toxicity resulting from exposure to metal mixtures in legacy waste from the Cold War weapons build-up. Millions of tons of waste remain at >4500 abandoned uranium mine sites in the 15 Western states that are home to >50% of the US Indigenous population. Our integrated team focuses on community informed, solution-oriented team science to reduce the risk of identified chronic disease risk from these exposures through development of partnered environmental and clinical interventions.

Complementary studies in experimental models are designed to identify mechanisms of toxicity that can be targeted for future population- based interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Project 2 - ENVIRONMENTAL PROJECT 2 – ESE PM - NARRATIVE This project examines the potential exposures through inhalation and ingestion of toxic metals carried in ultrafine-grained particulate matter (PM) especially nanoparticles experienced by tribal communities living in close proximity to abandoned uranium mines (AUMs). The bioavailability and bioacessibility of nanoparticulates for uptake into agricultural crops via root and folial systems will be examined by field and experimental studies. Understanding these pathways for community exposures to metals is essential for providing comprehensive, real-world exposure estimates for risk reduction and prioritization strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Harnessing the power of the T cell response to kill tumor cells is proving to be a highly effective anti-cancer strategy. Most approaches focus on re-targeting T cells to better recognize tumor cells. In contrast our approach focuses on improving the quality of the T cell response, to enable T cells to better persist and function in the metabolically challenging environment of the tumor, and this can be layered upon potentially any T cell tumor- targeting strategy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Communities living around legacy and active uranium and hard rock mines are concerned about metal exposures that may produce adverse health effects. This project evaluates the effects of drinking water exposures to potentially toxic metals (uranium, vanadium, and arsenic) alone and in combination. Our previous work shows that immune and non-immune cells in the gastrointestinal tract receive high exposures to metals leading to immune changes that will be further investigated in animal and human studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Project Narrative There is great concern regarding the potential health risks associated with increased exposure to metals due to legacy uranium and hard rock mining in the Southwestern United States. This project evaluates the effects of inhalation exposure to metal-rich particulates alone or in mixtures on immune dysregulation and the potential to lead to lung and systemic autoimmunity. Information gained will provide novel mechanistic insight into the potential risks associated with exposure to airborne metals and their role in metal-mediated immune modulation and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE African American menthol cigarette smokers experience disproportionate tobacco-caused health burdens and have increased difficulty quitting smoking. Our novel examination of momentary predictors of smoking lapse will further our understanding of how to prevent smoking lapses and relapse among African American menthol smokers who try to quit smoking. These data can be used to inform high-impact, technology-supported observational studies and interventions aimed at mitigating tobacco-caused disparities among African Americans and menthol cigarette smokers.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The co-occurrence of metal mixtures has been reported in natural geologic deposits and Superfund sites affected by mining legacy. The proposed research will contribute novel mechanistic insights that will enable the development of bioreactors catalyzed by plant-fungal symbiosis coupled with adsorption and precipitation using natural minerals for sustainable bioremediation of metal mixtures. The knowledge resulting from the proposed project is essential to risk assessment and to the advancement of bioremediation risk reduction strategies for metal mixtures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS THE STATE UNIV OF NJ CAMDEN
PHR: NARRATIVE The main goal of this research program is to elucidate the role of mammalian inorganic polyphosphate (polyP), an understudied molecule, in the stress response in mammalian cells. To accomplish this, using mammalian cellular models in which the levels of mitochondrial polyP will be modified, we will study the effects of polyP on the regulation of mammalian bioenergetics and mitochondrial physiology; and elucidate the signaling role of polyP in mammalian cells. Our findings will not only increase our knowledge of mitochondrial physiology, but they could also lead to the use of the metabolism of mitochondrial polyP as a valid and innovative pharmacological target in a wide-range of pathologies where mitochondrial dysfunction has been described, ranging from rare ophthalmological diseases to the most common neurodegenerative disorders.
PI_NAMEs: SOLESIO TORREGROSA, MARIA DE LA ENCARNACION  (contact)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hookworm infection is a leading cause of anemia and malnutrition in developing countries, especially sub- Saharan Africa. Using human field samples and parasites cultivated in an animal model, we will conduct studies to define host immune responses to hookworm infection. The studies proposed here will provide novel insights that will aid the future development of effective monitoring and control strategies for human hookworm infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Project Narrative: Community Engagement Core The METALS SRP Community Engagement Core links Native American community members exposed to hazardous substances in uranium mine wastes to the METALS environmental and biomedical projects that aim to reduce exposures through innovative remediation methods, biospecimen collections and biomonitoring to ascertain exposures, and community participation in ongoing federal and tribal Superfund remedial action decisions. CEC seeks to reduce health risks of exposures to mixed-metal mining wastes in other parts of the Western U.S. by sponsoring webinars in Indigenous Science that will emphasize for the national SRP network a place-based, participatory approach to the vexing and widespread problem of cleaning up large-volume metal-laden wastes.

PHR: Project Narrative – Data Management and Analysis Core (DMAC) The Data Management and Analysis Core (DMAC) has direct public health relevance as it will provide analysis support for the UNM METALS research projects, and perform comprehensive assessments of environmental exposure profiles to search for disease risk factors. The DMAC will also develop integrative modeling of the environmental and biological research data to detect unique exposure profiles for risk classification and disease prevention. It will also provide valid data and scientific conclusions that can be translated to inform intervention strategies with the ultimate goal to improve community health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative / Lay Language Description Pathogens that cause diarrheal disease account for an immense global public health burden, primarily among young children in low-resource settings. The use of antibodies to study the epidemiology of diarrhea-causing pathogens has potential to improve our measurement of pathogen transmission in research and surveillance. This project will advance the epidemiologic methods used to measure diarrhea-causing pathogen exposure at the population level, by completing the first comprehensive study that pairs antibody-based and stool-based measures of infection among a birth cohort living across a rural-urban gradient in Ecuador.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on ethical and social implications of medical genomics for patients with rare diseases. Using in-depth, mix-methods research, this work will develop concrete, pragmatic communication strategies that can improve care for patients with rare genetic disorders. Therefore, the project is relevant to NHGRI’s mission because it pertains to analyzing the impact of genomics on society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TOLEDO HEALTH SCI CAMPUS
PHR: Drug resistance and minimal residual disease in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) leads to aggressive tumors and metastasis leading to many fatalities. Altered tumor protein profile in TNBC contributes to therapy resistance in the clinic. The proposal outlines a strategy to identify the mechanisms through which eIF4A1 might facilitate drug resistance program in TNBC Finally, we outline strategies to overcome chemoresistance by co-targeting eIF4A1 and its downstream translational targets in breast cancer stem-like cells (BCSCs) and bulk tumor cells in metastatic TNBC.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Increasing physical activity and sleep during pregnancy may help mitigate risk for adverse pregnancy outcomes in overweight and obese pregnant women. How the interdependent relationships between physical activity, sedentary behavior, and sleep within a 24-hour movement framework during pregnancy affect risk for altered maternal metabolic profile and subsequent childhood obesity risk in infants remains unclear. This project will guide development of clinical and public health recommendations and interventions for 24-hour movement during pregnancy by studying the impact of 24-hour movement profiles on maternal metabolic profile and childhood obesity risk factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Olfactory dysfunction (OD) occurs in the majority of elderly adults and is often unrecognized. It has been shown to have significant impacts upon patient health and mortality, thus improved understanding of how OD occurs in individual subjects and its progression is sorely needed. Future treatments to prevent or reverse OD in aging adults will depend upon improved understanding of mechanisms by which it occurs and its impact upon patient health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE COVID-19 vaccines have been inequitably distributed and uptake has lagged especially in underserved communities necessitating culturally relevant and linguistically appropriate, dynamic, and scalable strategies for immediate and long-term success of COVID-19 vaccine uptake and pandemic mitigation. Addressing COVID-19 vaccine uptake behaviors offers an opportunity to concurrently improve engagement in other preventive health behaviors that are important public health priorities (e.g., diabetes management, cancer screenings, recommended adult vaccines). We propose to co-refine, test, and scale a multicomponent health program to address the multi-level barriers to vaccine uptake and engagement in primary and secondary preventative healthcare in immigrant, refugee, Latino, and Black, Indigenous People of Color (BIPOC) communities in San Diego.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacterial ligand-induced murine vasculitis, coronary arteritis and myocarditis is highly dependent of NLRP3 inflammasome activation and bioactive IL-1β release. Here, we will characterize the immune cells infiltrating the inflamed tissues and investigate how the modulation of Sirtuin-1 activity could prevent the vascular innate immune responses leading to vascular inflammation and injury. We will also decipher the immune mechanisms by which Sirtuin-1 may lessen the inflammatory response by blocking the NLRP3 inflammasome response and the autophagy/mitophagy axis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed work is relevant to public health and to the mission of the NICHD to improve child and adolescent health, and reduce disparities in care. Although most children receive emergency care in general emergency departments (EDs), national studies have shown that pediatric preparedness is low. Presence of a pediatric emergency care coordinator (PECC) is associated with increased preparedness, but limited data are available to assess the association between PECC status, quality of care and outcomes for children. This work will address this knowledge gap to identify actionable strategies to improve care for children receiving care in general EDs.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative (3 sentences): We have developed a research network of pediatric critical care physicians across 5 academic centers to enroll 370 children in a Phase III double-masked placebo-controlled randomized trial of high-dose AZM [20 mg/kg (IV) x 3 days] to test the overarching hypothesis that administration of AZM during acute, RSV-induced respiratory failure be beneficial. We will test whether high-dose AZM administration will result in 1. decreased length of hospital stay, duration of ICU stay and duration of oxygen therapy, 2. decreased number of wheezing episodes and time to first wheeze 12 months post-acute infection, and 3. whether nasal markers of matrix metalloproteinase-9 driven lung inflammation will be decreased in patients receiving AZM, and predictive of outcome. A positive result from this trial will represent a paradigm shift in the management of severe RSV infection, as the first successful treatment for acute and post-RSV related respiratory exacerbation and has the potential to identify novel biomarkers of disease outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Empagliflozin, a novel diabetic medication that targets the kidney, has recently been shown to improve cardiovascular survival in diabetic and non-diabetic patients with minimal to moderate kidney dysfunction. We will examine if empagliflozin is safe in patients with end-stage kidney disease on chronic dialysis. If our study shows that empagliflozin is safe and is well tolerated in dialysis patients, it will encourage future studies to evaluate its efficacy to reduce heart failure risk and improve survival in dialysis patients and provide a new potential therapeutic option.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Aggression varies substantially between different people, and extreme levels of aggression have negative consequences for individuals and society. This proposal will leverage genetic tools and resources in an emerging model system to investigate the genetic and neuronal basis of variability in aggression. Elucidating the genetic architecture underlying differences in aggression in natural populations will help establish why individual differences in social behaviors manifest, which could lead to long term solutions for treatment and management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: This project will utilize microglia and cerebral organoids derived from induced pluripotent stem cells to study how HIV causes inflammation and neuronal damage in the brain, leading to HIV-associated neurocognitive disorders (HAND). Signaling pathways that result in inflammation following HIV infection of microglia will be a focus of investigation. The mechanisms underlying the adverse effects of methamphetamine on the HIV- infected brain will defined in this model system.

PHR: Programmed cell death signaling pathways are integral components of the host response to infection, yet how they contribute to inflammation during sepsis remains incompletely defined. This program aims to define mechanisms by which cell death signaling pathways contribute to septic inflammation and inflammatory dysregulation, thereby identifying therapeutic targets and strategies for a lethal and highly prevalent disease process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The parasympathetic nervous system controls heart rate and this is perturbed in many heart diseases, including heart failure, arrhythmia after myocardial infarction, cardiac sudden death, and cardiac autonomic neuropathy (CAN) in diabetes. Parasympathetic control of the heart (e.g., heart rate variability) is a robust indicator of cardiac health and predictor of mortality and morbidity, though the neurobiological basis of this control is only partly known. A better understanding of the parasympathetic cells, circuitry, and signals which control heart rate will reveal novel therapeutic targets and strategies for treating heart diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) is a critical public health issue characterize by heterogeneous pathologic mechanisms that contribute to symptoms and poor outcomes across several different subgroups of patients. Understanding to the heterogeneous nature of HFpEF, randomized trials have been unable to identify pharmacological therapies that improve symptoms or clinical outcomes in patients with HFpEF on a large scale. The goal of the current proposal is to establish a large cohort of deeply phenotyped patients with HF to help with better understanding differential mechanisms of adverse outcomes in patients with HFpEF and identifying subgroups of patients that are likely to benefit from targeted therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: NARRATIVE The objective of this study is to improve the performance of lung cancer screening by optimizing the management of screen-detected pulmonary nodules. To do this, we will develop a simulation model, the Multi- Racial and Ethnic Lung Cancer Model (MELCAM), to perform comparative effectiveness and cost- effectiveness analyses to identify optimal nodule management algorithm(s). Our results will reduce harms from false-positive findings and maximize benefits from lung cancer early cancer detection by computed tomography screening.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Wolbachia bacteria are the most common endosymbionts in nature. Vector-control groups are attempting to establish pathogen-blocking Wolbachia strains in mosquito populations to reduce the transmission of human diseases, particularly dengue and Zika. This research will identify and evaluate the mechanisms that govern the spread and maintenance of Wolbachia in host populations.

PHR: Narrative Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of death worldwide. The Translational Cardiovascular Research and Entrepreneurship Training Program is focused on training the next generation of PhD scientists to be capable of both making discoveries in the molecular mechanisms of cardiovascular disease and leading research programs to guide the translation of those discoveries into effective therapies that can be applied in clinical medicine. This training program will therefore contribute to accelerating the translation of laboratory discoveries into clinical therapies that directly impact our ability to improve treatment of human cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public Health Relevance: The volume of biomedical research literature and data, and electronic health records is exploding exponentially, making it almost impossible for investigators to query such almost infinite information for new connections that might exploited to improve human health. This application proposes to develop a next generation artificial intelligence-based program to rapidly and efficiently query biomedical and health record information for new, unexplored connections between HIV infection and substanses of abuse comorbidities. These new connections will furthermore be prioritized for those connections that might already have a potential treatment, called drug repurposing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative The proposed research is relevant globally to public health because each year injury is a leading cause of over four million deaths, and over half of survivors suffer from organ failure. Platelets contribute to the pathobiology of organ failure through thromboinflammation, and in many diseases characterized by organ failure, studying the platelet transcriptome has improved mechanistic understandings and driven exploration of platelet-based therapeutics. Platelets are anucleate and lack RNA synthesis, providing the cleanest transcriptomic view of RNA modification in human biology; thus, this proposal seeks to re-imagine how we understand, measure, and intervene on early alterations in platelets after injury by focusing on the platelet transcriptome to 1) identify novel molecular biomarkers and preventative targets of development of organ failure after injury, and 2) innovate our understanding of physiologically driven RNA modification through the ideal anucleate biology of platelets under the optimal acute physiologic changes of injury.

PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) is common, its mechanisms are not well understood, and there are few proven treatments; this problem will be addressed by HeartShare. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative In the human body, rhythms of metabolism play an essential role in maintaining normal function. Disrupting these rhythms can contribute to many types of disease, including diabetes, cancer, and aging. However, the effect that metabolic rhythms have on cells is still not fully understood. This study will investigate how changing metabolic rhythms can activate or deactivate certain genes, helping us to understand the connection between these rhythms and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary nodules (PNs) are detected via computed tomography (CT) in approximately 2 million adults in the U.S. each year, but the current diagnostic process for PN evaluation and management results in delayed cancer diagnoses and unnecessary invasive biopsy procedures among individuals with benign diagnoses. Existing clinical malignancy risk prediction models provide only modest diagnostic accuracy, but radiomics- based computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) tools, which synthesize quantitative features from CT imaging data to predict cancer risk, may help clinicians estimate PN malignancy risk more accurately. This proposal will evaluate the clinical utility, clinical effectiveness, and cost-effectiveness of a CAD-based risk stratification strategy for PN evaluation and management, with the goal of optimizing the PN diagnostic process to improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Hypothalamic amenorrhea (HA) occurs during reproductive years and results in ovulatory dysfunction, anovulation and infertility which can be prolonged from months to years and is characterized by varying combinations of psychosocial stress, anxiety, high levels of physical activity and/or weight loss. Data from our group indicates that one-third of women with HA (mean age: 27 yrs) have preclinical CVD measured noninvasively as vascular dysfunction and vascular inflammation. Our application will study HA as a marker of fertility status for cardiovascular health and perform dense-phenotyping using remote patient monitoring and patient reported outcomes to determine which HA phenotype are related to preclinical CVD and inflammation, and expand our analyses to a large population cohort with 30-year CVD risk factors and CVD event follow-up.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Allogeneic Human MEsenchymal Stem Cell (MSC) Injection in Patients with Hypoplastic Left Heart Syndrome (HLHS): a Phase IIb Clinical Trial (ELPIS) requires a Data Coordinating Center (DCC) for project coordination, administration, data management, and biostatistical support. ELPIS is designed to determine the efficacy of mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) treatment in HLHS patients undergoing the stage II operation for HLHS by determining the improvement of right ventricular function as measured by the diastolic mass indexed on cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (CMRI). When the DCC fulfills its requirements in collaboration with the Clinical Coordinating Center (CCC), we will be able to answer this important research question to determine the efficacy of MSC's for a primary endpoint with clinical relevance to this HLHS patient population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE The incidence of KSHV infection and associated disease in the developing and developed world will continue to grow as KSHV transmission spreads and the population becomes immunodeficient due to HIV-1 infection or iatrogenic agents associated with organ transplantation. Unfortunately, despite the gains documented with anti- retroviral therapy to inhibit progression to AIDS, KSHV-associated disease is still widespread, implying more effective therapies are required to stem the incidence of disease. The results from the proposed studies utilizing the well-studied and characterized nonhuman primate (NHP) model should help elucidate the roles of viral factors involved in infection, persistence and disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oral immunotherapy (OIT) is a promising treatment for food allergy; however, it may cause gastrointestinal side effects including eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE). The overall goal of the proposed research is to understand the mechanisms underlying the gastrointestinal side effects of OIT. We will pursue this goal by studying eosinophil and other immune responses in the blood and the esophagus during a clinical trial of dupilumab with milk OIT, which may help us improve treatments for food allergy and better understand the pathogenesis of EoE.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the fact that a substantial number of children struggle with reading comprehension (RC), and that schools prominently focus on having adequate RC for various types of texts, including stories and informational text, there is scant knowledge about the neurocognitive correlates of RC for different text types, or how readers process texts for optimal RC. This project aims to determine which brain networks are: (1) differentially linked to various text types and reader profiles and (2) predict optimal RC outcomes in children ages 10-12. Our ultimate goal is to understand the best way for children to learn new information through reading so that we can better understand how to effectively individualize instruction in a way that maximizes academic success and prevents academic failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Centrosomes are structures inside cells that nucleate and organize long fibers called microtubules, which attach to DNA and separate it during embryo development and stem cell divisions. This proposal will determine how centrosomes assemble, generate thousands of microtubules, and resist microtubule-mediated forces without suffering mechanical failure. The long-term goal is to identify the molecular and material causes of disorders caused by centrosome dysregulation, such as microcephaly, primary dwarfism, and various cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Convergent evidence from animal and human studies have strongly implicated functional perturbations in the subgenual anterior cingulate cortex (sgACC) in depression. However, it is not known how dysfunction within specific sub-circuits of this heterogenous structure map to specific depression-related symptom domains. To address this gap, we propose a rigorous translational neuroscience study to define the distinct circuit-specific mechanisms of anhedonia and anxiety in humans with depression, building upon work in non-human primates, and converging human evidence from our laboratories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Molecular and Cellular Mechanisms of Copper-Dependent Nutrient Signaling and Metabolism PROJECT NARRATIVE The transition metal copper (Cu), which is acquired as a dietary nutrient, contributes to the balance between cell proliferation and cell death that is essential for life. An emerging paradigm in nutrient sensing and protein regulation, termed metalloallostery, whereby protein activity is controlled by Cu at non-catalytic sites has expanded the contribution of Cu to signaling events and enabled therapeutic exploitation of Cu-dependent disease associated cellular processes. This proposal will build on this new and clinically relevant signaling paradigm by delineating molecular and cellular mechanisms that underlie Cu-dependent adaptations to nutrient scarcity that are critical for sustaining energy balance for survival under physiological conditions and in diseases settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although oxygenated lipids play critical roles in health and disease, the biological significance of many oxygenated lipid remains incomplete. This project presents an innovative basic research program to investigate the signaling machinery that regulates the synthesis and function of bioactive lipids. Deciphering the function of novel signaling lipids will provide valuable insight into the initiation and progression of a broad range of diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Extremely high-throughput mapping of protein, RNA, and chromatin interactions in health and disease  Project narrative This project will develop extremely high-throughput technologies and companion bioinformatics tools for mapping diverse types of molecular interactions at the genomic scale. I will identify protein-protein, RNA-protein and RNA- chromatin changes at whole-genome scale in diabetes related vascular complications, specifically in hyperglycemia and chronic inflammation-induced irreversible alterations vascular endothelial cells. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antibody dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) partially protects exposed infants from acquiring neutralization-resistant HIV-1 from their chronically infected mothers and it decreases infected infant mortality. This proposal will investigate ADCC selection pressure during mother to child transmission and estimate ADCC impact on level of infected cells and inflammation in infected infants. We will identify the ADCC antibodies that influence mother to child transmission and characterize their properties, which may highlight novel avenues for future vaccine strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Quality control pathways that maintain the integrity of biological entities at different levels, including single molecules, complexes, and organelles, are important for the pathogenesis and pathophysiology of a wide range of human diseases. Little is known about whether and how these quality control pathways crosstalk with each other in response to pathological changes. This project is designed to characterize the interaction of different quality control pathways and understand how their defects contribute to disease pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Malformations of the oral cavity are among the most common birth defects in the US. Progress in design of therapeutic interventions is delayed by an incomplete understanding of the genetic underpinnings of these disorders and our inability to create models of relevant oral cell types from induced pluripotent stem cells. We propose to use spatial transcriptomics on donated human fetal tissue, to reveal details of gene regulatory networks regulating differentiation of relevant oral cell types, and to design growth factor cocktail paradigms to create these cell types in vitro.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Evaluating interventions that consider both social communication and disruptive behavior strategies is critical for children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) who have challenges in both domains, which limit a family's participation in everyday activities. Understanding when, in what sequence, and how best to teach parents to use social communication and disruptive behavior interventions is critical to reducing family burden and increasing the efficiency and efficacy of each intervention. Developing and evaluating interventions for children with ASD supports NIDCD's mission of behavioral research aimed to support social communication in children with ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Endothelial cell migration and cell-cell interactions are fundamental processes mediating physiological angiogenesis and they are often dysregulated in human diseases. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Working with independently owned restaurants, a common source of calorie-rich, nutrient-poor foods in predominantly minority, low-income urban neighborhoods, has the potential to improve dietary quality, and contribute to cancer prevention. This study uses systems science approaches to sustainably improve access to healthier foods in independently owned restaurants by: 1) testing the effects of a novel intervention called FRESH (Focus on Restaurant Engagement to Strengthen Health) on dietary quality, health indicators and other outcomes in African American and Latinx communities, and 2) developing a system dynamics model to allow stakeholders to virtually test FRESH strategies in their own communities. The resulting restaurant intervention simulation model offers potential cost savings from avoided trial-and-error testing, and will support community-based cancer prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Modern cancer research requires investigators who are skilled in a wide variety of advanced and innovative laboratory techniques and knowledge in both gene expression regulation and the fundamental of tissue/organ development and homeostasis. These Cold Spring Harbor annual three-week short courses offer specialized training in a residential setting that immediately impacts the progress of the trainees’ research. The courses also promote collaboration and exchange of ideas between faculty and trainees, and thus represent a significant and valuable investment towards accelerating cancer research by educating select cadres of researchers in the latest methods and concepts in these disciplines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is relevant to public health because it seeks to develop personalized anti-tumor vaccines, focusing here on the childhood malignancy neuroblastoma. The research is highly relevant to the NIH mission and the urgent unmet need of developing rational evidence-based therapeutic and relapse preventative strategies to reduce the health burden of cancer. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative About 13% of US adults, some 30 million people, suffer from nasal sinus disease. Although nasal obstruction and smell loss are two of the major symptoms of the disease that are crucial to disease management, currently we lack clinical tools to effectively evaluate the mechanisms contributing to these symptoms. The proposed study aims to develop novel clinical tools to better evaluate and relieve patients’ nasal obstructive symptoms and to enable patients and clinicians to make more informed, personalized decisions regarding treatment strategy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative/Abstract Chronic joint destruction is a primary source of morbidity in rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Despite advances in treatment, there are currently no therapies which target both immune and stromal/bone pathology in RA. This goal of this application is to better understand the biology of the CD47 pathway in RA and to investigate whether treatments targeting this pathway can serve as novel therapeutic strategies which may not only treat but possibly reverse arthritis and bone destruction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many diseases, including Azheimer’s, Parkinson’s, and Huntington’s diseases, are caused by an abnormal accumulation of proteins, yet the pathways that degrade proteins are not fully understood. The goal of this proposal is to characterize a ubiquitin-independent protein degradation pathway that may be involved in degrading misfolded and/or oxidatively-damaged proteins. This work will provide fundamental insights into protein degradation and may lead to new methods for treating diseases caused by aberrant proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative Compared to polydisperse nanoparticles, precise nanoparticles built by molecular approaches provide better reproducibility, uniformity, and more reliable quantification in biological and medical applications. The hexakisadducts of fullerene C60 make excellent structural scaffolds to build multivalent molecular nanoparticles. The proposed work will use synthetic chemistry to build a series of MRI and fluorescent probes with multiplex functional ligands, and structural precision unmatched by conventional nanoparticles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Drug compounds with a higher proportion of sp3 carbons and chiral centers tend to be more successful in the clinic, but few catalytic methods exist to perform selective late-stage dearomatizations of complex organic molecules. Heterogeneous arene hydrogenation would be an appealing method to generate six sp3 carbon centers in a single reaction, but existing catalysts suffer from poor chemo- and stereoselectivity. This proposal describes a heterogeneous substrate-directed strategy using noble metal alloy catalysts for the chemo- and stereoselective hydrogenation of arenes and hindered olefins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) affect millions of women, with profound health, social, and economic implications. The goal of this research is to provide a deeper understanding of individual, social, and environmental risk and protective factors for LUTS development in women across the life course. Findings will be used to inform preventative strategies that will help reduce the burden of LUTS and promote bladder health in girls and women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Periodontitis is a prevalent disease causing destruction of the tooth-supporting tissues and may adversely affect systemic health. Preliminary studies indicate that a protein expressed by periodontal tissue resident cells, designated Del-1, acts as a gatekeeper of inflammation. This project investigates the hypothesis that Del- 1 additionally promotes resolution of inflammation and restores tissue integrity, thereby paving the way to a new class of endogenous therapeutic molecules for treating periodontitis.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will examine the short-, medium-, and long-term health, social and economic effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on an underserved and vulnerable population of young adults who have been followed since birth along with their primary caregivers who are entering middle age. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This project is motivated by two significant overarching problems (1) existing avenues for reading intervention in the US are not available to most children in need of help, and (2) across children there is substantial variability in pre-to-post intervention gains in reading. This project will evaluate the effectiveness of a home delivered technology-based (Edtech) reading intervention in a large and diverse sample of children, and identify factors that facilitate (or hinder) positive Edtech intervention outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Our proposed study called Addressing risk through Community Treatment for Infectious disease and Opioid use disorder Now (ACTION) among justice-involved populations, focuses on the need to improve linkage to HIV prevention and treatment and Opioid Use Disorder services for criminal justice-involved individuals by comparing the effectiveness and implementation of Patient Navigation (PN) and Mobile Health Unit (MHU) intervention models for service delivery in four highly at-risk geographic territories in Connecticut and Texas. Providing the evidence base to support effective implementation approaches that improve linkage to and engagement in integrated community services is critical to preventing new HIV infections among persons who inject drugs and those with opioid use disorders who are being released from prison and jail to the community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Brainstem gliomas are lethal brain tumors that represent the most common cause of brain tumor-related death in children. Radiation therapy can provide temporary relief from neurological symptoms, but despite radiation therapy the tumors eventually progress and lead to death. In this project we will investigate the mechanisms by which brainstem gliomas resist radiation therapy, which will guide the design of new treatment strategies that enhance the efficacy of radiation therapy in order to improve survival for patients with brainstem gliomas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: An incurable subgroup of childhood medulloblastoma are driven by N-myc, an undruggable oncogene. We hypothesize that N-myc hijacks the translational machinery regulated by the mTOR kinase to drive transformation; and that targeting translation control represents a therapeutic strategy for N-myc driven cancers. Our proposal will delineate how N-myc interacts with mTOR to regulate key subsets of translational targets, and elucidates druggable mechanisms in N-myc driven medulloblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Project narrative Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) is an aggressive, clonally heterogeneous, myeloid malignancy and, finding a target antigen that is critical for AML biology and selectively expressed on leukemic cells is one of the foremost challenges in the emerging field of anti-AML immunotherapy. Frequently recurring mutations in genes coding for epigenetic modifiers and components of the spliceosome may generate unconventional target antigens that may arise by means of aberrant transcription, translation or post-translational modifications. Based on a novel pipeline that we called Spliced_immuneTargetFinder, we identified splice variants of cell surface proteins highly expressed in AML and we aim to investigate the relevance of these targets, opening new avenues for AML pathogenesis and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality and although significant progress has been made in clarifying the complex pathophysiology, successful clinical translation of treatments has yet to be achieved. Our research programs have investigated the safety and effectiveness of cell transplantation strategies in people with brain and spinal cord injuries and current studies are now evaluating the use of human Schwann cell-derived exosomes to deliver anti-inflammatory and pro-regenerative mediators to the injured nervous system. We believe this novel treatment approach by targeting both neuroprotective and reparative processes will have a significant impact on the field of neurotrauma and lead to future clinical trials using this innovative therapeutic approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Chronic uncontrollable stress can cause or worsen many debilitating psychiatric disorders such as major depression, which often is characterized by motivational deficits and reduced engagement in activities directed toward the pursuit of goals. Dopamine plays critical roles in voluntary movement, motivation, and reward-based learning, but its precise contribution to self-initiated goal-directed behavior remains poorly understood. The proposed experiments will address this critical gap by examining the circuitry regulating dopamine during such goal-directed behavior and investigating how these circuits are altered by chronic stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE HIV-1 trans-infection is thought to play a key role in the pathogenesis of HIV-1 infection. Direct evidence of HIV- 1 trans-infection in vivo, however, is lacking. In this this application, we propose to use novel state-of the-art approaches to ascertain whether B lymphocyte-mediated cell-to-cell HIV-1 trans-infection contributes to the establishment and replenishment of the latent viral reservoir in resting CD4+ T cells. We anticipate that this study will provide the first in vivo evidence that HIV-1 trans-infection plays a key role in viral pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The development of treatment options for insulin-dependent diabetics with islet cells, which provide physiological regulation of glucose, could result in dramatic improvements in quality of life, as well as a substantial decrease in disease management complications. Herein, we seek to develop a novel encapsulation approach that serves to minimize or eliminate the need for anti-rejection therapy following an islet cell transplant, which should significantly enhance treatment options for insulin-dependent diabetics. We believe these studies are highly relevant to the mission of the National Institutes of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK) and are designed to result in a significant impact on public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The COVID-19 pandemic puts individuals recovering from opioid use disorders (OUDs), an already vulnerable population, at increased risk of overdose due to decreased access to treatment, decreased social support, and increased psychosocial stress. This proposal will test the efficacy of a promising mobile app-based peer support program, compared to usual care, in increasing recovery capital, improving retention in treatment, and reducing psychosocial adverse effects, among a national sample of people in recovery from OUD. If effective, it would provide an accessible, personalized, and scalable approach to OUD recovery increasingly needed during the COVID-19 pandemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Heart failure and cardiac arrhythmias affect millions of Americans. Ca-Calmodulin dependent protein kinase II (CaMKII) has been shown to regulate the function of numerous ion channels and calcium transporters in cardiac myocytes that govern normal excitability and contraction. CaMKII is known to be upregulated and chronically activated in multiple chronic cardiovascular diseases including, and has been implicated in the development of heart failure and arrhythmias. We will elucidate the actual molecular mechanisms that individually cause chronic CaMKII activation, limit CaMKII activation, study how these functionally synergize, and how a novel regulation by S- nitrosylation may be critical to the hearts intrinsic ability to adapt to increased afterload, and how CaMKII may play differential roles in two different models of heart failure with preserved ejection fraction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative DNA methylation is an epigenetic mark crucial for maintaining transcriptional states and aberrant DNA methylation patterns are a hallmark of cancer and other diseases. This research will decipher how DNA methylation patterns are dynamically maintained from the cellular to generational scales, determine the function of DNA demethylation during somatic and reproductive development, and identify the mechanisms underlying imprinted gene expression. The research will lead to new understanding of how these processes are modulated during normal growth and development and how they are potentially altered in disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In salt sensitive (SS) hypertension, an increase in dietary salt intake causes an elevation in blood pressure, which largely happens due to a pathological inability of the kidneys to get rid of the salt. Existing hypertension treatment strategies are often ineffective for salt-sensitive people. This proposal is focused on the renal mechanisms of salt-sensitive hypertension development. Specifically, we will look into mitochondria function and energy metabolism regulated by a crucial hormone (atrial natriuretic peptide), that is known to be decreased in SS individuals. We will seek novel mitochondria-related targets for the treatment of this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: NARRATIVE The transcription factor p53 is a central regulator of genome fidelity through its control of a complex gene regulatory network that restrains cell proliferation after DNA damage. The inability to properly respond to DNA damage severely reduces organismal fitness and leads to a number of deleterious human disorders, such as premature aging, cancer, neuro-developmental diseases, and infertility. Further, multiple therapeutic approaches currently in development, including stem cell reprogramming and genome editing strategies, are strongly inhibited by the p53 pathway, and recent evidence suggests that many “successful” stem cell reprogramming events actually have accidentally inactivated this key checkpoint. Therefore, a vigorous examination of the complex gene networks controlled by p53 is timely and prudent. Ultimately, this work will launch a long-term research program focused on investigation into the molecular mechanisms underlying transcription factor regulation of cell fate decisions and human disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed work will test entirely novel approaches to achieve HIV-1 remission in infants and children affected by the global HIV-1 pandemic. A proven animal model of vertical HIV-1 infection in primates will be used to study a novel combined treatment of drugs, infection-blocking antibodies, and HIV-directed antibodies with the potential to reduce disease severity or clear infection, so that children will not need lifelong treatment. These clinical strategies could be adapted for addressing pediatric HIV-1 infection worldwide.

PHR: This study focuses on delivering a smoking cessation induction intervention during and after dental patients’ teeth cleaning, providing access to smokers who may not otherwise seek treatment for smoking cessation. Because the intervention is video-and text message based, it is appropriate for low literacy and underserved populations, and could easily be disseminated to other dental clinics with minimal provider and patient burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS) is one of the most complex forms of congenital heart disease (CHD), with a reported incidence of 0.2 per 1000 live births, or 3% of children born with CHD. Once a universally fatal diagnosis, dramatic improvements in three staged palliative operations now allow the single right ventricle (RV) to functionally support the total circulation. Despite these strides in medical care, the mortality rate of these infants remains as high as 25 to 35% during the first year of life and continues with a high mortality rate for the rest of their life. High mortality may in part be related to RV performance in these challenging infants. The major objective of the proposed study is to assess for the first time in a single blinded randomized control trial (RCT), whether intramyocardial injection of MSCs is beneficial for HLHS patients. The study is randomized so that during the Stage II operation, half the patients will receive MSC treatment and the other half will receive standard of care. The two groups will receive the same care thereafter and CMR will be used to assess RV performance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Benign breast diseases are common findings on breast biopsy, and certain benign diagnoses are known to be associated with a high risk for development of breast cancer; however, the etiology and risk of cancer associated with other specific benign breast diseases have not been extensively studied or quantified. This study leverages data on over 2.1 million women from 7 diverse Breast Cancer Surveillance Consortium breast imaging registries across the U.S. with up to 25 years of follow-up to identify specific benign breast disease diagnoses and accurately quantify their associations with future breast cancer risk. Our results will provide a better understanding of the relationship between benign breast disease and breast cancer risk among premenopausal and postmenopausal women and by time since diagnosis and may identify subgroups of women most likely to benefit from targeted screening and other prevention efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative By conventional measures, women with estrogen receptor positive invasive lobular breast cancer (ILC) have poor responses to standard treatment approaches. Given the poor outcomes seen in patients with ILC, there is a great need to improve patient selection for standard chemotherapy and identify novel treatment strategies. In this project, I will develop a new clinical prediction tool to identify chemotherapy responders, and conduct a pilot trial testing a novel agent for estrogen receptor positive tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ulcerative colitis continues to increase in children and environmental factors such as diet play a vital role in the management of the disease. Sulfites are potentially harmful compounds that must be detoxified in many cells and tissues, but they are also ubiquitous in our diet as preservatives. To inform future practices on the dietary management of pediatric ulcerative colitis, this study proposes innovative scientific approaches to determine whether sulfites interfere with the normal function of the colon function in health and in UC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: I determined how SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid (N) protein recognizes viral RNA to undergo condensation in an RNA sequence, RNA structure, and temperature dependent manner. I will uncover new modes of condensation function by identifying how RNA-RNA interactions are modulated by condensation as well as identifying which N role(s) in viral replication require condensation. Lastly, I will design and test novel inhibitors of N condensation including synthetic RNA-binding proteins and small molecules with the goal of eventually developing treatments for SARS-CoV-2.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research tests the role of everyday walking experience in the development of adaptability in infant walking skill. Despite abundant research characterizing improvements in walking skill under uniform conditions (bare feet, flat ground), little research tested infants’ ability to adapt their walking patterns to changing conditions (i.e., changes to the body or environment). The proposed project will characterize experience-related changes in the adaptability of walking in typically developing infants and thus has the potential to inform early interventions to improve locomotor function for children with disabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Our basic research is focused on elucidating the connections and functions of aromatase neurons relevant to energy balance control. In addition to the urgent search for novel controls of body weight with the hope of identifying new anti-obesity treatments, the urgency of the current proposal is increased by the fact that pharmaceuticals inhibiting aromatase production are prescribed to many women yearly. They are capable of crossing the blood brain barrier, and their ability to affect behavior and metabolism via action on brain aromatase is poorly understood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute myeloid leukemia is one of the deadliest blood cancers, yet decades-old chemotherapies remain the standard of care for treatment due to its molecularly heterogeneous pathobiology. The epigenetic repression of LINE1 retrotransposons (“jumping genes”) is a newly recognized feature of AML-initiating cells to maintain malignant self-renewal, differentiation blockade, and genomic stability, whereas aberrant LINE1 reactivation impairs AML development. This project aims to elucidate the functional and mechanistic role of retrotransposon- mediated interferon signaling in AML pathogenesis, knowledge of which can inform whether and how the retrotransposon-innate immune crosstalk may be leveraged to selectively eradicate AML-initiating cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to develop and evaluate a digital mental health intervention (DMHI) for adolescents who engage in nonsuicidal self-injury (NSSI) and who are not currently engaged in treatment. I will employ user- centered design methodologies to understand adolescents' specific needs and preferences, which will guide the development of a scalable, low-intensity DMHI designed to be implemented within the digital offerings of a large mental health advocacy website. The DMHI will support the acquisition and practice of skills to reduce NSSI frequency, and encourage use of external supports to increase further help-seeking among high-risk adolescents who are currently unable or uninterested in accessing traditional psychological treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Microglia, the resident immune cells of the brain, are one of the causal cell types of neurodegenerative disease, especially in Alzheimer’s disease (AD). While neuronal dysfunctions prior to cognitive impairment detected in AD patients, it is unclear how microglia affect neuronal function especially selectively vulnerable brain regions of prodromal AD stage. The goal of this project is to understand the mechanisms of AD microglia effect in brain network and determine the efficacy of microglia-targeted pharmacological and cell therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chimeric antigen receptor macrophage (ChARM) therapy offers great promises against solid tumors, but their ex vivo production is complex and technically challenging. The proposed research aims to investigate an innovative strategy of producing ChARMs in vivo using macrophage-targeting exosomes loaded with CAR- encoding mRNA. If successful, the results generated from the proposal will pave the way for a new strategy to produce CAR cells in vivo and greatly expand the utility of cell therapy against solid tumors.
