IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Loss of communication is one of the most disabling and distressing symptoms of neurologic disease and injury and is often cited as a primary factor in the decision to withdraw life-sustaining treatments. For the hundreds of thousands of people worldwide living with ALS, muscular dystrophy, brainstem stroke, and other paralyzing conditions, the existing augmentative and assistive devices that attempt to restore communication by adapting residual volitional motor control (e.g., eye gaze) are often slow, error-prone, and difficult to use, leading to high rates of abandonment. Dr. Rubin’s proposed career development and research plan has the potential to greatly improve the lives of this large patient population by studying the neural basis of speech motor control for the purpose of enabling an intracortical brain computer interface able to restore near-fluent rates of communication by decoding intended speech directly from the associated motor cortical neural activity.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Inappropriate chromosome segregation during meiosis is common in humans and represents the leading cause of miscarriage, birth defects, and infertility. The rate of chromosome segregation errors is strikingly higher in females by comparison to males. This study will use mice from diverse genetic backgrounds to investigate the molecular and genetic factors underlying sex differences that contribute to making female meiosis more error-prone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Public Health Narrative The neuromuscular junction (or NMJ) is the point of contact between a motor neuron and skeletal muscle fiber, it initiates muscle contraction and allows physical movement across the lifespan. Without innervation (due to a loss of this connection), muscle fibers cannot contract, significantly reducing function. My work seeks to understand the similarities that occur at the neuromuscular junction with aging and injury to identify treatment targets to improve function and physical movement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE By 2030, ~70 million people in the USA will be >65 years of age and ~10 million will be >85 years old, and with aging of our population, the incidence of sarcopenia (age-related muscle wasting and weakness) will increase, which is a significant predictor of chronic disease and mortality in the elderly. The diaphragm muscle is the most important inspiratory muscle, and it is also susceptible to sarcopenia, which may limit higher force expulsive airway clearance behaviors such as coughing and sneezing and thereby increase the risk for airway infections in the elderly. The proposed studies will examine the mechanisms underlying age-related loss of phrenic motor neurons and diaphragm muscle sarcopenia and explore the development of novel therapies to mitigate sarcopenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although cigarette smoke exposure is the leading risk factor for the development of chronic obstructive pulmo- nary disease (COPD), how smoke causes progressive lung damage in COPD is poorly understood. Our prelim- inary data suggest that the abnormal accumulation of iron in alveolar macrophages, sentinel immune cells in the lung, may be a critical link between smoke and its downstream detrimental effects. In this proposal, we will develop and confirm this biological connection between iron, alveolar macrophages, and COPD development using a mouse smoke-exposure model and an extensively characterized multicenter COPD cohort, with the goal of building evidence to eventually develop therapy targeting iron in COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The COVID-19 pandemic has created unprecedented disruptions in cancer care, and patients with cancer who have slipped through the system unidentified will present with late-stage disease that is too advanced for curative treatments. While studies have demonstrated deficits in new cancer diagnoses, healthcare leaders and policymakers have no data on the impact of these deficits on cancer outcomes or outcome disparities exacerbated in already vulnerable populations. We propose a comprehensive evaluation of this evolving crisis and a framework for systematic surveillance of changing cancer outcomes and disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Tooth enamel is the most highly mineralized tissue in the human body, formed by the ameloblasts to create a structure consisting of long, thin and intricately interwoven crystals. We will investigate how pH cycling in the enamel matrix directs matrix mineralization and ameloblast function. By understanding these processes, we can, develop strategies to improve resistance to dental caries and enamel fracture, and to synthesize biomaterials with enamel-like structures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dogs are outbred companion animals that develop naturally occurring osteosarcoma in the setting of an intact immune system, allowing for comparative studies evaluating complex genetic interactions and the role of the immune and tumor microenvironment during progression and metastasis. This proposal seeks to build on extensive prior work in canine osteosarcoma biology and clinical trials to better understand the fundamental biology of naturally occurring osteosarcoma in dogs. Importantly, the proposed research will expand the utility of the canine and will identify cellular and molecular signatures to guide the futuredesign of canine osteosarcoma trials to improve translational impact and inform human trials aimed to improve outcomes in human patients with osteosarcoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the introduction of ponatinib, a third-generation tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI), has revolutionized the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) patients with T315I mutation, leading to a significant impact on overall survival and prognosis of patients, cardiotoxicity associated with ponatinib put the cancer survivors at a heightened risk of dying from heart failure instead. Several studies have linked that ponatinib-induced cardiotoxicity to impaired pro-survival signaling pathways leading to cell death, however, the molecular underpinning of these events is currently unknown making it difficult to efficiently counteract treatment-related adversities. Using human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived cardiomyocytes, an inducible cardiac-specific transgenic knockout and overexpression mouse, and CML mouse models, this research proposal aims to delineate novel molecular mechanisms responsible for ponatinib-induced cardiotoxicity and assess whether a small-molecule integrated stress response inhibitor (ISRIB) can mitigate undesirable outcomes of ISR activation on the heart without compromising the efficacy of ponatinib to limit cancer burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The neuronal aggregation of alpha-synuclein is deeply connected to Parkinson’s Disease and Alzheimer’s Disease Related Dementias. We recently uncovered an entirely new mechanism of alpha-synuclein toxicity in neurons, through modulation of mRNA. We will now systematically assess how important this is across a range of neuronal models and postmortem brain samples, examine why certain mRNAs are more perturbed in synucleinopathy, and determine key enzymes in the pathway that may be prospective therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: DETAILED DESCRIPTION Migraine is a common, painful and disabling disorder; depressive symptoms are often comorbid with in people with migraine and increase suffering. The goal of this project is to evaluate the fidelity, feasibility, and acceptability of remote-delivered (telephone and video) mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) for migraine disability and depressive symptoms. We will use pre-specified decision rules to determine study design for a future phase III clinical trial of remote-delivered MBCT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cerebrospinal fluid flow plays an essential role in brain’s waste clearance system, and disrupted CSF flow is implicated in Alzheimer's disease. The goal of this project is to obtain previously unavailable knowledge on brain- wide CSF flow dynamics and pathways in the human brain using novel MR imaging technologies, and investigate the alteration of CSF flow in aging and in Alzheimer's disease, particularly its correlation with neuropathological protein depositions in AD patients, laying the foundation for future studies to discover CSF-flow-based imaging biomarkers and therapeutic interventions for Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Public Narrative No model organism has contributed more than the laboratory mouse to improving human health. This project will develop computational tools that will greatly accelerate the pace of genetic discovery using the many available murine genetic models for human disease. Also, the mechanism by which computationally identified murine genetic factors that cause two diseases (lymphoma and diabetes) that are major public health problems will be characterized.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite the dramatic health inequities faced by sexual and gender minority (SGM) individuals, there are a dearth of training opportunities in general, and especially in the Deep South. Over 4 years, we will develop and implement a one-year training program for graduate students pursuing careers in health research, GenderS (Education on Gender and Sex), to synthesize SGM health content, develop concrete advocacy skills, and facilitate transparent dialogues regarding the systems and structures that limit SGM experience in the Deep South. Led by a unique community-academic partnership, and refined by rigorous evaluation and strategically disseminated to have national reach, the GenderS program will demonstrate to future investigators in health research how leaders from diverse backgrounds can work together to improve SGM health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: This project develops advanced computational analysis methods for magnetic resonance imaging of brain networks. It uses novel tractometry techniques and high-performance computing methods to create new tools that will be useful for studying the structure of the brain’s white matter, both in healthy and diseased populations. In addition, this project seeks to validate these methods and tools in existing publicly available human and non-human primate data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative In the United States, nearly half of all HIV infected individuals show neurocognitive defects despite effective anti- retroviral treatment suggesting potential widespread HIV infections that impact the CNS. We will test whether silent HIV infections in the brain become reactivated in response to inflammation and how they are regulated by a specific class of nuclear receptors using model systems derived from induced pluripotent stem cells and humanized mice. The availability of numerous clinically-effective brain-penetrant drugs targeting key microglial cell nuclear receptors will allow us to identify drug candidates with high therapeutic potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative  Flow cytometry is a powerful analysis platform that is capable of measuring dozens of characteristics of single cells within complex populations of cells. In this grant, we propose to further develop a technology that can greatly increase the number of proteins that can be measured by flow cytometry, focusing on developing markers for T cells, which play an essential role in the immune system's response to pathogens, in diseases such as autoimmunity, and more recently in the fight against cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: In the life cycle of the human oncogenic virus Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus, the expression of key viral lates genes is dependent on replication of the viral genome. Here, we propose to use a variety of functional genomics methods to discover the viral proteins, viral DNA regulatory regions, and functional host interactors that maintain this dependency. Together, these will allow us to develop and test new models for this key therapeutic target in this human oncovirus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Skeletal muscle is the largest insulin-sensitive tissue and a major regulator of metabolic homeostasis in the human body. Human variants in the cytoskeletal protein ankyrin-B, highly expressed in skeletal muscle, lead to ankyrin-B deficiency and metabolic disease. This project will determine how ankyrin-B deficiency in skeletal muscle leads to altered skeletal muscle energetic and metabolic capacity via its association with mitochondria. These studies are essential to understand mitochondrial physiology and the development of skeletal muscle and metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Exercise is a powerful stimulus for attenuating age-associated tissue decline, but the molecular mechanisms behind this are incompletely understood. Using muscle functional, bioenergetic, and cellular measures as well as nucleus-specific DNA methylation aging analysis and single myonuclear RNA-sequencing, the purpose of this proposal is to provide fundamental information on what mediates skeletal muscle molecular reprogramming toward youthfulness. Combined with a conditional and inducible muscle-specific gene expression model and a new murine exercise training approach, we hypothesize that the exercise-responsive Yamanaka factor MYC plays a central role in promoting a youthful tissue profile during aging and can be leveraged to improve muscle health throughout the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Activated vitamin D use in kidney failure is ubiquitous, costly, and almost certainly has important effects on outcomes. Yet, the high vitamin D doses encouraged by the current treatment paradigm pose substantial potential risks and optimal dosing strategies have not been adequately assessed. Advancing this field has the potential to improve safety, cardiovascular outcomes, and treatment costs for the millions of patients worldwide with kidney failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Cancers are characterized by deletions of chromosomal regions some of which can inactivate cell cycle regulators while the role of others is not known. This proposal investigates the role of PRMT5, a gene central to cellular proliferation and carcinogenesis, in suppressing chromosomal deletions in human cells. Successful completion of the proposed experiments will delineate new mechanisms of cellular transformation and carcinogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Transplantation is the only treatment for patients suffering from end-stage organ failure and early injuries in the donor organ are attributed to long-term failure. New therapeutic strategies are needed to mitigate early injuries and improve organ transplantation outcomes. The endothelium in the donor organ is central to early injuries and therefore, we seek to investigate the role of protecting the endothelial barrier in mitigating early insults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Hypothalamic obesity is a treatment-resistant form of obesity that affects survivors of hypothalamic brain tumors. In this pilot clinical trial, we will collect important safety and efficacy data and thereby lay the groundwork for a larger innovative sequential multiple assignment randomized trial (SMART) in the future. The overall goal is to understand individual responses to obesity interventions, and to personalize therapeutic interventions based on the individual initial responses utilizing different drugs with demonstrated safety and potential efficacy in HO.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: We address the unmet challenge in mechanistically understanding how human variation contributes to genetic disease through rigorous experimental and computational approaches. We will apply variation spatial profiling (VSP) and variation capture (VarC), approaches that use Gaussian process (GP) machine learning to define quantitatively spatial co-variance (SCV) relationships that rigorously link on a residue-residue basis the genotype to its basic function(s) and clinical phenotype(s) at atomic resolution. We will mechanistically dissect the role of proteostasis components, the cellular protein folding machinery, in the management of naturally occurring genetic variation for presentation to the COPII components Sar1, Sec12, Sec16, Sec23/24, Sec13/31 to understand the integrated events triggering for human pathophysiology, setting the stage for a quantitative global platform for describing clinical disease and its management based on the common biological principle of SCV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative A core symptom among the post-acute sequelae of COVID-19 (PASC) is 'brain fog,' which involves a disruption of cognitive control executive functioning. With dual MRI-PET (magnetic resonance imaging - positron emission tomography) neuroimaging, we will use multiple complimentary techniques to probe the function of the anterior midcingulate cortex (aMCC) in PASC during a cognitive control task. Functional MRI will detect the aCC voxel with peak blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) response while simultaneous [11C]PBR28 scanning will measure microglial activation within that voxel and subsequent magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) will measure metabolite concentrations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pediatric high-grade glioma (PHGG), a deadly childhood brain tumor, likely originates from tumor stem  cells that differentiate into proliferating tumor cells. PHGG tumors are heterogeneous and include several  different types of proliferating cells, leading to the question of how tumor stem cells and proliferating tumor  cells relate to one another. I will investigate whether a single multipotent tumor stem cell population  produces the multiple proliferating cell types of PHGG, to provide a biological foundation for the  development of critically needed advances in therapeutic alternatives for this deadly childhood disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric cancer survivors (PCS) experience an excess risk of numerous adverse outcomes related to their cancer diagnosis and treatment, which impact social functioning, quality of life, and health care resource utilization. Latinos, in particular, are more likely to experience these adverse outcomes and have reduced access to routine medical care, contributing to higher morbidity and mortality among Latino children diagnosed with cancer. Existing and well-established cohorts of PCS exclusively include long-term survivors with a relatively small proportion of Latino PCS; therefore, the data that inform our understanding of risk for treatment-related late effects, our clinical practice guidelines to address them, and the uptake of survivorship care in this vulnerable and growing population are deficient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure (HF) remains a leading cause of cardiovascular mortality and morbidity that results in a poor quality of life and reduced lifespan. Renal denervation (RDN) is a powerful, device-based treatment for patients with severe hypertension for whom drug therapies have failed. We will investigate the beneficial effects of RDN in a clinically relevant animal model of HF and the results of these studies will guide the development of novel HF treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE X-linked myotubular myopathy (XLMTM) is a rare neurogenetic disorder associated with severe clinical symptoms and early death that is currently without treatment. Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) is a prevalent liver condition that does not have adequate therapy and that can progress to liver failure, cancer, and death. Inhibition of the enzyme PIK3C2B may surprisingly be a therapeutic strategy for both XLMTM and NASH, and the goal of this proposal is to develop and test an miRNA-based PIK3C2B knockdown therapeutic as a treatment for both of these conditions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will develop and validate a computable phenotype algorithm for classifying pediatric sleep deficiency. Furthermore, postprocessing bias mitigation methods will be applied to build and test an equitable computable phenotype model across subpopulations defined by age, gender, race/ethnicity, and socioeconomic status. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Food allergy is rapidly increasing in prevalence affecting up to 6 million American children at an economic cost of ~$25 billion per year. Currently there is an FDA-approved treatment for peanut allergy, however there are no approved treatments for other food allergies (shellfish, milk, tree nuts, egg, wheat, soy and sesame) which affect ~23.2 million Americans. Successful completion of the proposed studies will identify key cellular and molecular processes in the passage of dietary antigens to the gastrointestinal compartment and the priming for clinical reactivity to foods, thereby directing development of new and pre-existing therapeutics for treating all food allergies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic immune-mediated disease that impacts over 3 million Americans, represents a major socio-economic health challenge, and currently has limited preventative, therapeutic or curative treatment strategies. Basic, translational, and clinical studies defined a key role for the pro-inflammatory factor, tumor necrosis factor (TNF), in driving cell death in the intestinal epithelium and orchestrating chronic inflammation. The focus of this proposal is to delineate a novel pathway that is essential to protect the intestinal epithelium from TNF and determine the relevance of this pathway to IBD.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative There is a paucity of data to inform safe and effective prescribing practices in children. Real-world evidence (RWE) studies using data from routine clinical practice have the potential to generate high-quality evidence that could guide prescribing when randomized controlled trials do not but are underdeveloped in pediatrics. This study aims to develop a rigorous framework for RWE studies such that they can reliably address key evidence gaps of medication safety and effectiveness in pediatrics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Inflammation is a pervasive driver of disease progression and a crucial mediator of tissue healing processes. This proposal will develop biomaterials that improve our understanding of interactions between different immune system components and recapitulate the progression of signaling mechanisms that underlie normal tissue healing. The work will have broad implications for the development of drug delivery systems and synergistic therapies to treat disease and promote tissue healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE Alcohol-related liver disease (ALD), from chronic cirrhosis to acute alcoholic hepatitis, is now the leading indication for liver transplantation in the United States. However, there is no consensus on the optimal transplant candidate selection criteria, and center-specific practices remain the norm. This project will 1) study the impacts of liver transplant and sobriety on survival in alcoholic hepatitis and 2) identify the ideal predictors of post-transplant outcomes in ALD. The study findings will help establish standardized and transparent liver transplant candidate selection in ALD across the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oral thrush continues to be a clinically significant problem for patients with weak immune systems. The proposed studies have the potential to lead to a paradigm shift in how clinicians and scientists view the microbiome changes characterizing this infection. This project will identify certain oral bacteria as new, clinically relevant mediators of invasive disease thus providing justification for the combined use of antifungal and anti-bacterial treatments in high risk patients, such as patients undergoing intensive cancer chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The nucleus accumbens is a region of the brain involved in maintaining social attachments to partners, the loss of which are detrimental to mental health. Here, I seek to investigate the role of an understudied, but powerful cell type in the nucleus accumbens – the inhibitory interneuron – in the development of social attachments. This proposal will expand our fundamental understanding of how the brain forms and maintains social attachments, thus paving the way for possible therapies for deficits in social bonding.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will advance mechanistic understanding of exercise adaptation in skeletal muscle of a relevant AD mouse model and the roles of a key regulator of cellular energetics in AD etiology, a pathology for which there are few treatment options. The project is relevant to NIA’s mission because it focuses on the molecular and physiological response of skeletal muscle mitochondria in the context of AD neuropathology that indicates a maladaptive bioenergetic response to exercise, which may elucidate an integrated mechanism that will take into account the system-dependent nuance of bioenergetic dysregulation in AD etiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hyperexcitable cortical pyramidal neurons (CPNs) in motor cortex, specifically the supplementary motor cortex (M2) may cause relapse, the most challenging stage in the clinical treatment of substance use disorder. We will try to attenuate the hyperexcitability of M2 CPNs in the M2 area, and to depress the axonal terminal transmission of the CPNs to the dorsolateral striatum. Our hope is to identify novel molecular, neuronal and circuitry targets to prevent relapse to drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Bipolar Disorder (BD) is often misdiagnosed as Major Depressive Disorder (MDD). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The Gordon Research Conference and the Gordon Research Seminar on Chemotactic Cytokines will bring together scientists from all over the world from an unusually diverse array of scientific disciplines and experimental approaches to discuss the functions of chemokines in health and disease ranging from inflammatory diseases to cancer, neurological disorders and autoimmunity. It will pave the way for the identification of new therapeutic targets for drug development by fostering the exchange of information between basic scientists, clinicians and researchers from the biomed industry. The meeting will promote direct informal exchange of ideas coming from different scientific disciplines, countries, as well as ethnic, experience and gender groups, and facilitate the training of the next generation scientists in this exciting multidisciplinary research field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH SIGNIFICANCE This 5-year multilevel longitudinal study investigates informal caregivers' (unpaid family members and friends) involvement in end-of-life care of residents with advanced dementia in 45 diverse assisted living communities in Georgia. Our goal is to improve understanding of the relationships between and among informal caregiver involvement, informal caregiver health, and quality of life of assisted living residents with advanced dementia at end of life and ultimately identify potentially modifiable factors at the individual, assisted living, and wider community-level associated with adverse outcomes. This study, which is the first to focus on these relationships in depth or over time, will offer valuable insights to researchers, policymakers, and providers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This research study will investigate the mechanisms by which microglia dysfunction due to age and inheritance of genetic risk factors contribute to Alzheimer Disease, a devastating neurodegenerative condition that impairs memory and causes cognitive and psychiatric deficits. Because microglia play important roles in maintaining brain homeostasis and health, therapies aimed at restoring or enhancing their normal function may effectively mitigate disease course. This proposal aims to validate the role of the AD protective CD33 allele and elucidate the mechanism by which it regulates microglia homeostasis and can be targeted as novel AD therapeutic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodegenerative diseases, like Alzheimer's, have massive accumulation of proteins such as tau, which is linked to the failure of the cellular recycling system known as autophagy. A unique protein called BOK connects an intricate signaling network between autophagy and cellular survival. This project will elucidate the metabolic pathways regulated by BOK in order to reveal potential mechanisms by which to prevent tau-mediated death of neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Ageing and cerebrovascular disorders are known to lead to white matter abnormalities and cognitive impairment. The studies described in this proposal are designed to gain a better understanding of the molecular and cellular pathogenesis that underlies the dementia that develops in these individuals. Our working hypothesis is that strategies that increase oligodendrocyte protection against the cytotoxic CNS environment that develops in response to ageing and cerebrovascular maladies will help ameliorate the white matter and cognitive abnormalities that develop.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD), the most common neurodegenerative disorder, afflicts millions of individuals worldwide. Unless highly effective disease modifying therapies are identified, the AD epidemic will continue to exact an ever-expanding and profound personal, societal and economic toll. We are exploring a large number of biologically active proteins that co- accumulate with amyloid in the disease, these may play biological roles and could be future targets for therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Engaging in lifestyle physical activity is a promising preventive strategy for sustaining cognition and thus reducing the risks of developing neuropsychological diseases in older adults. Current literature has predominately focused on the total volume of physical activity performed but has not yet established the time- sensitive association between daily lifestyle physical activity distribution and everyday cognition. This study bridges the literature gap by leveraging accelerometers and app-based cognitive measures to identify whether activity distribution represents a meaningful behavioral target that can be engaged in everyday life to sustain brain health among vulnerable older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep-based metrics are promising as potential noninvasive biomarkers for the early identification of individuals at risk of Alzheimer’s disease. In this R01 Research Project Grant, we will collect and analyze sleep and activity data from three wearable devices for sleep, heart rate, and activity monitoring along with blood biomarkers for Alzheimer’s disease from elderly Mass General Brigham Biobank participants with elevated genetic susceptibility to Alzheimer’s disease. We will also develop artificial intelligence tools for digital phenotyping and the discovery of novel sleep- and activity-related predictors of Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Multiple sclerosis (MS) remains an insidious disease, with unpredictable outcomes. Though the typical form of the disease, in which there are relapses and remissions, is responsive to many new medications, ultimately nearly seventy percent of patients go onto a secondary progressive phase for which there is currently no effective treatment. This application details experiments to understand the make-up and function of particular structures that appear in the brain and spinal cord uniquely during this progressive phase – meningeal ectopic lymphoid tissues (mELTs) – potentially highlighting new therapeutic treatments for progressive MS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to develop a new gene editing platform for understanding how natural human genetic variation can influence disease progression and drug efficacy. As proof-of-principle, this platform will be first be used to systematically characterize how variants of the HIV-1 co-receptor CCR5 can influence receptor expression, HIV infection, and antiretroviral drug activity. Ultimately, this work seeks to provide new technologies and paradigms for efficiently and rapidly exploring the influence of human genetic variation on disease outcomes and treatment efficacy to enhance the speed of future therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: The causal role of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk variants in neuronal or glial cells is unresolved.  By combining genetic fine-mapping, CRISPR-genetic engineering, and human induced pluripotent   stem cell models, we propose to test the molecular and functional impact of perturbing the  genotype of AD risk alleles. We hope to find insights into the mechanism of disease initiation and  progression in AD, in order to one day reverse the disrupted molecular pathways that contribute to this debilitating disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the most common neurodegenerative disease that causes dementia. Neuroinflammation, mediated by microglia, is a key disease mechanism of AD that needs to be better understood at the molecular level although existing methodological barriers limit our ability to characterize protein changes occurring in microglia in AD. In this proposal, we will use a novel cell type-specific in-vivo proteomic labeling approach called ciBONCAT to investigate the proteomic characteristics of microglia-mediated disease mechanisms in the brain and cerebrospinal fluid using mouse models of AD pathology, which may ultimately lead to identifying novel treatment targets and biomarkers for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative There is no treatment to correct the reduced brain blood flow observed in Alzheimer disease patients, although this reduction likely contributes to cognitive deficits and may accelerate disease progression. We recently found that blood flow in individual brain capillaries is stalled by arrested white blood cells in mouse models of Alzheimer’s disease, and we now propose to investigate the molecular and cellular mechanisms causing these capillary stalls and to determine the impact of increasing brain blood flow by interfering with capillary stalling on the progression of disease. These capillary stalls are a potential mechanism for the decreased blood flow in AD, and this work could lead to novel therapies that improve cognitive function and slow Alzheimer’s disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE Although many patients have benefited from existing medications for alcohol use disorder (AUD), their effects are moderate or not effective in some individuals. Future efforts in the development of medications for AUD need to include: establishing new targets for drug development; using validated animal models to test medications for AUD; and developing biomarkers to help predict drug response. In addition, if possible, it is important to utilize medications that are familiar within the clinical practitioner community which will facilitate the inclusion of these medications into the alcohol treatment process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Millions of years ago, retroviruses infected ancient human ancestors and became a normal part of our genome as Human Endogenous Retroviruses (HERVs). Although HERVs are generally suppressed in normal cells, HML-2 is a special HERV species transiently activated in normal embryonic cells that are destined to produce gametes as well as various adult-onset cancers, possibly contributing to formation of malignant cells. Taking advantage of the latest advancement in modeling human embryos in cell cultures using cells not derived from real human embryos, this project attempts to test the hypothesis that exposure of human embryos to environmental toxic chemicals may cause incomplete suppression of HML-2 after their transient activation in the gamete-producing cells and consequently increase the cancer risk in the next generation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Increasing evidence links a range of disorders, from congenital malformations to autism, intellectual disability, and brain tumors, to mutations that cause genes to be erroneously activated. Called gain-of-function mutations, such alterations often affect regions of our genomes called enhancers—“switches” for gene activity. The proposed research will use limb development as a model to determine the molecular mechanism by which these gain-of-function enhancer mutations promote limb congenital malformations utilizing novel genetically engineered mice and cutting-edge genomics and imaging methods. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is a devastating disease affecting over 6 million people in the U.S. and has burdened the U.S. healthcare system and caregivers with increases. It is hypothesized that biomarker deterioration starts many years before cognitive decline due to AD, and identifying high-risk subgroups based on biomarker information will expand the window of opportunity during which therapeutic intervention may have the greatest potential for success. This proposal will seek to develop novel statistical methods and new algorithms for subgroup identification and risk prediction for cognitive decline due to AD, through efforts to (1) establish a time-dynamic and personalized statistical classification and prediction framework using tree-based methods; and (2) leverage the Preclinical AD Consortium data to construct classification and prediction algorithms for onset of AD-related clinical symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Declines in attention and memory are a hallmark feature of Alzheimer’s disease, but some degree of cognitive decline is also evident in healthy older adults. This project will assess whether brain connectivity assessed by high-resolution relative to standard resolution diffusion-weighted imaging is more sensitive to both normal age- related cognitive decline and Alzheimer’s disease. Ultimately, results may assist with the early identification of adults who are at heightened risk for atypical cognitive decline and will set the stage for studies that may wish to use this clinically feasible high-resolution magnetic resonance imaging protocol in future aging research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will address the clinical failure of synthetic small diameter vascular grafts due to the ingrowth of vascular smooth muscle cells. We are directly altering the vascular smooth muscle cells through non- viral gene delivery of microRNA 145, which is a known regulator of smooth muscle cells. The knowledge gained in this work will improve the treatment of cardiovascular disease in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Public Health Relevance We propose to develop a biotherapeutic nanogel for Alzheimer’s disease treatment, with unique features of inherent autofluorescence, anti-viral, and anti-inflammatory properties. The proposed research will provide new avenues for the bioengineering of novel therapeutics for AD/ADRD research. The goal is to provide a safe and non-toxic treatment to reduce the oxidative stress and neuroinflammation associated with AD, which will advance the clinical application reducing the side effects and enhancing the treatment efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myelin, the insulating structure around neuronal axons that makes up ~30% of our brain (consisting of 75% lipids/25% proteins) and is crucial for forming and preserving memories, is degenerated and possibly plays an important role in Alzheimer’s disease (AD), but its extent of degeneration and its interactions with known disease pathologies have not been quantified. We propose to use our novel synchrotron imaging to produce 3D myelin maps and quantify myelin degeneration in subregions of the hippocampus, the brain’s central memory-processing area, to see how myelin interacts with other abnormal processes in AD, including protein accumulation and inflammation. Complementing that with molecular analyses, we aim to fill a knowledge gap about myelin’s spatial degeneration, relationship with important pathology markers in the AD brain, and known lipid and protein dysregulation in AD, paving the way to a detailed understanding of the involvement of this important component of the brain in the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pneumonia is the most common cause of death due to infection worldwide and in patients admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU); it is not clear why some patients improve quickly while others do not, despite receiving appropriate therapy. Machine learning offers great opportunity to reveal important early features of response to treatment and predict which patients will be subsequently cured or not. This proposal will use state-of-the-art machine learning using clinical features and local lung host response transcriptomics to predict pneumonia cure, thereby providing opportunities for earlier diagnostic and treatment interventions to promote cure in critically ill patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to investigate the significance of different human CD8+ T cell subsets, including those expressing different levels of IL-7 receptor alpha, in health and disease such as Alzheimer’s disease using peripheral blood immune cells, brain cortical organoids and tissue. The results of the proposed study would advance our understanding of how aging alters CD8+ T cells, contributing to the development and progress of age-associated diseases like Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Every year, millions of older adults undergoing surgery suffer from sleep disturbances, including insomnia, linked with poorer surgical recovery, such as postoperative delirium, cognitive decline, and potentially Alzheimer’s disease (AD). This proposal is relevant to public health because it will test whether cognitive-based therapy for insomnia (CBT-I), an existing evidence-based therapy for insomnia and sleep disturbances newly tailored to the surgical patient, is feasible before planned orthopedic surgery and whether it improves sleep and brain health outcomes in those with moderate to severe insomnia. This unique pilot clinical trial will provide novel groundwork for future sleep interventions that may improve brain health outcomes after surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Perilipin-2 (Plin2), a surface component of organelles known as lipid droplets, has been shown to accumulate in specific cells within the brains of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) patients and those with APOE4, a gene variant that increases risk of AD. Increased amounts of Plin2 indicates lipid accumulation and dysregulated metabolism. This project aims to determine the effects of lowering Plin2 in the specific brain cells on AD pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Infection with human papillomaviruses (HPV) has been associated with cancers of the cervix, head and neck and the anogenital organs, and these cancers account for at least 5% of all cancers worldwide. In this study, we will develop a new way to stratify these cancers so that we can discover the underlying processes that distinguish the patients who will respond to certain treatments and have good prognosis, from patients whose tumors will not respond and instead progress rapidly. We expect our contribution to be significant because it will tremendously improve our understanding of how to better prevent, diagnose and treat cervical cancer and other HPV-associated cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Degenerative disorders of Temporomandibular Joint (TMJ) are painful and debilitating diseases, affecting over 20 million people in United States. The prevalence of obesity and growth of older population has risen dramatically over the past two decades and it has been observed that obesity accelerates aging. Our application proposes to understand the role of p21–highly-expressed (p21high) cells in TMJ degeneration and underlying mechanism by which p21high cells modulate TMJ degeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement (Narrative) Hypertension is a leading cause of stroke, age related vascular dementia and end-stage renal disease, which places a heavy burden on our economy and contributes to health disparities. Pressure-induced constriction of renal vessels is one mechanism that protects the delicate microvasculature of the kidney from injury associated with increases in systemic blood pressure; however, the mechanism(s) underlying initiation of the response is unknown. This proposal will determine the importance of members of the ENaC/Degenerin family of ions channels and TrpC6 channels in the initiation of pressure-induced constriction, and the role of these channels in protecting the kidney from hypertension related injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Melanin-concentrating hormone (MCH) is a peptide produced in the brain that stimulates eating, and there is interest in developing obesity pharmacotherapies that block this system. However, despite its known role in increasing food intake and body weight, very little is understood about the biological mechanisms through which MCH influences energy balance. This proposal will unravel the specific physiological and neural mechanisms through which MCH influences food intake regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clinical solid organ transplantation requires life-long immunosuppression to prevent allograft rejection. Current immunosuppressive strategies rely primarily on broad pharmacologic inhibition of lymphocyte function, which is incompletely effective at preventing rejection while increasing the risk for infection and tumors. Thus, new approaches for specific and durable allograft-specific immunosuppression are critically needed. We propose to utilize a pMHCII-based allogeneic 5-module chimeric antigen receptor-cytotoxic T cell (5MCAR-CTL) system to target and eliminate alloreactive T cells. Successful completion of the proposed experiments will generate tools and data to support refinement and development of this clinically-translatable cell engineering approach.

PHR: This renewal would continue the tradition of innovative training for top-notch neuroscientists at Washington University. The proposed Neuroscience Pipeline will prepare underrepresented students for graduate-level studies through advanced educational and research experiences, intensive advising and dedicated community outreach. These efforts, combined with our mentor training and evaluation plans, should be scalable and findings translatable to those who share our goals of changing the local culture of mentoring future scientists and increasing diversity in the neurosciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative. Communication between the lymph node and the organs it drains is imperative for predicting immune responses to vaccination, infection, and chronic disease, but have been difficult to study in vivo or in vitro. To address this gap, we will develop a user friendly, microscale system specifically co-culture intact samples of live tissue from the lymph node with other organs and allow recirculating of white blood cells between them as occurs in vivo. After determining the effects of various modes of fluid motion on intact lymph node tissue for the first time, we will generate a simple model the response of the lymph node to vaccination, as a proof-of-principle of this new system for modeling multi-tissue immunity outside the body.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Methamphetamine use disorder – MUD – is a serious problem in the US and worldwide; treatment options and understanding of its underlying biology are severely limited. Large-scale genomewide studies are a proven method to increase knowledge of a disorder's biology, and accordingly, we propose collection of 10,000 subjects in Thailand ascertained for MUD and other substance use and psychiatric traits, to conduct a whole- genome sequencing analysis; these will be meta-analyzed with other MUD samples. Results from this study have the potential to advance greatly our understanding of genetic risk factors for MUD, and therefore of MUD biology, especially in understudied East Asian populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Most cells in adult animals are in a non-cycling, quiescent state often referred to as G0. Some cells enter reversible states of G0 while others enter more robust and permanent states of G0, but the differences between reversible G0 and permanent G0 are poorly understood. This work investigates the molecular mechanisms that control different states of G0 across tissues, with an ultimate goal of generating tools to manipulate and control G0, which becomes improperly regulated in both cancer and aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Molecular communication across cell types is central to life—communication between cell types in a human organ is critical to normal function, and microbe-host or microbe-microbe communication drives microbial ecosystems. This proposal will study signaling between human immune cells and fibroblasts and signaling between microbes relevant for human health (e.g., commensal and pathogenic bacteria and fungi). We will develop a suite of microfluidic tools to broaden the scope of mechanistic questions that can be addressed, ultimately enabling the development of therapies to target dysfunctional signaling and inflammation in human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative  Maternal high-fat feeding during pregnancy and lactation predisposes the offspring to higher risk of developing non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). This project investigates the interacting effect of prenatal and postnatal choline supplementation with dietary fat on preventing the prenatal programming of NASH. This study will provide proof-of-concept evidence for a cost-effective and noninvasive prophylaxis for NASH, dissociating the maternal obesogenic environment with adverse health consequences in the offspring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: ZFIN analyzes and curates zebrafish research data, provides support for zebrafish models of human disease, integrates links to data from other databases, and maintains and updates the zebrafish reference genome. The long term goals for ZFIN are a) to be the community database resource for the laboratory use of zebrafish, b) to develop and support integrated zebrafish genetic, genomic, developmental, and physiological information, c) to maintain the definitive reference data sets of zebrafish research information, d) to link this information extensively to corresponding data in other model organism and human databases, e) to facilitate the use of zebrafish as a model for human biology, and f) to help serve the broad needs of the biomedical research community.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer is the second most commonly diagnosed cancer in the United States, and it is the leading cause of cancer-related deaths among both men and women. A screening test known as low-dose computed tomography can detect lung cancer early and reduce lung cancer deaths among patients with a history of heavy smoking, but this test requires patients and their physicians to carefully consider potential benefits and harms that differ according to each patient’s individual risk profile, and less than 5% of eligible patients receive the screening every year. This project will address this urgent need by widely sharing patient-centered tools that analyze patients’ electronic health records and enable patients and their physicians to review individually- tailored information on the potential benefits and harms of lung cancer screening, so that patients and their physicians can make informed, patient-centered decisions regarding this potentially life-saving test.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Engaging patients to enable interoperable lung cancer decision support at scale

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Compelling observational data indicate the benefit of coffee for improved survivorship of colorectal cancer. Coffee contains hundreds of bioactive compounds that are degraded and modified by the gut microbiota and endogenous enzymes to generate new metabolites that can reduce inflammation, modulate metabolism, improve fatty liver and liver fibrosis, and inhibit tumor growth and invasion, thereby reducing cancer recurrence and liver metastasis. Understanding the mechanistic effect of coffee on colorectal cancer survival through modulation of the gut microbiome and liver function will illuminate significant insights into the role of natural products in metabolic regulation and cancer progression and launch novel research into cancer prevention through diet- and gut microbiota-targeted therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE How layers of cells communicate with each other across hollow voids remains poorly understood, but is relevant to a wide variety of biological phenomena. To illuminate this 'fourth dimension' of tissue biology, we will generate a new type of microscope that allows us to bring sheets of cells closer together or farther apart and measure the strength of their physical connections. We will apply this new technology to determine the role of static electricity when cell sheets are brought into close range interactions, and the role of antenna-like projections called cilia in longer range interactions, as major examples of this nascent field.

PHR: In this study, we will adapt and implement a digital mental health intervention within the care coordination service of a large healthcare system. Data gathered throughout this project will be used to develop an implementation guide, capable of being used by other for healthcare systems as they expand their mental health service offerings to provide holistic support for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Current Cardiac MRI (CMR) is limited in many aspects, which prevent CMR from achieving its full potential. The current proposal builds on our recent success in developing a new paradigm of CMR for pediatric congenital heart disease, which has changed how CMR is practiced in pediatric congenital heart disease. We propose accelerated imaging techniques and patient surgical outcome prediction tools to boost the value of CMR in managing children with congenital heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this grant is to use and develop single-molecule technologies along with biochemical methods to examine the molecular mechanisms by which DNA mismatch repair proteins promote mutation avoidance, thereby reducing cancer risk, while also promoting trinucleotide repeat expansion, which causes several neurodegenerative diseases such as Huntington's. This research will both provide needed tools to the research community and further our understanding of the molecular mechanisms that underlie mismatch repair and trinucleotide-repeat expansion, which will be important for designing treatments for cancers and trinucleotide- repeat neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Despite an increase in telehealth for outpatient palliative care since the beginning of the COVID- 19 pandemic, little is known about the perspectives on modality of outpatient palliative care among historically underserved patients and how communication may be impacted by a virtual mode of delivery for these patients who already experience inequities in receipt of goal- concordant care. This prospective cohort study uses a mixed-methods approach to examine and compare care experiences for in-person versus tele-palliative care provided to historically underserved patients and their caregivers and to evaluate palliative care provider perspectives on the perceived effectiveness of tele-palliative care for this population. Findings will provide a roadmap for health systems to improve patient-provider communication and identify strategies to promote cultural competence to improve experience and overall quality of palliative care delivered both in person and via telehealth to seriously ill patients and their family caregivers who have been historically marginalized in health care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prostate needle biopsies, often carried out under multiparametric MRI guidance, provide essential histopathological and gene transcript data for risk assessment. Major goals of the proposal are to improve needle biopsy targeting for procurement of tissue representative of highest grade group and expression of prostate transcripts of aggressiveness (PTAs), and to define and minimize effects from preanalytical tissue processing variables for analysis of PTAs. These steps will reduce the uncertainty in risk assessment and selection of men for active surveillance, single modality treatment, and multi-modality treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Throughout the animal kingdom, social species establish social hierarchies and use social rank to guide the appropriate expression of dominance behaviors that are critical for survival. Our proposed mouse model research will characterize how orbitofrontal cortex neurons process social ranking information and evaluate how their interactions with serotonergic systems influence the expression of social dominance behaviors. Developing a better understanding of the neuronal mechanisms governing the appropriate expression of social behaviors will provide great value to clinicians and translational researchers wanting to treat impairments in control of social behaviors that are found in psychiatric disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This study proposes to collect friendship data from two cohorts of students attending 14 schools in southern California. The friendship nominations will be used to determine if adolescents are influenced by their friends to initiate or continue e-cigarette and marijuana use. The longitudinal data will also be used to determine if adolescents make changes in their networks to be consistent with substance use behaviors and to determine if substance use patterns (trajectories) are associated with network changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative An estimated 50% of women will experience Lower urinary tract symptoms – a source of illness, pain, and embarrassment, which can affect work, social interactions, and athletic and recreational activities from adolescence through old age. Through its transdisciplinary team science approach, the Prevention of Lower Urinary tract Symptoms Research Consortium has created new conceptual models and paradigms, developed innovative measures, established evidence, and lead and seeded research on bladder health and LUTS prevention. The objective of this program is to carry out epidemiologic studies, including the launch of a longitudinal cohort study, to identify risk and protective factors that can support prevention of lower urinary tract symptoms in girls and women across the lifecourse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ribosomal RNA (rRNA), transfer RNA (tRNA), and messenger RNA (mRNA) are subjected to regulated and dynamic tissue-specific, signaling-specific, or disease-specific chemical modifications, many of which appear to regulate the fate and function of these RNAs. Although N6-methyladenosine (m6A) in mRNA comprises the major focus of the scientific community, other highly prevalent, and possibly similarly important, modifications in rRNA, tRNA and mRNA have not been studied in similar depth due to the lack the tools to quantify their precise stoichiometries in a site-specific and high-throughput manner. The Center for Quantitative and Site-Specific Analysis of RNA Modifications comprises an interdisciplinary and highly synergistic group of investigators who will develop a suite of enabling technologies that will provide the foundational tools, datasets, protocols, and concepts regarding modified nucleotide function, which will be needed to unravel the function of the still unresolved epitranscriptomic code in rRNA, tRNA, and mRNA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative: As a group, skin cancers are the most commonly diagnosed and treated malignancies in the United States. Increasing age and ultraviolet light exposure are the two most prominent epidemiologic risk factors for the development of skin cancer and are associated with epigenetic changes, like altered DNA methylation. The goal of this study is to define the importance of, and mechanisms responsible for, altered epigenetic states in the progression from normal to cancerous skin.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative: Although artificial intelligence (AI) has shown theoretical promise to mitigate pediatric sepsis, which is a leading cause of morbidity and motility pediatric care, in practice, AI-based interventions have had mixed results. These mixed results are difficult to interpret because current approaches to measure AI system performance are inadequate as they do not establish the causal mechanisms for what is a complex intervention. This study will establish feasibility of measuring mechanism of impact via human performance measures in real world acute care settings.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative As one of four Centers of Excellence (COEs) of FDA's Center for Food Safety and Applied Nutrition, JIFSAN conducts various research and outreach activities in food safety and applied nutrition to help ensure that regulatory decisions have a sound science footing and that the best methods and tools are available to advance food and public health. The JIFSAN's programs support the Food Safety Modernization Act that emphasizes the concept of preventing food safety-related problems before they occur and enhance FDA's efforts to partner with other nations to improve U.S. and worldwide health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Foundational work in bladder health research was completed during the first PLUS funding cycle, with significant transdisciplinary contributions and expertise of the Loyola Clinical Center (LCC) investigators who will work collaboratively in the next funding cycle toward the over-arching goal of advancing bladder health through the final design, conduct and analysis of a large, US population-based observational cohort of women across the life-span, using the Bladder Health Instrument which PLUS developed and validated. Our LCC trans-disciplinary team of researchers plan to conduct high-impact research that challenge existing paradigms and improve research approaches in bladder health, with a focus on musculoskeletal interventions and urobiome research. With the LCC as an integral component of the PLUS Research Consortium, we expect rapid improvements in scientific knowledge and LUTS prevention strategies that will benefit and support the broader research community with particular impact on the broader urology community and women’s health.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PAR-21-174 Utah Project Narrative  The Utah Produce Safety Program will educate and enforce the safe production of fresh fruits and vegetables and promote understanding and compliance with the requirements of FDA’s Produce Safety Rule, 21 CFR 112, Standards for the Growing, Harvesting, Packing, and Holding of Produce for Human Consumption. UDAF Regulatory Services, Plant Industry and Utah State University Cooperative Extension have been engaged in working together to implement the Utah Produce Safety Program. This program will cover these objectives:  • Self-Assessment and Strategic Planning  • Program Administration  • Education, Outreach and Technical Assistance  • Farm Inventory  • Inspection Program  • Compliance and Enforcement  • Produce Related Event Response Planning and Implementation We will conduct an annual self-assessment and set goals for each FOA objective in our Strategic Plan and Project Outline. The UDAF Produce Safety Program will continue to monitor our Program Administration as needed to be successful in each objective listed above and develop a plan of succession. We will continue to monitor and report on Project Outline goals for Outreach and Education, Farm Inventory, Inspection Program elements, Compliance and Enforcement and Produce Related Event Response Planning and Implementation.

PROJECT_TITLE: Path C The State of Utah Cooperative Agreement to Implement and Enhance a Produce Safety Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity-induced metabolic deregulation is linked to increased bone fragility. However, bone is also a crucial driver of energy metabolism, yet the impact of obesity on the bone’s metabolic function remains unclear. Here, we test the possibility that obesity disrupts osteocyte-intrinsic energy metabolism that in turn contributes to deregulation of systemic energy balance. Testing this hypothesis will advance our understanding of the cellular and molecular mechanisms that mediate the crosstalk between bone and metabolic tissues, which will improve the success of clinical efforts to reestablish energy balance while protecting musculoskeletal health in obesity. Project Narrative

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abnormal development of the hemochorial placenta contributes to pregnancy complications and is a significant health issue for mother and fetus. The uterine-placental interface is a complex environment that represents the site of trophoblast cell-guided transformation of uterine cell populations. Identifying regulatory pathways controlling the uterine-placental interface will provide insights into the development of diagnostics and therapeutic interventions for pregnancy-related disorders.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol is the third leading cause of preventable death worldwide yet; hepatic therapeutic interventions remain undiscovered. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Necrosis is a catastrophic lytic form of cell death that occurs in many diseases and injury contexts, and has significant consequences for human health. While other forms of cell death, such as apoptosis, are known to influence the ability of a tissue to recover and regenerate through defined signaling events, it is unknown whether these same events occur during necrosis, and whether they can be manipulated and augmented to improve healing outcomes. Our work will take advantage of the exceptionally powerful genetics of Drosophila, and a novel system we have developed to induce, manipulate and characterize necrosis, to understand the genetic factors and events necessary for necrosis-induced tissue repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Public Health Relevance: In eukaryotes from single-celled fungi to mammals, metabolism takes place in the context of cells organized into spatial compartments known as organelles. In this proposal, we seek to illuminate the fundamental quantitative principles by which the cell coordinates the dynamic properties of its organelles, their regulation by gene expression, and the role coordinated organelle dynamics plays in cellular growth and metabolism. Knowledge of these principles can help uncover mechanisms underlying how cells develop normally into cell types and how in the context of disease, such as cancer and diabetes, they remodel their organelle composition to handle altered metabolic profiles and thus point toward potentially new targets for therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parkinson's disease (PD) is a neurodegenerative disease affecting millions of people globally and there are no therapeutic approaches that can stop or slow down disease progression. Recent research highlights the interaction of glia and neurons as a central mechanism contributing to neurodegeneration, and the advancement in genetic tools and microscopy techniques allows studying disease phenotypes with an exquisite level of detail. The proposed studies seek to examine how neurite defects lead to synaptic dysfunction, and assess the role of glia in PD pathogenesis, with the hope of discovering new therapeutic avenues to manage this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study is motivated by the observation that platelets are frequently dysfunctional immediately following severe injury, a phenomenon which is associated with worse outcomes but which remains poorly understood and therefore inadequately treated. Based on observational studies of injured patients and mechanistic studies in other disease states, there is evidence that mitochondrial DNA released in response to injury acts directly on platelets, leading to platelet dysfunction and impaired systemic fibrinolysis. This proposal aims to evaluate the effect of mitochondrial DNA on platelets by examining a core set of platelet and fibrinolytic functional assays, as applied to an observational human study to gain key clinical insights, a study of isolated platelets in which to probe mechanisms, and an animal study in which to replicate human findings and evaluate potential therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Chronic ischemic heart disease (IHD) continues to be the number one cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with kidney disease. Contrast-enhanced stress perfusion cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for detection of IHD provides high quality images and lacks ionizing radiation, but has technical shortcomings. We propose to develop a new framework for steady state cardiac MRI stress testing that can potentially overcome many drawbacks of stress gadolinium perfusion MRI while heightening its impact across a broad spectrum of patients with renal dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Leveraging the big data generated by large consortiums, e.g., ENCODE, Roadmap Epigenomics, GTEx, and Human Cell Atlas, we will perform a systematic survey of the usage of domesticated TEs-derived promoters in the human genome. We will identify the TEs that were domesticated as promoters of protein-coding genes and non-coding genes in the human genome, and further characterize the tissue-level expression pattern of domesticated TEs-derived transcripts, by using our established transcripts assemble pipeline to analyze the tissue bulk RNA-seq data generated by ENCODE and GTEx. We will investigate the cell-type-specific expression pattern of domesticated TEs-derived transcripts, by reconstructing the single-cell RNA-seq data analysis with novel bioinformatics analysis tool. We will apply comparative-genomics approaches to create the expression matrix of orthologous TEs-derived protein-coding genes across multi-species, and construct the phylogenetic trees to explore the expression pattern changes of TEs-derived protein-coding genes during evolution. Our study will significantly improve our understanding of the expression behaviors of domesticated TE- derived genes in human tissues and cell types, and reveal the contribution of domestication of TEs in gene transcription during human genome evolution.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Overall Component Our proposed Research Hub, UZIMA-DS (UtiliZe health Information for Meaningful impact in East Africa through Data Science) will create a scalable and sustainable platform to apply novel approaches to data assimilation and advanced artificial intelligence/machine learning-based methods to serve as early warning systems to 1) improve health outcomes for at-risk mothers and children and 2) improve mental health outcomes for at-risk adolescents and young adults in Kenya. We will bring together method experts in statistics, computer science, and informatics, health domain experts and practitioners, and partnerships with key stakeholders to not only improve the quality, efficiency, and relevance of multidisciplinary data science in health research, but also its transparency, reproducibility, and dissemination for sustainable impact in Africa. Thus, helping ensure current and future generations of Africans can achieve uzima (health/well-being in Swahili).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Cancer Health Activism Network for Greater Equity (CHANGE) aims to increase Black and African American K-12 student motivation and interest in biosciences and health careers by developing and disseminating novel high school biology lessons that focus on cancer biology and cancer disparities with a social justice lens. High school biology teachers will participate in research internships to study cancer fundamentals and will work with a team of experts to develop lesson plans that connect biology standards with cancer biology and disparities research. We hypothesize that aligning cancer research with the Transformative Leadership framework will create equitable learning experiences for Black and African American students, motivating them to pursue bioscience careers.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development and efficacy-testing of a holistic, personalized, electronically integrated clinical decision support system for left-ventricular assist device (LVAD) candidates will help to ensure that heart failure (HF) patients receive tailored treatments that lead to optimal and values-based outcomes. Our study applies the most advanced personalized risk prediction technologies and decision support available to make sure that evidence about cardiac outcomes is used by both patients and clinicians in the service of shared decision making that leads to more informed and value-concordant health decisions. The impact of this personalized approach to clinical decision making addresses the urgent need to better identify and respond to the specific and dynamic nature of patient needs in seeking treatment for advanced HF.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: A multi-site trial to test benefits of adding a personalized risk calculator to an online decision aid for left ventricular assist device

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Cognitive behavioral therapy involving exposure and ritual prevention (EX/RP) is a first-line treatment for obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD), yet EX/RP leads to more variable responses in women than in men. Studies show that the hormone estrogen affects the brain’s fear extinction network, and the functioning of this network predicts response to EX/RP. This study will examine whether delivering EX/RP to women during the time in their menstrual period when estrogen is high affects the fear extinction network and leads to better outcome, with the long-term goal of optimizing and personalizing treatments for individuals suffering from OCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The brain first becomes active during development, before it can receive signals from any of our senses, and we do not fully understand how this activity affects the maturation of connections between nerve cells. We will use the fruit fly, which has a much simpler brain but offers much greater experimental control, to study how this activity during development comes about and how it controls the organization of nerve cell connections. Answering these fundamental questions about brain development in the fruit fly may lead to insights into the origins of neurodevelopmental diseases.
