IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ion channel proteins underlie neuronal communication, organ function, environmental sensation, and many other physiological processes. The specific ion channels being investigated here are involved in breathing control, kidney function, and heart rate regulation; are disrupted genetically in inherited forms of renal failure, cardiac arrythmias, and pulmonary hypertension; and are targets of anesthetics, antiarrhythmics, and drugs to treat sleep apnea. Studying how these channels operate and are regulated will lead to a better understanding of their physiological roles and the development of more potent and specific therapeutics that target ion channels to promote health and treat disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a poor understanding of tendon healing in humans, which has led to a disconnect between the way treatments are designed for overuse tendon injuries and their use in clinical practice, placing patients at risk for long-lasting impairments, injury recurrence, impaired function, and decreased quality of life. Graft harvest (removing a portion of the tendon to use in another area of the body) provides an opportunity to improve our understanding of tendon healing and narrow the gap between research and clinical practice. Long-term, this will allow us to design better treatments and measures of treatment effectiveness, which will accelerate and enhance recovery from overuse tendon injuries.

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: BDNF and other neurotrophins have widespread and powerful roles in the mammalian nervous system, and are thought to be involved in a number of psychiatric and neurological disorders. However, how neurotrophins function at the cellular and synaptic levels is not well understood. This project will explore the hypothesis that a BDNF ortholog and its Trk receptor are key components in two synaptic feedback loops that underly consolidation of long-term synaptic plasticity and memory, and may suggest how dysfunctions of those loops could contribute to psychiatric and neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions of Americans have late-stage Alzheimer’s and related dementias (ADRD), causing suffering due to loss of awareness of self and family, progressive dependency, physical and neuropsychiatric symptoms, and physical, emotional and financial strain for caregivers. We now propose a multi-site randomized clinical trial of the ADRD Palliative Care (ADRD-PC) program for persons with late-stage ADRD and their family caregivers, triggered during hospitalization. We aim to learn if this program of dementia-specific palliative care, standardized caregiver education, and transitional care is effective to reduce burdensome hospital transfers, improve symptom treatment and control, augment supportive services, and reduce nursing home transitions for patients, and to improve caregiver outcomes of communication, shared decision-making and distress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE Approximately 7% of alcohol users engage in chronic heavy drinking (CHD), which is associated with increased risk of bacterial and viral infections as well as decreased tissue repair ability. These observations suggest a failure of innate immune cells to perform their functions. The proposed research aims to identify CHD-mediated functional, transcriptomic, and epigenetic alterations in monocytes and their progenitors in the bone marrow, with the goal of better understanding the etiology of reduced immune fitness.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans bear a disproportionate burden of disability as a result of chronic limb threatening ischemia (CLTI) compared to their age-matched non-Veteran counterparts, often culminating in limb loss. Restoring of blood flow through surgery is the ideal treatment, however, not all Veterans are able to successfully undergo surgery to achieve this. New therapies aimed at local vascular regeneration to restore perfusion and function of the ischemic leg are paramount. This study aims to generate and embed clinical grade stem cell-derived endothelial cells in a resorbable platelet lysate hydrogel, and to implant these cells into ischemic mouse hindlimbs to quantify the restoration of perfusion and function. This is a critical step toward applying induced pluripotent stem cells to vascular regeneration to improve therapies for Veterans with CLTI.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE    Heavy  metal  homeostasis  is  essential  for  normal  physiology,  whose  deregulation  is  associated  with  multiple  human  diseases.  Understanding the elaborate  response  system that  sequesters and  expels  overdosed heavy  metals  is  significant  for  human  health.  Our  proposed  research  will  focus  on  the  molecular  mechanisms  underlying  heavy  metal  response,  which  will  shed  lights  on  various  physiological  and  pathological  processes  involving heavy metals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: In this project, we will provide an atomic level view, and mechanistic insights into the lytic transglycosylase peptidoglycan degrading multi-enzyme machines in the human pathogen Neisseria meningitidis. This project will use a multifaceted approach, that will apply tools of biochemistry, bacterial physiology, genetics, and structural biology; to define the dynamic interactions of these enzymatic machineries and elucidate their role in peptidoglycan formation as well as organelle assembly and insertion across the bacterial cell wall. We aim to define molecular interactions that could be used to develop the next generation of antibiotics aimed at treating infections caused by drug-resistant bacterial pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The demographics of tenure-track biomedical faculty at research universities do not closely match those of the general US population, as women, some racial groups and disabled scientists are under-represented in the professoriate. Broadening participation by these groups is a national priority because it will ensure that the US captures as much of the research talent pool as possible and because it will make universities more equitable. To address this need, the American Society for Cell Biology’s AMP program will combine skills development workshops, mentor training and institutional culture-change initiatives at universities to support postdoctoral researchers from under-represented groups as they attain and thrive in tenure-track faculty positions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: There is mounting evidence that proteins at the cell membrane, which allow cells to sense and respond to the external environment, are highly organized. The goal of the proposed studies is to investigate the nature of this organization, how it comes about, and how it affects the proteins’ functions, focusing on processes that regulate blood vessel formation and immune cell function. This will be achieved by developing innovative live-cell imaging and computational image and data analysis approaches to quantitatively probe molecules in their native cellular environment and dissect their complex behaviors and interrelationships.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Morphological plasticity is fundamental to bacterial fitness and survival in a variety of environmental and host- associated niches. Filamentation is an example of this plasticity, as bacteria can dramatically increase in length to survive a variety of insults, including predation, phagocytosis, and exposure to antimicrobial compounds. This proposal will characterize a novel, nutrient-based mechanism for induction of filamentation whereby an intracellular bacterium detects invasion of a host cell to initiate filamentation for spreading into neighboring cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The element iron plays an enormous role in biology, and we plan to study how iron contributes to catalysis (in hydrogenases), to pH and small molecule sensing (in NEET proteins), and to electron transport reactions (in rubredoxins). Using very bright x-ray beams from synchrotron radiation sources, we will study the vibrations of iron in the above systems, and this will provide structural information about how these proteins work. Information and insights gained from this project will help us better understand the biological chemistry of iron, so that we can learn from Nature to create a more efficient and healthier society and perhaps alleviate the damage from cancer and other diseases that occurs when some of these enzymes fail.

PHR: Narrative We will analyze whole-genome and RNA sequence data in a unique collection of multigenerational Utah pedigrees to answer fundamental questions about the causes and consequences of germline mutation, somatic mutation, and DNA repair. IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Secure messaging (SM) via patient portals is an effective health IT platform that can enable patients and providers to reach shared understanding, an intermediate communication outcome, which has been linked to improved adherence, better disease control, and safer outcomes. For patients with communication barriers, advanced age or severe illness, SM also has potential to engage caregivers in facilitating patients’ ability to reach shared understanding with their healthcare providers. The goal of the research proposed in this career development award is to (a) understand the value and attributes of caregiver involvement in SM exchange between diverse T2D patients and their providers, and (b) apply this knowledge to develop a pilot portal intervention in the safety-net targeting diverse T2D patients (at high risk for hypoglycemia, a patient safety event) and their caregivers to promote shared understanding and safety.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Promoting Safety by Engaging Diverse Diabetes Patients and their Caregivers in Secure Messaging

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The advent of molecular imaging has prompted a paradigm shift in medical imaging as a whole, from its foundations in purely anatomical imaging towards techniques aimed at probing tissue phenotype and function. We have for many years exploited aberrant targets associated with cancer in order to better diagnose, stage and monitor this disease. In this R35, we plan to highlight three highly integrated areas within the context of our expertise and insights that will have a significant impact on cancer treatment outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Overall The Duke Pepper Older Americans Independence Center (OAIC) will advance knowledge of reserve and resilience in older adults and develop and evaluate strategies to improve the ability of older adults to withstand or recover from health stressors. Aging is associated with increasing exposure and vulnerability to multiple stressors that threaten independence; so, research on resilience in older adults is essential to bolster independence. The Duke OAIC will train promising new investigators through a comprehensive multidisciplinary program and support pilot studies to lead to innovative larger grants investigating reserve and resilience in older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Autoimmune tissue inflammation is dictated by a balance between proinflammatory effector T cells and tissue protective FoxP3+ regulatory T cells. The factors besides cytokines that regulate the balance between Tregs and Th17 are beginning to be elucidated. By developing a novel computational algorithm Compass, we have identified polyamine pathway as a major metabolic driver the dictates the balance between Treg and Th17 cells. The proposal will focus on understanding the role of polyamine metabolism, mitochondrial respiration, and demethylase Jmjd3/Kdm6b at a molecular level by analyzing changes in transcriptome, metabolome, and epigenome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Social support, a social determinant of health (SDoH), is a definitive predictor of breast cancer (BC) treatment and mortality outcomes and is critical to racial/ethnic disparities in breast cancer (BC) treatment and mortality outcomes. This study will develop and validate an Electronic Health Record Social Support Patient Risk Tool (EHR-SUPPORT) in 44,348 women diagnosed with BC from Kaiser Permanente Northern California. Developing this measure is central to identifying patients at risk of low social support and to enhancing social support-cancer research needed to improve clinical care and reduce BC disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As we age, mutations accumulate inside our cells that limit energy production, contributing to various forms of age-related pathology, including muscle wasting and neurodegeneration. In this application, we propose to determine when these mutations arise, what happens to them as we grow older and whether they can be selectively removed from our cells. Together, these experiments will help us gain a deeper understanding of the aging process itself, guide the development of treatments that are aimed at treating age-related disease, and help us determine when these treatments should be administered.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The proposed research is relevant to public health because Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) causes muscle wasting, heart disease, and ultimately death. In this application, we will test a novel mechanism through which cardiac fibroblasts produce FGF23 to promote cardiac myocyte remodeling and functional defects in DMD hearts. The proposed research is relevant to NHLBI’s mission to identify specific pathogenic mechanisms that promote cardiomyopathy for the development of targeted therapeutics to preserve heart function so that patients can live longer and more fulfilling lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Many transgender people have an increased risk of HIV acquisition compared to the general population, yet little is known about how the use of gender-affirming hormones may impact mucosal HIV transmission. In this proposal, we will examine the effects of biological sex and sex hormone treatment on rectal mucosal epithelial and immune cell transcriptomic diversity and function, and we will assess the impact of sex hormone treatment on rectal mucosal immune responses and HIV susceptibility. A better understanding of rectal HIV transmission among transgender people utilizing gender-affirming hormone therapy could contribute to the development of sex- and gender-specific biomedical HIV prevention interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Musculoskeletal complications associated with the occurrence of cachexia afflict up to 80% of patients diagnosed with colorectal cancer, and equally impact the quality of life in cancer survivors. By using in vitro and in vivo experimental models, we will define new pathological mechanisms responsible for bone resorption and muscle wasting in a context of elevated liver-derived IGFBP1. This study will shed light on novel mechanisms of cachexia and identify IGFBP1 as a therapeutic target for the treatment of musculoskeletal deficits in colorectal cancer.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Narrative The overarching goal of the Data Science for Social Determinants (DSSD) pre- and post-doctoral training program is to develop future leaders in data science who are equipped to develop and analyze data to better leverage deep and rich survey as well as internet and other digitized data sources that can help us capture information on the social determinants of health. Such data can provide unique illumination into factors on where we live, work, and play which can be used to better understand and address health disparities across noncommunicable disease, infectious disease and injuries in the Kenyan context. However, the data are often unstructured and can have complex relationships with health outcomes, making the use of modern data science approaches critical. DSSD leverages strong investment across biomedical, public health, data science and artificial intelligence investment at both partners (NYU School of Medicine is 11th in the nation for NIH funding, NYU is home of the AI-now institute and Moi University has a strong NIH funding record) as well as a broader network of academic, industrial and non-governmental organizations (IBM, Deep Learning Indaba, DataKind, AI.Kenya and Aga Khan University Nairobi and Karachi), opening a wide pool of potential, strong trainees from both data science and health backgrounds. To develop capacity, priority will be given to Moi affiliates, Kenyan citizens and then others from anywhere in Africa while also prioritizing diversity. A complementary team of 23 mentors at NYU and Moi committed to training and career development will offer resources across social determinants, biomedical sciences, statistics, epidemiology, data management, analytics and ethics. First, the program will provide long-term development of a cohort of PhD, postdoctoral and Faculty fellow trainees who will benefit from interdisciplinary training that carefully layers a core set of competencies in data science across data management and wrangling, prediction and analytics and data communication and ethics, with didactic and experiential training in social determinants as well as best practices in responsible conduct of research, reproducibility and community-engaged, ethical data science at NYU. Second, the program will leverage international standard biostatistics and informatics faculty and programming at Moi with trainees equipped in advanced data science coursework at NYU, to expand the base of local expertise and capacity in data science by developing MSc and PhD data science tracks at the Institute for Biomedical Informatics and Biostatistics programs at Moi University within 5 years. Finally, continuing education opportunities and networking will occur through workshops bringing together experts in health and data science in Kenya and surrounding areas. Programs will be evaluated annually by our Internal Advisory Board and Training Advisory Committee. As social determinants can be cross-cutting rather than disease-specific, classroom and research opportunities across social determinants and their applicability to wide range of health application domains will be available at both project sites and curricula will be relevant to research and training efforts across the entire DSI-Africa consortium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Relevance: The proposed program aims to develop new technologies that will allow advancements in the chemical and biological understanding of botanicals and natural products that are used for the improvement of health and the potential treatment to a wide range of disorders. As part of the development of these new technologies, we aim to provide a greater understanding of how multiple constituents in a botanical or natural products work in synergy to provide a biological activity. Overall, this program will help provide greater basic understanding of the molecules that are part of a $17 billion healthcare industry that currently has a number of outstanding questions.

The Healthy Brain and Child Development National Consortium (HBCD-NC) will follow 7,500 mothers and their children from 24 locations across the U.S. from before birth to 10 years of age to better understand which harmful and protective environments exert the greatest impact on child development. This study will help to improve the health and development of children across the nation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  In Africa, malaria in pregnancy contributes to approximately 20% of low birthweight infants and as such, the World Health Organization recommends a malaria chemoprevention strategy in which pregnant women receive repeated doses of sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (SP) throughout their pregnancy. However, recent evidence suggests that SP, an antimalarial with known antibiotic and anti-inflammatory properties, may be improving LBW through mechanisms independent of its antimalarial activity. Thus, the goal of the proposed research is to improve our understanding of these non-malarial mechanisms in order to inform more optimal chemoprevention drug regimens that can target both the malarial and non-malarial causes of adverse birth outcomes in Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This is an application to renew current R01 award that has funded our research on small-fiber neuropathy (SFN), which is increasingly linked to fibromyalgia and mysterious multi-symptom illnesses that include unexplained widespread pain, intolerance of exertion and gastrointestinal discomfort. We now propose to revise and optimize the tools we developed for SFN diagnosis for use by doctors and patients around the world and to work with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration to get their Qualification recommendations on how to improve the skin biopsies used globally to confirm SFN diagnoses. We will also collaborate with a leading neuropathy geneticist to sequence the genes of SFN patients we select with our tools that have genetic mutations likely to contribute fundamental knowledge about SFN.

PHR: Filoviruses such as Ebola virus and Marburg virus are among the most lethal viral pathogens, but our understanding of their biology is incomplete. Our studies will clarify how expression of filoviral proteins is regulated and how these viruses evade antiviral responses of the host, thereby providing insight into what makes these viruses such deadly pathogens..

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative These studies will address the unanswered fundamental question as to how androgen receptor (AR)-expressing cells recognize and respond to different doses of physiological/synthetic androgens. They will also formally test the “coregulator hypothesis” by exploring the relationship between hormone-induced changes in AR structure, differential recruitment of functionally distinct coregulators, and biological response. The insights from this work will be informative with respect to the pharmacology of existing AR-modulators and will direct approaches to develop the next generation of modulators for use in the treatment of prostate cancer (PCa) and other androgenopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative This proposal will pursue an HIV functional cure by developing a new generation of anti-HIV CD4 CARs that are resistant to exhaustion, enhanced for reactivation for improved immune surveillance and rendered infection-proof to maintain the pool of activated CD4 CAR-T cells without depletion. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to test the efficacy of a theory-based mHealth intervention, PositiveLinks (PL) to improve retention in care and viral suppression among people living with HIV. We will adapt PL to an urban cohort of PLWH receiving care in Washington, DC, determine its efficacy compared to the standard of care at 12 months, and conduct mixed methods implementation science research to identify multi-level factors that characterize best practices to implement PL. If successful, this research will lead to the development of a novel and efficacious approach to improving retention in care and viral suppression among PLWH that could contribute to HIV epidemic control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative How consumers access and utilize retail food outlets could have significant impacts on dietary quality, an important and modifiable behavioral risk factor. At present, methods for the long-term, objective measurement of consumer interaction with the food environment in population research is greatly limited. Using existing geospatial location data from smartphones, we will develop new long-term measures of food retailer use and measure how patterns of food retailing use relates to measures of dietary quality, body weight, and health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) are cumulative childhood exposures to potentially traumatic family and community experiences that can have lasting, negative impact on health, with potential intergenerational transmission of effects. The purpose of this mixed methods study is to understand how parents' exposures to ACEs and positive childhood experiences (PCEs) impact their parenting practices, particularly in the context of living in unsafe neighborhoods. This study will advance the science of ACEs by elucidating protective and health-promoting factors in the intergenerational transmission of ACEs and explore a method of understanding how neighborhoods influence the impact of ACEs and PCEs on parenting practices using community-level geospatial data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite several weight loss-independent benefits of exercise, nearly half of Americans with obesity do not exercise due to low time availability and exertional dyspnea – a major barrier to exercise participation. However, emerging data demonstrates that time-efficient (5-minutes daily) high-resistance inspiratory muscle strength training (IMST) improves cardiovascular health in clinical populations. Therefore, we will determine whether IMST reduces blood pressure, improves respiratory muscle function, and reduces exertional dyspnea using a randomized, double-blind, sham-controlled clinical trial among adults with obesity – potentially identifying a novel, safe, and time-efficient lifestyle strategy to mitigate obesity-related cardiovascular and respiratory dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: A large body of evidence has demonstrated that unique immune cell types and molecular mediators differentially contribute to pain pathogenesis in male and females. In this study, we propose to identify new sexually dimorphic drivers of pain using a novel reverse translational screening approach in conjunction with proteomic and transcriptomic technologies. This project is anticipated to identify new cell types and soluble protein mediators that are causally associated with pain and its comorbidities in patients with chronic pain conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The overall objective of this proposal is to train graduate students and postdoctoral scientists about the concept of implicit bias, the effects of bias on underrepresented minority students in the biomedical, behavioral and clinical science (BBCS) fields, and the strategies to mitigate the effects of bias on themselves, as well as in their current and future work environments. This training both complements and extends the previously-funded project titled, Breaking the Bias Cycle for Future Scientists: A Workshop to Learn, Experience, and Change (NIH-NIGMS, R25GM114002, 2005-2020). It also leverages a number of other NIH-funded projects to ensure that successful bias-reducing and mentoring models, trainings/workshops, and strategies are applied in different venues and with additional populations (Carnes, 2015, 2017; Kaatz et al., 2017; Sorkness et al., 2017).

By enhancing the biomedical research enterprise in Puerto Rico, the PR-INBRE will increase the representation of Hispanics in the national biomedical workforce and expand their contributions to the improvement of human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Overall Antibiotic resistance is one of the foremost public health concerns worldwide. This program to combat antibiotic resistance, which has as its goal to develop new approaches to treat antibiotic resistant infections by targeting the bacterial cell envelope, was specifically designed to be responsive to this global threat. A highly productive multidisciplinary team will function collaboratively to capitalize on the many advances it has already made to enable fundamentally new approaches that target this essential structure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Individual cells generate and harness polarity domains to organize their contents and drive morphogenesis. The proposed research will fill a critical knowledge gap by investigating how dynamic polarity domains are generated to control cell identity at single-cell resolution within complex, developing tissues. Interrogating polarization mechanisms during morphogenesis will provide valuable insight into essential developmental pathways that are also associated with disease states, such as tumorigenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mammary glands continue to develop throughout late puberty and early adulthood when they are sensitive to environmental disrupters that can increase later breast cancer risk. Using a rat model of human breast development and cancer, our transdisciplinary team, comprised of behavioral, endocrine, and breast cancer biologists, will study how increased stress hormone reactivity, resulting from continuous social isolation, disrupts mammary gland development and stem cell differentiation, thereby increasing the risk of breast cancer. We will also determine if normal mammary gland development can be restored and cancer risk reduced by a pharmacological or social intervention that attenuate stress hormone reactivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative  The proposed research is relevant to public health because the methionine metabolism pathway is altered in a number of different diseases including cancer, obesity, neurodegeneration, and aging. By establishing a mechanistic connection between this pathway and downstream methyltransferases, we will be able to provide attractive and “druggable” targets for the development of novel therapies relevant to these diseases. Therefore, the research is relevant to NIGMS’s mission in supporting basic research that increases understanding of biological processes and laying the foundation for advances in disease treatment.

PROJECT_TITLE: Deciphering the crosstalk between methionine metabolism and methyltransferases in health and disease

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: While the U.S. population of adults age 65 and over is predicted to double from 35 million in 2000 to 70 million by 2030, the number of physicians with training in aging research is declining. In a parallel, the aging population's diversity is increasing while the proportion of physicians from underrepresented or disadvantaged backgrounds entering careers in aging research is insufficient to meet society's needs. A program that stimulates and excites the interest of a cadre of culturally and ethnically diverse medical students to choose careers in aging research is critically needed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative  Fragile X syndrome (FXS) is one of the most common inherited intellectual disabilities (ID) that is caused by transcriptional silencing of the Fmr1 gene and loss of its encoded fragile X messenger ribonucleoprotein (FMRP). This project will investigate how a particular small non-coding RNA, microRNA-128, regulates postnatal astroglial development and also how the selective loss of this microRNA in brain astroglial cells impact typical FXS phenotypes. Results from this project will begin to define specific microRNA that regulates postnatal astroglial development and will reveal astroglia specific mechanisms and targets to modulate FXS disease development, thus will advance our understanding about the role of astroglia in FXS pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This study is relevant to public health because mortality following allogeneic bone marrow transplant remains a major barrier to its use for patients with all diseases which require bone marrow transplant for survival. Reduced intensity and reduced toxicity conditioning regimens that contain alemtuzumab offer the benefit of less toxicity for patients but are still hindered by transplant complications including acute graft versus host disease and graft failure. This study will test a novel Precision Alemtuzumab Dosing strategy to target alemtuzumab levels to an optimal therapeutic range which will decrease graft failure and graft versus host disease and improve immune recovery and patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Transcription factors are proteins that turn genes ON or OFF. When we sequence a new genome, we can predict transcription factors, but we cannot predict which transcription factors turn target genes ON. We are studying the different ways transcription factors turn genes ON and working to predict the regions of transcription factors responsible for this function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Maintaining genome integrity is an essential task of all cells, and imperfect repair of the damaged genome is responsible for a myriad of human diseases, ranging from aggressive cancers to defective immune systems. This research proposal aims to incorporate on-demand CRISPR technologies and quantitative biophysical approaches to investigate the complex DNA damage responses induced by DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) in living mammalian cells. Revealing the detailed spatiotemporal information of DDR will inform how kinetics, structures, and chromatin status modulate DSB repair pathway choices, transcription activity, and their interplay with the innate immune systems, providing valuable information complementary to traditional steady-state biochemical and genetic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: The human-seeking motivation of mosquitoes in response to human cues is not only essential for female mosquito reproduction, but also for the transmission of mosquito-borne viruses that affect ~400 million people worldwide. Two of these viruses have been recently shown to manipulate human skin microbiome to produce mosquito attractants and thus facilitate their transmission. This proposal will address how these viruses do so and whether this mechanism can be applicable to many more mosquito-borne viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CD1 autoreactive T cells in human immune mediated skin disease D. Branch Moody, MD Contact dermatitis, psoriasis and other major human skin disease involve antigens that activate immune cells known as T cells. This proposal takes a unique approach to study lipids and small molecules that turn off T cell activation by binding and blocking a protein known as CD1a. Using human cells and tissues, as well as mice expressing human CD1a proteins, we will identify the molecules, receptors and activation pathways involved in human skin T cell response, with the goal of discovering fundamentally new disease treatments.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Black and Latinx adolescents in low-income urban communities are disproportionately exposed to stress and trauma stemming from systemic racism, including COVID-19 adversities, police brutality, and oppressive immigration policies, exacerbating mental health disparities; however, critical consciousness (social justice awareness and action) may serve as a protective factor. We will collect quantitative and qualitative data on Black, Latinx, and White urban adolescents over a four-year period to assess race-related stress, critical consciousness, and emotional and behavioral health trajectories and test the potentially protective role of critical consciousness. Findings will inform policy and intervention development to enhance adolescent mental health equity.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed studies aim to leverage a physiologically relevant non-human primate model of both HIV and malaria to identify key immune factors that drive poor maternal and fetal outcomes during infection in pregnancy. Establishing such immune mechanisms would create potential for considerable advances in the identification and pre-clinical testing of novel therapeutic strategies to restore health in women living with HIV who become infected with malaria during pregnancy. The proposed research is relevant to the mission of the NICHD as it will significantly contribute to the ultimate goal of reducing the substantial burden of malaria infection in vulnerable women living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mantle cell lymphoma is a lethal cancer with no standard of care and upon disease relapse, the cancer is considered clinically incurable. The proposed project will shed light on how different sized mRNA transcripts of cyclin D1 are processed to increase their half-life and tumorigenic potential which can be applied to other disease causing genes. In addition, we will also identify recurrent fusion genes that arise from two distinct parent genes that are a consequence of cyclin D1 induced chromosomal instability which in the long-term can be used as potential biomarkers that will help us stratify MCL patients for molecularly targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Our EDRN BCC proposal aims to address the critical clinical unmet needs of over-treatment and under-treatment in prostate cancer. We plan to develop in vitro diagnostic multivariate index assays (IVDMIA) that combine a panel of biomarkers into a single-valued numerical index for the conservative treatment of prostate cancer patients through the Active Surveillance (AS) approach. The discovery, validation, and translation of prostate cancer biomarkers into clinical diagnostics, as well as the development of clinical-grade assays will be accomplished through partnerships with EDRN BCC, CVC, and DMCC components, and the diagnostics industry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Globally, acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is the most common cancer in children 0-14 years of age, with an estimated 74,000 incident cases each year and a disproportionate number of years of life lost in Asia, the Middle East/North Africa, and sub-Saharan Africa. In order to address genetic risk of this disease in diverse populations, we will examine existing genotype data for ~12,000 children with ALL in the Childhood Cancer and Leukemia International Consortium. Specifically, we propose to: 1) estimate heritability for ALL in diverse populations, 2) conduct comprehensive genomewide and local discovery for variants associated with ALL, and 3) create population-specific polygenic risk scores for risk of ALL and examine their relationship with non-genetic risk factors.

PHR: Overall Component Project Narrative Mobility and balance disorders are common among the aged and contribute to reduced physical activity, falls, injuries, disability, loss of independence and health care utilization. Our multidisciplinary group of collaborative investigators are dedicated to foster optimal mobility and balance among older Americans, both through improved understanding of their causes and through development of preventive and therapeutic interventions to reduce falls and maintain independence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Latino children experience increased incidence of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), as well as disparities in ALL treatment toxicities, relapse, and survival – however, less is known about neurocognitive outcomes in Latino survivors, which has important implications for educational attainment and quality of life. The proposed study will employ an accelerated longitudinal cohort design to examine for the first time ever 1) the extent to which neurocognitive response to ALL chemotherapy differs by ethnicity; and 2) the relative contribution of clinical, socioeconomic, cultural, and biological variability in explaining neurocognitive disparities among childhood ALL survivors. This line of research is well-poised to identify: a) subpopulations of youth at greatest risk for neurocognitive difficulties and in greatest need of intervention; b) critical points in treatment/survivorship to employ intervention strategies to mitigate disparities in neurocognitive outcome; and c) potential targets for intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO RIO PIEDRAS
PHR: Narrative The IDGeNe program will be the first training program for undergraduates of its kind at the University of Puerto Rico (UPR), a premier research-intensive Hispanic Serving Institution in the USA. This program aims to attract students into the Genomics field by providing meaningful, in depth, experiences in areas of research associated with Genomics and by providing a series of academic and professional activities that will prepare a new generation of promising underrepresented students to insert themselves into this growing biomedical field. In view of the history and track record of the UPR, this grant will succeed in increasing the diversity of the field by increasing the number of Hispanic researchers in the 21st Century Genomics workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE InterveXion has created humanized methamphetamine (METH)-binding variable regions and modified antibody constant domains that when combined are likely to produce an anti-METH antibody for treating METH use disorder with a target dosing frequency of only once every 2-3 months. The studies in this proposal are designed to identify which combination of antibody segments are most effective in reducing METH stimulant effects, to develop a scalable manufacturing platform, and to test the lead candidate’s safety in toxicology studies. When completed, this medication will be ready for initial clinical trials and if successful would significantly improve patient outcomes and adherence to therapy while lowering the cost and burden of delivering healthcare for patients with METH use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic exposure to diabetogenic environments such as inflammation can alter β-cell to β-cell communication which can impact the overall function and survival of these cells during Type 1 diabetes (T1D) pathogenesis. Emerging evidence has implicated circulating membrane-derived nanovesicles termed extracellular vesicles (EVs) as mediators of T1D pathogenesis through the delivery of harmful β-cell EV cargoes to recipient β-cells to induce dysfunction. The overall goal of this project is to understand how alterations in β-cell EV cargo can change the physiological state of the β-cell and the mechanisms behind this process, which will help to afford novel biomarker and therapeutic strategies to improve β-cell health in T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research will apply novel and established techniques and approaches towards understanding the molecular mechanism of function of a physiologically important class of ion channels, the cyclic nucleotide gated channels, that are responsible for visual and olfactory signal transduction and the pacemaking activity of the heart and brain. Understanding the fundamental mechanisms of channel workings is a prerequisite to understanding the critical physiological processes they control. The insight we gain into the basic mechanism of this important class of channels will enable the design and discovery of novel therapeutics that specifically target the channels responsible for particular disease conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The overall goal of this project is to increase numbers of clinical trials and observational cohort studies in Institutional Development Award (IDeA) states that currently have less than 10% of active NIH supported trials. Strategies to accomplish this goal include communicating to trial sponsors the expertise, quality, and capacity of IDeA state institutions to conduct clinical trials and to IDeA investigators available clinical trial opportunities. We will also train a cadre of skilled research coordinators across IDeA states to provide the necessary workforce capacity to conduct increased numbers of trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Relevance: The brain shows marked plasticity across a variety of learning and memory tasks as well as during recovery after injury. This proposal aims to investigate targeted stimulation of cortex to drive cortical plasticity and induce functional recovery via state-of-the-art electrophysiology and optogenetics to simultaneously record and manipulate activity of sensorimotor neurons in awake behaving macaques. Understanding the role of these basic physiological phenomena will shed light on underlying mechanisms of brain plasticity that leads to functional reorganization in the brain and can provide us with vital insight to develop stimulation-based therapies for a broad range of neurological disorders such as stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The Greater Boston MSTAR Program at Harvard Medical School was developed to address the increasing need for medical students to pursue careers in aging research and geriatrics. By exposing students to this field early in their careers, this proposal addresses these needs by providing aging research training for 11 students per year for the next 5 years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many qualified students, especially students from historically underrepresented groups (i.e., women and racial minorities), are choosing not to pursue graduate education in the biomedical sciences, or are leaving biomedical science graduate training programs early, creating a critical deficit in  the unique perspectives necessary to perform the innovative research that will benefit the health of our increasingly diverse population . Good mentoring relationships are critical for recruiting and retaining students with diverse backgrounds in science because they provide encouragement, guidance, and social support that enhance student personal and professional development, as well as their integration into the scientific profession. To promote good mentoring relationships, we will build online courses that will empower students with the ability to establish and maintain positive mentoring and collegial relationships shown to be associated with successful biomedical research careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The number of adolescents living with HIV (ALHIV) in Uganda is over 170,000 and growing, yet less than 50% of ALHIV in Uganda are ART-adherent, leading to low rates of viral suppression due to social and structural inequities. Informed by the multi-phase optimization strategy (MOST), we propose to conduct a factorial experiment (optimization trial) to identify the most cost-effective combination of four-intervention components for viral suppression and ART adherence, as well as mental health and several psychosocial outcomes among ALHIV in Uganda. The proposal will unpack a multi-component combination intervention named Suubi that uses economic empowerment and psychosocial intervention components to address social and structural inequities, with the goal of optimizing the Suubi intervention to enhance scale up in health systems and advance intervention science for HIV care globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this grant cycle, we test whether right and left hemisphere temporal regions have different roles in processing the sounds of speech, examining neuroimaging and TMS data from typical controls and behavioral data from individuals with left and right temporal lobe lesions. Understanding the roles of right and left hemisphere regions is key to developing appropriate rehabilitation strategies for people with aphasia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Cellular membranes not only compartmentalize intracellular processes, but also serve as the dynamic hubs for the assembly of many multi-protein signaling complexes, oncoproteins, and tumor suppressors. This proposal will investigate the role played by membrane anchored substrate degradation via the ubiquitin proteasome system, modulating communication networks for cell survival and proliferation. The results of this application are expected to impact cancer and cardiac biology.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this training program is to strengthen research that will ultimately improve cardiovascular disease (CVD)-related health outcomes in Haiti and the world. We will address the knowledge gaps in understanding and intervening in the CVD epidemic in Haiti by providing mentored CVD research training to Haitian investigators, training research staff in technical CVD skills, and establishing a CVD Implementation Network to accelerate the uptake of CVD interventions across the country. This would be the first CVD-specific research training program in Haiti and is urgently needed to expand locally driven CVD research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Drug formulations are key to enable the safe and effective delivery of therapeutics but are currently costly to produce or insufficiently optimized for specific drugs and specific patients. We will here develop novel platforms that tightly integrate machine learning and experiments to more rapidly and effectively design (1) functional excipients, (2) targeted nanoparticles, and (3) prodrugs. Our research will pioneer and prototype innovative approaches in the nascent field of computational drug delivery and will also produce targeted drug formulations that provide safer and more effective therapies for every patient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The aim of this project is to bring together engineers and a group of multi-disciplinary clinicians to develop the Comprehensive Augmented Reality Testing (CART) platform to enhance the understanding and treatment of Parkinson’s disease (PD). The CART platform will utilize augmented reality technology to systematically evaluate motor and cognitive function and the performance of instrumental activities of daily living on a single technology platform. Following completion of software development, a series of validation and reliability experiments will be competed in 140 individuals with PD, evenly dispersed among Hoehn & Yahr stages, and 35 age-matched controls to ensure the CART platform provides accurate and actionable information about PD symptoms to ultimately advance PD treatment strategies and discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our PCDC-RU proposal aims to address the critical clinical unmet needs of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC). We plan to develop in vitro diagnostic multivariate index assays (IVDMIA) that combine a panel of biomarkers into a single-valued numerical index for the early detection of PDAC and high-risk lesions. The discovery, verification, validation and translation of pancreatic cancer biomarkers into clinical diagnostics, as well as the development of clinical-grade assays will be accomplished through partnerships with other PCDC-RUs, the MDCU, and the diagnostics industry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Irradiations with extreme dose rates (FLASH) has been shown to greatly spare healthy tissue while not affecting tumor control, promising to significantly improve radiation therapy (RT). However, the underlying mechanisms are not yet understood, preventing optimal clinical use of FLASH-RT. This proposal combines chemistry, in vitro and in vivo experiments with a multi-scale modeling approach from the DNA scale up, to determine the mechanisms of FLASH-RT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to establish whether the mechanisms of alpha-range (8-12Hz) neural oscillations, robustly observed in human visual cortex, are strictly attentional or whether they reflect other mechanisms, such as local visual dynamics or system-wide alertness. We will record EEG and fMRI concurrently in human participants, and employ causal models, to identify functional connectivity of visual cortex during alpha modulations across different task contexts. The results will drive interpretation of alpha oscillations as a biomarker of attention-system efficacy in ADHD and related conditions, refining a model that can be targeted in treatment monitoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - Overall The vision of the UC Davis ADRC is to strive for a lifetime of brain health for all and our mission is to advance the science of healthy brain aging among diverse populations while caring for those affected by dementia. This vision and mission reflects the evolving needs of an increasingly older and more diverse US population. Moreover, while AD continues to be the major pathological cause of dementia, more recent studies find that dementia pathology is multifactorial and highly heterogeneous, due in part to the co-occurrence of AD and vascular disease, which varies by ethnoracial characteristics, is emphasized as part of dementia prediction and which can be modified by treatment even in later life.

PHR: Project Narrative This project will define biochemical and cellular mechanisms by which the innate immune kinase TBK1 promotes activation of the anabolic kinase mTOR. Through study of genetically modified mice, it will also advance our knowledge of how the TBK1-mTOR axis integrates innate immune and metabolic signals to attenuate obesity-linked insulin resistance and hyperglycemia, potentially revealing therapeutic opportunities to treat type II diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal explores the basic mechanisms whereby members of the Bacillus cereus sensu lato group cause gastrointestinal anthrax, a lethal disease that affects all mammals. Host-pathogen interactions are studied in the context of the unusual lifestyle of these spore-forming bacteria and their unique envelope. Results from these studies are expected to be broadly informative for the appreciation of gastrointestinal infections by invasive pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although intersectional stigma and discrimination are critical barriers to HIV care engagement among women living with HIV who use drugs (WLHIV-WUD) in the United States (US), there is a notable lack of interventions that draw upon intersectionality to optimize HIV care in this population. This study will examine how stigma and discrimination lead to intersectional inequalities in antiretroviral therapy adherence and viral suppression and explore how resilience promotes HIV care, to inform the systematic adaptation of an HIV-related evidence- based intervention to facilitate engagement in care among racially diverse WLHIV-WUD in the US. Findings from this research will advance HIV treatment and intervention science by applying an intersectional framework and approach to improve HIV treatment outcomes and promote intersectional equity among WLHIV-WUD through the delivery of specialized intervention strategies.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative NEUFIN (Neuroscience in First Nations) is a unique advanced research training and mentoring program focused on the indigenous minorities of South America, one of the most underserved populations in the globe. Over the past five years we completed two cycles of advanced training -in the context of an international master of science degree - and capacity development, for scholars and faculty of First Nations from Bolivia, Peru and Argentina. We will continue to build capacity and train Quechua neuroscientists on clinical research applications of neuroimaging, genetics, epidemiology, neuropsychology and neuromodulation. We will also create personalized training environments and an innovation ecosystem online to support capacity and career development for Quechua neuroscientists after completion of their initial degree.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pain is a common, highly distressing symptom for patients hospitalized in comprehensive rehabilitation that may disrupt recovery and rehabilitative efforts (e.g., avoidance of physical therapy). Narcotic treatment is an option for severe pain, but side effects and risk of addiction prevent its long-term use. Using quantitative and qualitative methods, this project will assess the feasibility and acceptability of a pharmaco-behavioral intervention for pain by applying principles of classical conditioning and open-label placebo among hospitalized patients and will inform the science of managing pain and their clinical consequences amongst medical populations more broadly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glucagon and insulin are considered to be opposing factors for regulating glucose metabolism, yet they are co- secreted in response to a mixed nutrient meal. Our preliminary data suggests that glucagon and insulin coordinate, rather than oppose, each other to regulate hepatic glycogen metabolism. In this proposal, we will test the hypothesis that glucagon and insulin generate a unique hepatic signature that leads to optimal systemic glucose utilization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on discovery of novel signaling pathways that drive castration-resistant prostate cancer. These studies will establish new avenues of investigation to develop improved therapeutics to treat this deadly disease and to greatly improve patient outcome. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NCI's mission of fostering creative discoveries and innovative research strategies for protecting and improving health and reducing the burdens associated with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Proper cell shape control is essential for the proliferation of cells, normal development and maintenance of a healthy organism. We study how cytokinesis, the physical process in which one cell splits into two, works at a fundamental level in order to understand how cells control cell shape more generally. Ultimately, with a rigorous understanding and a complete molecular handle on these processes, it should be possible to develop better therapies that are tailored to the properties of specific disease types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Major depressive disorder (MDD) is a chronic, recurrent illness impacting more than a fifth of the U.S. population and causing significant disability and economic impacts annually. Antidepressants are a first-line depression treatment taken by 70% of patients with depression, yet 50% of patients taking an antidepressant continue to experience significant depressive symptoms, creating an urgent need to identify patients at risk for inadequate antidepressant response early to reduce MDD chronicity, disability, and costs. This study aims to 1) develop a predictive model from clinical and demographic data identifying patients at risk for inadequate antidepressant response at first clinical presentation for depression using predictive modeling and machine learning approaches, 2) examine how genetic and behavioral data enhance clinical prediction models, and 3) evaluate barriers and facilitators of predictive models for depression into clinical practice.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE MPIs: de las Fuentes, Lisa; Davila-Roman, Victor G.; Málaga, German; Hartinger, Stella D43 Project Title: “Research Training: Chronic Non-communicable CVDs and Comorbidities in Peru” Project start / end: 9/1/2021-8/31/2026 Chronic non-communicable cardiovascular disease (CVD) and CVD co-morbid conditions are responsible for high morbidity and mortality in Peru. This D43 training program, led by two US institutions (Washington University in St. Louis, MO and Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, MD) in coordination with 2 academic Peruvian institutions (Universidad Peruana Cayetano Heredia in Lima and Universidad Nacional del Altiplano de Puno (UNAP); and a Peruvian NGO in Lima and Puno (AB PRISMA), will develop a comprehensive research training program with the objective of preparing the next generation of Peruvian researchers to conduct high-quality, independent research on chronic CVD across the lifespan in Peru.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is a large and growing public health problem, especially for people with HIV (PWH). Within Kaiser Permanente, we use a syndemic approach to investigate combinations of social and biological conditions that may act synergistically to increase risk for of CVD in PWH, with a focus on the understudied conditions of mental health, substance use, economic factors, social isolation, stigma/discrimination, trauma history, and healthcare access challenges. Study findings have potential to identify community- and health system-based CVD prevention interventions for vulnerable PWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Projective Narrative  C. difficile infection is the most common nosocomial infection in the US. IL-6 is highly upregulated in patients with severe C. difficile infection (CDI) pathology and in CDI murine models. Our preliminary data suggests that IL-6 has a protective role against CDI disease progression and this work will determine the mechanism by which IL-6 can alter CDI pathology and explore the therapeutic potential of targeting this axis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Glioblastoma is a devastating brain cancer that needs new treatment options because even with chemotherapy, radiation, and surgical resection, tumor recurrence almost always leads to death. Here we propose synergistic combination therapy that relies on optimized elution of chemotherapeutics from a nanofibrous controlled-release scaffold placed in the brain at time of surgery to remove the tumor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gene-environment interactions (GxE) are widespread and contribute to phenotypic variation, environmental response, and adaptation, but we do not understand how genetic differences between individuals cause GxE. My research will use genome sequence, gene expression, and phenotypic data from genetically diverse individuals and a range of real-world environments to understand how GxE occurs at different scales. This research will help us to predict phenotypes across broader ranges of environmental conditions and contribute to a better understanding of how organisms adapt to new or changing environments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Walking-induced claudication afflicts 5% of the US population older than 55 years of age and develops along with hardening of the arteries of the legs. Claudicating patients limp and can walk only very short distances because their leg muscles are damaged, and their legs hurt. Our protocol evaluates a mechanism believed by many to produce leg muscle damage and dysfunction of claudication and its successful completion can confirm this mechanism and yield a new treatment for the care of these patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE While it is clear that early childhood development is a critical time period for development of later health and human capital, there are gaps in understanding the mechanisms underlying human capital development during the childhood years when intervention can make an enormous difference. China's major social, policy, and demographic shifts provide a unique opportunity examine how modifiable factors can be used to reduce adverse effects of such challenges in any context. The objective of the proposed study is to collect an 11th round of CHNS data and identify life-stage-specific exposures that predict health and human capital.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Overall Narrative Kidney cancer is expected to be diagnosed in over 75,000 individuals in the US in 2021 and is particularly prevalent in Texas. Approximately 30% of patients develop metastatic disease, and 5-year survival rates are 12%. To address this unmet medical need, the UT Southwestern Medical Center Kidney Cancer SPORE has developed a comprehensive program to explore and translate therapeutic opportunities with established and new treatment approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: To increase the pathways for URM students to reach graduate biomedical training, Bridges-UAB will initially focus on the transition and initial biomedical education of students into Jefferson State Community College (JSCC) and then the transition to rigorous laboratory research and training at the University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB). Bridges-UAB will offer 10 JSCC students each year the opportunity to pursue biomedical and behavioral research under the tutelage of world-class, funded researchers and educators, so that working in research teams, the students will conduct discovery research that they design in concert with their research mentor, thus advancing their research skills and knowledge of biomedical and behavioral sciences and helping them to decide a direction for their careers. In addition to the research mentors, more senior Bridges-UAB students and graduate students will serve as peer mentors to ensure that Bridges-UAB students have a smooth transition into biomedical courses at JSCC, into successful research at UAB and career success.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most of the over 32.7 million people in the U.S. who have special health, developmental, and mental health concerns have typically developing (TD) brothers and sisters who share high levels of involvement in their sibling’s lives. Disability and health agencies lack effective tools to support the information and support needs of TD siblings and their families, in particular for ethnic minority and rural families. The aims of this proposal are to complete development and evaluation of the dual language SIBTime app, designed to build parents’ and children’s knowledge, skills, and engaging family routines to nurture TD siblings’ (ages 3-6) social-emotional health and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) is characterized by altered metabolic pathways that promote tumor growth but may render the tumors susceptible to metabolic inhibitors. In this Project, we will apply our discoveries of metabolic pathways that promote ccRCC progression and metastasis in patients to test whether inhibiting these pathways with novel metabolic inhibitors suppresses tumor growth in a panel of human-derived ccRCC tumors growing in mice. Further, we will test the impact of these inhibitors on both the tumor cells and immune cells in the tumor microenvironment (TME) in novel syngeneic models of kidney cancer in immunocompetent mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Data Analytics Core will provide biostatistics, bioinformatics, and data management support to all three SPORE projects, the CEP and DRP, as well as to the SPORE Cores. The Core will ensure that the appropriate statistical design is incorporated into all studies from inception, that the data are properly analyzed using the state-of-the-art data methods, and that all results are interpreted on statistical as well as biological significance. The Core also supports the SPORE through a state-of-the-art data management platform.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Aging is a universal cancer risk factor, highlighting the urgent need to identify molecular mechanisms that increase cancer incidence and aggressiveness in the elderly. While the immune system can suppress the growth of a developing tumor, CD8+ T cells are particularly vulnerable to age-related functional decline and surprisingly little is known about the impact of aging on anti-tumor immunity. This study seeks to define causal molecular and metabolic adaptations within T cells in the aging tumor microenvironment that mediate tumor progression, with the goal of revealing new pathways that may be targeted to improve cancer therapy and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Translational Imaging Core (TIC) will offer novel quantitative magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) techniques and Positron Emission Tomography (PET) with a variety of novel radiotracers to SPORE investigators for the noninvasive characterization of renal cell carcinoma in animal models and patients and for the assessment of the response to therapies. A sophisticated radiogenomics platform to co-register MRI and PET/CT images with tumor specimens will allow targeted tissue procurement informed by imaging features detected in vivo. The TIC will provide a web-based centralized archive and image analysis capabilities for all imaging data acquired in SPORE projects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The current design of neurosurgical residencies and changes to training priorities have imposed troublesome restrictions on our ability to foster and retain neurosurgeon-scientists. This proposal describes an innovative program to cultivate and maintain the interest and capability of neurosurgeon-scientists by providing newly formatted opportunities, mentorship, and continuity. Our residency has been specifically redesigned to recruit, train, and propel neurosurgeon-scientists into an NIH-funded academic career.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Medications for opioid use disorder (MOUD) like buprenorphine are currently the most effective form of intervention for opioid use disorder (OUD); however, novel behavioral adjuncts are needed to remediate dysregulation in brain reward systems, enhance MOUD adherence, and prevent relapse. BehaVR, LLC will meet this need by translating an evidence-based biobehavioral treatment approach into an innovative digital therapeutic for OUD that will increase accessibility to services to improve the patient's chances of long-term treatment success.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: ARISE NARRATIVE Mental disorders make an increasingly significant contribution to the burden of disease in African low- and middle-income countries, also increasing risk for a range of other health conditions and injuries, yet health systems are poorly resourced to address the problem. Although investment in mental health research capacity building in Africa has increased in recent years, disparities in these areas remain evident particularly in comparison to the substantial funding underpinning research and research training for infectious and other non- communicable diseases in the region. Thus, there is a need for mental health research capacity building in Africa, led by African public mental health researchers, to drive local research priorities and retain precious human resources on the continent.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Building on long-standing expertise of this lab on TGFβ signaling in development, regeneration and cancer, this project will elucidate how TGFβ regulates epithelial phenotypic plasticity in concert with intra-tumoral fibrosis to promote tumor invasion and metastasis, and how TGFβ stimulates entry of metastasis-initiating into quiescent, immune-evasive states that support their survival as residual disease. This work will increase our understanding of how to target TGFβ in order to suppress metastatic relapse and resistance to therapy. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The translocation of proteins across membranes is a fundamental process involved in the biosynthesis and degradation of a large class of proteins. The medical importance of translocation is demonstrated by the large number of diseases, including cystic fibrosis and α1-antitrypsin deficiency, which result from the misfolding of ER proteins and their subsequent degradation in the cytosol, as well as by peroxisomal disorders, such as Zellweger syndrome. A better understanding of the translocation processes may elucidate the causes of these diseases and result in the development of drugs that allow selective interference.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The Emergence of polymyxin resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae (PRKP) threatens a vital treatment approach for carbapenem resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE) infections. The proposed research will utilize a novel CRISPR- Cas9 system to characterize the genetic determinants of PR in KP and how these genetic changes induce resistance and alter bacterial fitness and virulence. A definitive understanding of how PR develops is necessary in the diagnosis, treatment and prevention of PRKP infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Laboratory and clinical neuroscience have advanced markedly in recent years, and there is now a growing role for clinician-scientists to translate developments in neuroscience into improvement in clinical care. Training young neurologists at a formative stage of their careers in research methods, and encouraging them to consider research as a career, will increase the number of committed, successful clinician-scientists. This proposal for a renewal of the highly successful Columbia University Neurology Resident Research Education Program will provide talented clinical neuroscience residents with the opportunity to develop research skills that have a high likelihood of reducing the burden of neurological disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding how underlying disease mechanisms in overactive bladder contribute to the development of urinary symptoms, including urinary urgency and urgency incontinence, is highly relevant to public health. The proposed, interdisciplinary research that includes experts in Urology, Psychology, and chronic pain research will contribute to the fundamental knowledge of how central sensitization relates to bladder sensitivity and to psychological burdens in people with overactive bladder and how this can be measured effectively. This will allow future studies in which interventions to improve bladder health and incontinence can be implemented and outcomes recorded, with the goal of improving bladder health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genome instability can be detrimental to cellular death, but also advantageous to cancer cells – linked to increased tumor progression, metastasis, immune evasion which leads to overall poor patient prognosis. My previous work demonstrated a novel, interphase-independent role of ATR in promoting faithful chromosome segregation, but much remains unknown of how this occurs. The goal of this proposal is to elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which ATR promotes genome stability by defining its non-canonical role in mitosis and interphase.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Gut bacteria impact aging in ways that can shorten or extend lifespan depending on which bacteria inhabit the gut. The goal of this proposal is to determine mechanisms by which the host gut creates specialized microenvironments that support specific populations of resident bacteria. Our proposal seeks to overcome key limitations of current research, which are the genetic tractability of host and microbes and a well-defined gut niche. The work may reveal mechanisms that can be applied to engineering a healthy human microbiome.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People seek out upper limb rehabilitation services to improve performance of activities in daily life, with performance defined by the World Health Organization ICF model as what someone actually does in the unstructured, free-living environment. Wearable, motion sensors now allow for direct measurement of upper limb performance in daily life, but performance is rarely measured or considered in research and clinical care. The goal of this project is to identify and validate categories of upper limb performance from wearable sensor data that can be used across populations to facilitate rehabilitation research and clinical care measurement of outcomes that are most relevant to patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement NIH has identified “workforce development” as one of its 5 strategic goals for biomedical data science in the coming decades and has called for integrative training in data-science approaches through curricula and mentored research. This proposed R25 program is designed to address the nationwide shortage of Big Data health science researchers in NIAID focus areas. The training program will target junior faculty in health science disciplines at the University of South Carolina and will foster a research environment to encourage individuals from diverse backgrounds, including those from underrepresented groups, to pursue further Big Data health science research in HIV, COVID-19, and other infectious diseases.
