IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Improvements in the surgical and medical care of children with congenital heart disease (CHD) have increased survival. Among survivors, however, there is a high prevalence and significant long-term impact of cognitive and behavioral problems and medical complications including heart failure and problems with growth. The goal of this study is to determine the genetic contributions to clinical outcomes in individuals with CHD and to begin to use this information in clinical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social determinates of health (SDoH) play a significant role in why 1.7 million Americans suffer from opioid use disorders (OUD) and 47,000 American die from opioid overdose. This study will use natural language processing and machine learning to identify SDoH in clinical notes, examine associations between SDoH and OUD, and develop a clinical decision support (CDS) tool to automatically assess OUD risk. Such a CDS tool will help clinicians quickly and accurately assess OUD risk, intervene earlier, and improve care and patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The expansion of the successful SciTrek program to more than twice as many local 2nd‐8th grade classroom will provide more data to demonstrate the effectiveness of the program. Furthermore, this will allow the program to address a fundamental question regarding if the program can influence elementary students’ attitudes towards science, which is suggested to cause girls and under represented minorities to leave the STEM field. Expansion of the program to other institutions and distant schools lacking the appropriate resources has broad significance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We will develop a new class of molecular probes to visualize and control the dynamic signals that regulate all cell and tissue function. Because our tools are modular, our designs will be widely applicable to study diverse physiological processes, as well as their breakdown in disease. Importantly, our probes could in the future be adapted as sensors of several disease states including neurodegeneration and certain cancers, and thus will present powerful opportunities to study and ultimately treat a broad range of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Increasing numbers of patients are seeking genetic counseling and testing to inform medical care and there is an urgent need to test ways to optimize the genetic counseling process to meet this growing demand. We will conduct a 3-arm randomized clinical trial to test two complementary approaches to shifting the primary genetic counseling session to post-test results-focused counseling for adults attending cardiovascular genetic counseling for diagnostic next-generation sequencing panel testing or family-specific variant testing. We hypothesize that post-test genetic counseling will: 1) increase efficiency, 2) promote patient empowerment and adherence, and 3) have similar psychosocial impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Incorporation of isotopically labeled carbon-14 atoms into bioactive compounds is required during all stages of preclinical and clinical drug development. Processes that allow carbon isotope exchange directly on drug candidates are of great importance to chemistry, biology, and medicine. Especially valuable are catalytic procedures that rely on a limited collection of available labeled materials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Correlations among mutations naturally arise and decay along the branches in an ancestral recombination graph (ARG) due to mutation, coalescence, and recombination. Developing novel statistical genetics methods on whole-genome ARGs will lead to faster, better-powered, and more rigorous approaches for studying and understanding the genetics and evolution of complex traits. The proposed methods can be directly applied to study human diseases and enable new discoveries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To proliferate successfully, cells must divide and maintain genome integrity, and aberrations in these processes underlie important human diseases such as cancer. Our studies will define how key enzymes and organelles regulate and perform cytokinetic abscission, the final irreversible step in cell division. This information will provide mechanistic understanding of a fundamental step in cell division, and help to reveal how cells prevent genome instability and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to investigate the significance and mechanisms of the inflammatory cell death pyroptosis and necroptosis as well as their interactions with the cytokine macrophage migration inhibitory factor (MIF) in human monocytes activated by lupus autoantigens and antibodies. The results of the proposal will advance our understanding in the pathogenesis of lupus and provide scientific justifications for targeting pyroptosis, necroptosis, and MIF in lupus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The human papillomaviruses (HPV) are responsible for approximately 5% of all cancers worldwide and most people, including minority populations in the U.S., will remain unvaccinated against HPV for the foreseeable future. We have identified and characterized cellular proteins required for HPV infection, and here we will focus on the role of these proteins in trafficking of HPV to the nucleus during infection. These studies will provide proof-of-principle of new approaches to inhibit infection by these important human tumor viruses and the cancers they cause and provide new insights into fundamental cellular processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The experiments in this proposal are aimed at elucidating the role of stellate cells as a key niche component of the liver HSC niche. The information gained through this project will advance our understanding of the extrinsic mechanisms that regulate HSCs. This may help improve methods of ex vivo expansion of HSCs for clinical use and devise ways to regenerate HSC niche in vivo. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Chickens and other avian species provide a good model for the study of human diseases; however, their use has been greatly limited due to the lack of tools to genetically modify them. We have for the first time established authentic embryonic stem cells from chickens and other avian species. We will use these embryonic stem cells to develop a genetic toolkit for the generation of transgenic avian species for the study of human diseases and for conservation of endangered avian species.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over four million stroke survivors currently living in the United States are unable to walk independently in the community. To increase the effectiveness of gait rehabilitation, it is critical we develop therapies that are based on an understanding of brain adaptations that occur after stroke. This project will be an important step towards the development of a promising therapeutic approach that utilizes brain stimulation and high intensity treadmill training to increase neural drive and walking capacity in stroke survivors and further understand patient- specific responses to prescribe custom walking treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rates of cognitive impairment are disproportionately high among older adults in rural areas compared to those in urban areas. The proposed project examines rural-urban cognitive health disparities and how the social environment influences cognitive function in later life. By increasing our understanding of the social mechanisms contributing to these geographic disparities, this project is intended to identify novel targets for assessment and intervention to reduce the burden of cognitive impairment on individuals, families, and the health care system across rural and urban areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Project Narrative  While heavy alcohol intake causes long-lasting changes in the brain that are likely to contribute to pathological alcohol use and relapse, little is known about how to treat alcohol use disorder by reversing these changes. The studies in this proposal seek to reverse the connectivity between two brain cells recruited by alcohol drinking in animals by strengthening extinction-associated mechanisms to normalize the cell activity and thereby persistently decrease alcohol seeking and relapse. The results will provide new therapeutic approaches to reduce relapse to alcohol use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The project involves the design, synthesis, and evaluation of new antibiotics to treat infections due mycobacterial pathogens, including both Mycobacterium tuberculosis as well as nontuberculous mycobacterial infections, such as Mycobacterium abscessus. These infections are extremely difficult to treat, requiring multidrug regimens that are administered over a lengthy period of time (months to years) often with poor clinical outcomes. We will develop newly discovered potent antimycobacterial agents with the objective of producing an orally bioavailable drug candidate with improved specificity for mycobacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The proposed research is relevant to public health because falls result in significant morbidity, mortality and disability. The current proposal seeks to characterize factors that explain the association between falls and hearing loss. This work addresses the NIDCD’s strategic priority area of improving treatment for hearing and balance problems as the proposed project will identify appropriate targets for intervention to reduce the societal and healthcare burden of falls in individuals with hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune checkpoint blockade therapy has changed the treatment paradigm of lung cancer, a very aggressive cancer with leading cause of cancer-related deaths; however, most patients fail to respond to it, and many of patients who initially respond to treatment eventually experience recurrence. The research strategy proposed herein seeks to develop an innovative method to specifically access circulating exosomes from lung cancer patients via characterizing these disease-associated exosomes to explore molecular signatures associated with therapeutic outcome. The technology developed will help physicians to accurately predict and identify patients who are the responders and non-responders during a course of treatment, as well as identify resistant biomarkers and druggable targets for future therapeutic modalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodegenerative diseases, such as spinal bulbar muscular atrophy (SBMA) and frontotemporal dementia (FTD), are a major burden on patients and their caregivers. These diseases are progressive and lethal, and no treatments exist. This work is significant because we will study how cells normally process the proteins that aberrantly accumulate in SBMA and FTD, potentially revealing new drug targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health as it focuses on understanding the mechanisms controlling the differentiation and function of enteroendocrine (EE) cells, key regulators of appetite regulation and insulin secretion. Completion of this proposal will highlight transcriptional and epigenetic factors that can induce EE hormone production and the mechanism(s) behind EE cell dysregulation in obesity and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), allowing for identification of new targets for therapeutics to improve appetite control and insulin secretion. Thus, this research has the potential to improve the health of millions of people with obesity and T2DM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social cognitive impairments are highly prominent in psychotic disorders and have been linked to social and functional outcomes beyond the impact of other illness-related factors (i.e., psychiatric symptoms, nonsocial cognition), yet available treatments for social and social cognitive dysfunction are limited in their effectiveness. Despite recognition as an area of clinical relevance and unmet need, the brain-behavior mechanisms that give rise to social cognitive impairment in psychosis remain poorly characterized, thus limiting our attempts to target primary sources of observed dysfunction. The proposed study will examine the neural bases of mentalizing, a key social cognitive process in psychosis, and its association with clinical and real-world functioning in a transdiagnostic sample of young adults with first-episode psychosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, continues to cause widespread infections associated with unacceptably high mortality. We will use previously collected samples from healthy volunteers inoculated with SARS-CoV-2 in a human challenge study to identify microbes and host immune responses in the upper respiratory tract that modify susceptibility to and symptoms of SARS-CoV-2 infection. These analyses could lead to development of new vaccines or therapies to prevent or treat SARS-CoV-2 infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance abuse is associated with significant individual and social burden. We will leverage two exemplary existing data sources containing both CW (child welfare) and community youth to accelerate knowledge regarding the most important risk factors of early substance use and evaluate the feasibility of translation of the predictive models into a risk score for clinical decision making. This approach, if implemented in clinical care settings, would allow medical providers to more accurately identify those at risk and trigger stratification into different treatment pathways to prevent substance abuse.

PHR: The research plan is relevant to public health because it explores a novel pathway that forms an endogenous reactive molecule that acutely attenuates inflammation and could promote immune tolerance. Understanding this pathway could open new therapeutic avenues for limiting auto-immune diseases, attenuating transplant rejection and treating chronic inflammation. Thus, this proposal is significant to the NIH mission in that it seeks to apply fundamental knowledge to enhance health, lengthen life, and reduce illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  We wish to understand why people who gain excess weight in the abdomen are more prone to diabetes and high blood fats. The fat tissue under the skin in the abdominal area releases excess fat into the bloodstream, which effects how the rest of our body can metabolize sugars. We are proposing experiments that will measure whether fat cells in leg and abdominal fat are regulated differently in people with excess abdominal fat, and whether this is due to altered functions of certain proteins inside the fat cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 193,000 Latino immigrants without green cards in California recently avoided Medicaid enrollment, despite the Biden administration’s reversal of the immigration public charge rule definition in 2021 and their eligibility for Medicaid in the state, likely because of fears about their citizenship and immigration statuses. This study will use three different but complementary sources of qualitative and quantitative data to study mis- and disinformation among Latinos regarding immigration policies, including their relationships with chilling effects in Medicaid enrollment and health care access and utilization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In response to the tobacco industry’s campaign about the exacerbation of police brutality to African Americans, scientists are calling for communication research that addresses the industry’s disinformation and corrects misperceptions about menthol cigarettes and flavored cigars. Our proposed study will develop a multi-level anti- disinformation message (ADM) campaign using a health equity lens. We will provide evidence of the effectiveness of the ADM campaign messages on flavor ban receptivity and tobacco industry beliefs among African Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Increasing energy expenditure is a promising strategy for treating obesity and metabolic diseases; however, a compensatory increase in food intake could dampen its benefits. We will use cold and thermogenesis-induced feeding in rodents as a model to investigate the neural mechanisms underlying the compensatory energy intake. This project aims to provide insight into how to effectively modulate energy homeostasis at the whole organismal level to battle metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is relevant to public health because Marfan syndrome (MFS), a disease of accelerated aging, and cerebrovascular aging are risk factors for cerebrovascular disease and potentially an increased risk for vascular cognitive impairment and dementia. The proposed experiments will be the first to measure the influence of an MFS-associated fibrillin-1 mutation’s accompanying signaling cascades on cerebrovascular pathology, neuropathology, neurotransmission, and neurobehavioral alterations and evaluate sex as a biological variable. Knowledge gained will improve mechanistic understanding behind cerebrovascular aging associated with neurological alterations and potentially provide novel therapeutic targets to attenuate the impact of aging on brain function, where biological sex differences would promote the need for personalized medicine based on sex.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Human stem cell-derived neurons show immature properties characteristic of fetal rather than adult nervous system cells, which limits their use for applications in modeling human disease or in regenerative medicine. Here, we will study the molecular factors that control the pace of human neuronal maturation, establish novel assays to precisely measure maturation in a dish and develop strategies that accelerate the maturation process. This project addresses a major bottleneck in human stem biology and should result in better tools to study neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative disorders in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Characterization of the transcriptional co-activator Yes-Associated Protein (YAP) and its paralog WW-domain containing Transcriptional co-Activator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ), two central effectors of the Hippo pathway, as downstream points of convergence in the signaling cascade initiated by anti-donor HLA antibodies (Ab) will permit us to establish mechanisms underlying how HLA Ab promote endothelial cell (EC) growth contributing to chronic antibody-mediated rejection (cAMR). We will also determine if FDA-approved drugs of the statin family inhibit YAP function in HLA Ab-activated ECs providing evidence that drugs of the statin family can be an important element in preventing cAMR via blocking growth-promoting YAP/TAZ signaling in ECs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative This K01 Mentored Research Scientist Development Award will partner with a Community Advisory Board to develop and pilot a community-based, theory-guided mental health literacy intervention for Black/African American young adults. Post-study focus groups with intervention participants will be held to elicit feedback on relevance, feasibility, acceptability, and satisfaction with the intervention to inform refinement and future dissemination efforts. The potential public health impact is large, as Black/African American young adults have low likelihood of engaging in mental health treatment despite elevated risk for exposure to trauma, subsequent mental health concerns (e.g., PTSD, substance use), and poor outcomes from untreated mental health conditions—particularly given the myriad psychological and emotional impacts of the Covid-19 pandemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE There are a wide array of negative outcomes associated with sleep disturbance (in general) and insomnia (in specific) including fatigue, cognitive impairment, mood disturbance, impaired daytime function, and diminished quality of life. Beyond these regular daytime effects, sleep disturbance substantially increases the risk for depression, substance abuse, hypertension cardiovascular disease, glucose homeostasis dysregulation, immuno-suppression, overall increased health care utilization, and possibly increased mortality. These associations clearly suggest that there is an urgent need to better characterize sleep disorders symptoms in terms of how they develop and how are expressed over time, both in general, and specifically in the most vulnerable of populations: older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: It is increasingly appreciated that multicellular interactions between the peripheral nervous system and immune cells drive the pathogenesis of chronic inflammatory diseases, and that understanding these interactions represents a major milestone toward developing effective treatments for these highly prevalent and debilitating disorders. The goal of this proposal is to determine how peripheral sensory neurons influence the pathogenesis of inflammatory diseases of the skin and visceral organs. This research will provide a basic understanding into the role of neuroimmune crosstalk in inflammation and inform the development of novel therapeutics for chronic inflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Human blood eosinophil (EOS) counts correlate with left ventricle mass and ventricular wall and interventricular septum thickness. Our recent published work suggests a cardioprotective role for EOS in pressure overload-induced cardiac hypertrophy and heart failure by releasing type-2 cytokines and cationic proteins. This plan is proposed to study the role of EOS cationic proteins in protecting cardiomyocytes and cardiac fibroblasts from pressure overload-induced cardiac hypertrophy and heart failure using different sets of bone morphogenetic protein receptors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This study investigates a new source of innate lymphoid cells (ILCs) that are known to modulate immune reactions. We have shown that ILCs can be made not only in the bone marrow but also in the thymus, which may generate ILCs with different functionality. Because only children have an active thymus, the ILCs they produce may help explain the different immune reactions between children and adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Aging is a complex issue that must not be viewed from a single lens. Older adults have the most to lose when the expertise of scientists from diverse backgrounds is absent and the most to gain from an approach that brings all perspectives to bear. The RCMAR National Coordinating Center addresses this issue by developing tools to support new researchers from diverse backgrounds and supporting a network of researchers in making scientific discoveries that eliminate health disparities and improve the health and well-being of older adults.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Much of the human head is formed from neural crest cells and abnormalities during neural crest cell development can lead to congenital craniofacial and neurological defects and cancers including melanoma. Preliminary data suggests that the precise location of RNAs within individual neural crest cells or their derivatives can affect behavior of the cell. This project will elucidate the fundamental principles regulating the location and function of these RNAs within cells, and causally link RNA localization to developmental and cancer-related outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Changes in the gut microbiota have been associated with many diseases, but causal inference is often lacking. Preclinical and clinical studies have demonstrated that the intestinal microbiota can regulate innate and adaptive immunity, including T cell and antitumor immunity after allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation and checkpoint blockade. The goal of our research is to target the intestinal microbiota to improve cancer immunotherapy, which has tremendous potential to improve the lives of patients being treated for cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reciprocal connections between the ventral tegmental area (VTA), a midbrain nucleus, and the hippocampus (CA1) form a loop that governs novelty and discrimination between contexts based on their relevance. Although the VTA contains several neuron types that innervate the hippocampus, the functions of the VTA in the loop have been primarily attributed to its dopamine neurons. The traditional focus on the dopamine pathway significantly limits our understanding of the anatomically dominant VTA glutamate projections in the hippocampus. Thus, the proposed project will use a multi-method approach to dissect the role of the VTA glutamate-CA1 tract in hippocampal encoding and expression of novelty-dependent behaviors.

PHR: Project Narrative  Reducing and preventing child bullying and victimization has become a national priority for improving safety in schools and the health and educational outcomes for children. The proposed project seeks to complete the adaption of the current 40-hour in-person radKIDS® instructor training (begun in Phase I) into a blended, multimedia in-person/online format to promote child safety from victimization and test the effectiveness of the program with a diverse school-based sample in a clustered randomized trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Studying the activity of chromatin-associating proteins (CAPs) is central to understanding the regulatory mechanisms that control gene expression. However, existing assays to study CAPs either require expensive sequencing and complex data analysis or do not specifically capture chromatin-bound CAPs. Here, EpiCypher is developing a novel, sequencing-free assay that will make accessible the study of global in vivo activity of CAPs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Brains demand significant amounts of glucose as a means to maintain neural function, and while a decline in this usage is a hallmark of both aging and Alzheimer’s disease, it is not possible to discern whether this decrease directly impairs neuronal communication in vivo with current techniques. This proposal presents a novel system for monitoring and manipulating glucose metabolism at a single cell resolution such that impacts of different metabolic states can be directly related to changes in neuronal function. This fundamental work is expected to provide a molecular mechanism for age-related neuronal decline as derived from cellular metabolic context.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Narrative  Adhering to a Mediterranean dietary pattern can reduce the risk of type 2 diabetes (T2D) and cardiovascular disease (CVD); yet there is scant evidence of this benefit in non-Mediterranean populations for which this diet may not be familiar or accessible, as well of trials examining the mechanisms that contribute to these cardiometabolic improvements. PROMED is a randomized clinical trial among adults in Puerto Rico that will test the efficacy of a culturally-tailored intervention using traditional foods vs. a standard healthy eating program in improving cardiometabolic risk factors in 2yr, and assess if these effects are mediated by metabolite changes, psychosocial factors, or food security and access. PROMED is expected to generate evidence on posited mechanisms of action of a healthy diet and to shift the paradigm from recommending generalized diets to adapting guidance according to the biological, psychosocial, and social needs of diverse populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children living in adversity and poverty are at much higher risk for poor socio-emotional outcomes and later psychopathology; yet, interventions that can improve developmental trajectories by enhancing nurturing caregiving early in development are often unavailable in communities in need. Educational settings offer a promising solution to increase access to innovative parent-child preventive interventions. It is expected that this test of THRIVE will have public health impact by informing best practices related to enhancing the emotional development of at-risk young children to prevent later emotional and behavioral disturbances

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The improvement of long-term outcomes for patients with treatment-refractory acute myeloid leukemia (AML) represents one of the highest unmet need for cancer therapy in general. Based on the initial preclinical and clinical studies, we propose to combine new image-guided AML radiotherapy, which spares normal organs, with a novel oligonucleotide-based immunotherapeutic agent, CpG-STAT3 inhibitor, to stimulate patients’ own immune responses against leukemia. The overarching goal is to develop a paradigm-shifting, effective and safer combinatorial treatment for relapsed and recurrent AML patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the prevalence and disability attributable to Parkinson’s disease (PD), we still do not have an integrated understanding of how brain circuits go awry and cause symptoms in PD. The goal of this proposal is to develop a more comprehensive understanding of motor network dysfunction by recording signals from multiple areas of the brains of patients with PD undergoing deep brain stimulation (DBS) implantation surgery. The knowledge gained will provide a critical framework for the development of novel therapies, contribute to improvements in surgical targeting and techniques, and potentially be used for the design of closed-loop DBS systems, all of which can lead to improving the quality of life of PD patients, improving the efficacy of therapies, and reducing health care expenditures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The proposed study of paradoxical lucidity is very early stage; refinement of definition, development of a staff-report measure using qualitative and quantitative methods and prevalence estimation are important steps in understanding the phenomenon. Such findings will likely both provide useful tools and inform future basic and intervention research. The study will result in the development of a case-reporting method for use by front-line staff to identify episodes of lucidity, with the potential of involving family and staff caregivers as witnesses who may provide comfort to patients prior to death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  With the goal of emergency preparedness, the NIAID is seeking drugs to prevent acute tissue damage and chronic pathologies resulting from accidental or terroristic exposure to ionizing radiation. The first-in-class, clinical-stage sphingosine kinase-2 inhibitor opaganib has anticancer and anti-inflammatory activity in many animal models, including Gastrointestinal Acute Radiation Syndrome in mice. The present studies will provide critical pharmacologic and mechanistic information needed for approval of opaganib as a medical countermeasure to protect people against radiation poisoning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative GSK3E functions as essential negative regulator of E-catenin-signaling, which represents a central oncogenic driver throughout most types of cancer. In striking contrast to other cancer-types, we found that B-cell malignancies are not only exempt from activating E-catenin lesions but highly sensitive to E-catenin nuclear accumulation and critically depend on its negative regulation by GSK3E-mediated degradation. To establish a conceptual framework for GSK3E as novel drug-target in refractory B-lymphoid malignancies, we propose two Aims to (1) elucidate the mechanistic basis of E-catenin-mediated tumor suppression and to (2) develop concepts to leverage GSK3E small molecule inhibitors for therapeutic intervention to overcome drug-resistance in refractory B-cell malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular pathogen that infects almost all warm-blooded animals and causes severe diseases in fetuses and immunocompromised individuals, such as AIDS patients. I will focus on Toxoplasma secretory effectors and determine the mechanism by which these effectors modulate the innate immune response in rat and human macrophages. This will help to uncover novel anti-Toxoplasma mechanisms from a host-pathogen interaction point of view and has the potential to provide the field with new drug targets against toxoplasmosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: SUMMARY Despite the promise of the immune checkpoint inhibitors, the outcomes with recently approved immunotherapies remain poor in many cancers. Less than 20% of patients treated with immune checkpoint inhibitors show durable response. This proposal studies a novel mechanism of immune evasion by nanotube-mediated mitochondria harvesting from immune cells by cancer cells, and will develop novel exocyst inhibitors that can overcome this barrier that limits immune checkpoint inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP), which involves the gain of mutations in blood stem cells, is common in older individuals and is linked to increased risk for blood cancers and cardiovascular disease. Genes commonly mutated in CHIP include genes known to regulate epigenetic changes to DNA and splicing of RNA. We will use genome-wide epigenetic and RNA expression data collected from tens of thousands of individuals to investigate whether epigenetic and gene expression patterns differ in individuals with CHIP, and whether this may contribute to their increased risk for cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project will have direct and immediate relevance for public health. Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a major cause of dementia in the elderly and an enormous health problem. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative BMCs play important roles in various physiological contexts, such as transcription, stress response, and in pathophysiological conditions, including cancer, viral infections, and neurodegenerative diseases, and may thus represent a hallmark of HIV/SIV disease. In this proposal, we aim to optimize a novel tool for the isolation and retrieval of in vivo generated BMCs, including blood plasma, CSF, saliva, and intestinal contents from rhesus macaques, then investigate how chronic administration of delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) to SIV-infected rhesus macaques affects the composition and function of BMCs. The outcome of these studies will provide illuminating initial example of BMCs as central organizers of biochemistry in vivo, and minimally, the product of this proposal will be an outstanding experimental resource and data sets that will facilitate studies of BMCs in vivo and in the setting of HIV/SIV and THC use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Regenerative medicine and cell therapy hold great promise to treat disease. We propose to try to help amputees who use prosthetics but find them painful or the cause of skin problems at the stump site. To do so, we will purify and expand cells from a native palm and sole and inject them into the stump site to hopefully give the stump some of the properties of normal palms and soles such as resilient skin that is pressure adaptive.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Recovery of function after nerve damage, which is a very common affliction, involves a regenerative process in which damaged axons within the nerve bundle must regrow back to their target tissues. Regeneration often fails, resulting in chronic pain and functional deficits for many patients, and therapeutic improvements are currently limited by our poor understanding of how this process is controlled. This project will use the zebrafish vagus nerve as a model to identify mechanisms that guide regrowing axons back to their target tissues during regeneration, thereby providing fundamental insights that will inform development of improved therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The formation of reactive oxygen and nitrogen species (ROS and RNS), such as hydrogen peroxide and nitric oxide, have been implicated in the demise of β-cells during diabetes development. However, we have demonstrated (1) that β-cells maintain a robust antioxidant defense system that allows them to detoxify ROS and RNS, and (2) that interleukin-1β and nitric oxide may play a protective role in β-cells. The broad goals of these studies are to identify mechanisms of β-cell protection from environmental challenges so we can better understand how β-cells fail during the pathogenesis of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The project seeks to gain a quantitative understanding of how human stem cell organoids, which have been validated against fetal tissue using single cell and in situ sequencing, respond to and process signals to axially elongate, and how the stem cells in the elongating tailbud are maintained to sustain this elongation. To achieve this goal, the reproducible embryonic stem cell organoid system will be studied using a combination of microscopy, single cell sequencing, statistical inference, mathematical modeling, and molecular biology. In the longer term, a quantitative understanding of how the embryo sustains axial elongation will help better understand the mechanisms of developmental defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in calcium channels and proteins involved in decoding calcium signals have been strongly associated with a variety of psychiatric disorders, including autism spectrum disorders and schizophrenia. The research described in this proposal aims to obtain a mechanistic understanding of the processes by which calcium signals influence immature neural progenitor cells to commit to specific identities in the developing brain. The results of our studies will have significant translational potential, providing insights into common pathways underlying psychiatric disease and revealing potentially novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Sarcopenia, the age-related decline in skeletal muscle mass and force, is a significant public health challenge due to its key role in the development of physical frailty and loss of independence in the elderly population. While degeneration of the structure of the synapses between motor neurons and muscle fibers and a resultant loss of innervation is widely accepted as a major contributor to sarcopenia, a lack of mechanistic understanding of the causes of these degenerative changes during aging represents a critical barrier to the development of effective and widely applicable interventions to mitigate the devastating effects of muscle loss and improve quality of life for elderly individuals. This research will clarify the role of changes in the expression of the protein Lamin A/C in a specific population of muscle fiber nuclei as important mediator of the recovery of innervation following denervation to identify potential therapeutic targets for preserving muscle during aging.

PHR: In this project, we propose using the personalized nutrition framework to test the effect of a brain healthy diet and omics signatures of a brain healthy diet on the brain of participants in the Framingham Heart Study. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many patients with Alzheimer’s disease (AD) have an increased risk of developing epilepsy, and over 40% of AD patients without a history of epilepsy exhibit subclinical epileptiform activity. Increased expression of the voltage-gated sodium channel SCN8A has been observed in brains from AD patients and mouse models of AD, and we speculate that increased Nav1.6 activity in AD contributes to multiple clinically challenging features of AD, including epileptiform discharges, cognitive impairment, and AD neuropathology. We will use genetic, behavioral, and electrophysiological, approaches to establish the beneficial effects of selectively reducing SCN8A expression in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of the Neurofibromatosis (NF) and Schwannomatosis (SWN) Genes Variant Curation Expert Panel (VCEP) is to develop, apply, and disseminate disease-specific curation guidelines for genes associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), Legius syndrome (LS), and schwannomatosis (SWN), including NF2-related schwannomatosis (NF2-SWN, formerly known as neurofibromatosis type 2) and non-NF2-related schwannomatosis (non-NF2-SWN). The team will publish a series of manuscripts describing the ClinGen- endorsed specific guidelines for interpreting germline variants in NF1, NF2, SMARCB1, LZTR1, and SPRED1. This information will standardize the assignment of pathogenicity across academic and commercial labs, will improve the diagnosis clinical management of patients by clarifying the interpretation of both intronic and missense variants, and will increase the number of curated variants deposited in ClinVar. page 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Clostridioides difficile is the most common cause of nosocomial antibiotic-associated diarrhea and the etiologic agent of life-threatening pseudomembranous colitis in the developed world, and is classified as ‘urgent threat’ by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). We propose to develop multivalent mucosal /parenteral vaccines against C. difficile infection (CDI).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: In up to 3% of the population, the mitral valve, which allows the heart to pump blood forward to the body while preventing it from going backwards, becomes floppy and billows backwards when the heart contracts. One- third of patients with such floppy valves have abnormal cardiac beats that increase their risk for sudden cardiac death, and those complications are associated with scarring of the heart muscle in the region to which the valve is attached, with the mechanism of such scarring currently unknown and studies limited by lack of a disease model. Based on patient and experimental data and a novel model in which creating mitral valve prolapse causes localized scarring in previously normal hearts, we aim to discover how this scarring occurs and its relation to the stress induced by the valve on the wall of the heart, leading to new ways to preserve healthy heart muscle and prevent sudden cardiac death in this condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) affects two million Americans every year and can cause pulmonary embolism (PE), which is fatal in ~10% of acute cases, with higher rates in patients with cancer. Current DVT treatment techniques include systemic administration of thrombolytic drugs and endovascular catheter-based thrombectomy, which is either slow and/or carries risk of vessel damage. Our renewal proposal will develop an integrated dual-frequency catheter-accelerated sonothrombolysis system (iDUCAS), which can quickly and safely treat even the most advanced and heterogeneous clots and reduce the occurrence of complications, morbidity, and mortality of DVT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC) is a rare, aggressive skin cancer highly responsive to immune checkpoint blockade, suggesting a strong antitumor immune response. However, the immune cells contributing to antitumor activity in the tumor microenvironment of MCC are not well understood. This proposal will investigate whether tumor- infiltrating B cells, which have recently shown robust antitumor activity in several different cancer types, have antitumor activity in MCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE KRAS-driven non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) remains one of the most aggressive and lethal solid tumors. Therapeutic options and outcomes for NSCLC have remained virtually unchanged over the past thirty years. Using novel CRISPR/Cas9-based genome-engineering technologies we have established a unique and rapid research program to functionally characterize lung cancer mutations and identify genotype-specific metabolic vulnerabilities that can lead to novel therapeutic approaches in KRAS-driven lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Moyamoya disease (MMD) is a severe cerebrovascular condition with unknown cause and confers a high risk of stroke; although historically observed in individuals of East Asian ancestry, MMD is now being reported with increasing frequency in North America over a broader range of races and ethnicities. Stroke risk can be reduced when surgical revascularization procedures are performed, however, surgical response and disease trajectory can be highly variable, especially in the increasingly recognized North American phenotype. This work is focused on using novel neuroimaging methods, in combination with assessments of traditional stroke risk factors, at two of the largest MMD treatment centers to identify personalized signatures of brain tissue health that can be used to portend stroke risk, with the long-term goal of using this information to triage patients for appropriate and personalized surgical revascularization procedures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Adoptive transfer of T cells that can recognize tumors and cause tumor cell death is a promising approach and has gained momentum after it was found that novel anti-tumor T cells could be engineered by viral transductions of tumor reactive T cell receptor (TCR), or chimeric antigen receptors (CAR). However, many confounding factors such as susceptibility to immunosuppression, or T cell's inability to persist and undergo activation induced cell death due to chronic antigen stimulation in a tumor microenvironment still persist. In this application, we propose to generate metabolically enhanced CD19-CAR-Ts based on our published methodology in Cell Metabolism and establish the issues of efficacy and toxicity in the phase 1B trial of this approach where targeting immunometabolism to program CAR-Ts could be used in future trials to treat a large umbrella of non-Hodgkin Lymphoma patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of the proposed research project is to design a new type of orally administered particle system capable of delivering DNA to the intestines for use as a gene therapy (e.g., to treat inflammatory bowel diseases) or a vaccine. These particles will be made using vesicles produced by non-pathogenic bacteria found in a healthy gut. The proposed delivery platform could improve DNA delivery to bring orally delivered, DNA-based medicines to the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Infantile hemangioma, a benign vascular tumor that occurs in 4-5% of children, is treated with propranolol, yet why and how propranolol is effective has remained a mystery. We have new data that uncovers a novel, unexpected mechanism downstream of propranolol that involves cholesterol metabolism. In this proposal we will deeply study how propranolol and statins reduce vascular overgrowth in infantile hemangioma with the goal of improving treatment options for infantile hemangioma, and potentially other diseases where vascular overgrowth occurs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative In the early stages of Alzheimer’s disease (AD), entorhinal cortex connections with hippocampal CA1 emerges as a primary neural circuit that undergoes significant neurodegenerative change, but the cell type specific connections and their susceptibility remains unclear. Here, we will use advanced viral labeling strategies in an AD mouse model to identify vulnerable CA1 projection cell types and characterize their morphological neurodegenerative changes to AD. After identifying CA1 structural vulnerabilities, we will use MERFISH spatial transcriptomics to investigate the changes to AD-relevant gene expression within these vulnerable neurons and characterize the molecular changes that are associated with AD neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative The proposed research is designed to understand the neuronal circuits that control posture (standing) after spinal cord injury. We use novel transgenic, electrophysiological and rehabilitation methods to target propriospinal neurons that promote motor function after injury. Once successfully developed in our animal preparations, these methods can be adapted to human subjects with spinal cord injury, allowing the possibility of new therapies for recovery of function after spinal cord injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The aim of this study is to develop an efficient and sensitive system for delivering and detecting multiple molecules, with the objective of understanding the roles of extracellular vesicles in cellular processes and facilitating their widespread use in research and therapy. The proposed system will simplify the labor-intensive and challenging procedures involved in vesicular loading and cargo quantification by integrating a high-throughput particle manipulation technique, physical molecular delivery mechanism, and single-molecule detection technique into a user-friendly device. By providing ease of operation and a streamlined workflow, this approach will offer a systematic and standardized method for manipulating, characterizing, and classifying extracellular vesicles based on their origins, properties, and functions.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed work aims to establish the Humanity Unlocking Biomaterials (HUB), a coordinating center that addresses the disconnectedness among biomaterials researchers and emerging disciplines, such as computational modeling and artificial intelligence, to unlock the full potential of biomaterials-based technologies. By creating a diverse community, providing accessible resources and funding opportunities, and fostering cross- disciplinary collaboration, the HUB seeks to revolutionize biomaterials translation and produce innovative technologies for biomedical applications. The HUB aims to significantly improve human health and save lives impacted by various diseases through this initiative.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: FEDERATION OF AMER SOC FOR EXPER BIOLOGY
PHR: NARRATIVE Ion channels have a critical role in all cell types and organs but our understanding of their function in the immune system and their role in physiological and pathological immune responses is in its nascent stages. This proposal requests funds to support the first FASEB Science Research Conference (SRC) on the topic of "Channels and Transporters in Immunity" from 14–20th June 2024. The overall goal of this SRC is to establish a recurring venue where immunologists, physiologists, and translational scientists can interact, discuss and collaborate in this burgeoning area of research, advance new therapeutic strategies and enhance the career-development of trainees and junior faculty, especially those from underepresented minorities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal intends to study the role of microRNAs (miRs) contained in the exosomes of Natural Killer (NK) cells in the cytotoxic activity of these vesicles against neuroblastoma (NB) and in their ability to synergize with chemoimmunotherapy. The study will identify the mechanism through which aNK-derived exosomal miRs elicit a cytotoxic effect on NB cells, will explore this mechanism to increase efficacy of current chemoimmunotherapy for the treatment of NB, and will correlate circulating and exosomal miRs to response to chemoimmunotherapy. The results of this study will help identify new strategies to treat NB (and possibly other types of cancer) and will ultimately lead to increased number of saved lives of cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Emergency medical services (EMS) serve as an important entry point in the United States’(U.S.) healthcare system, especially for Hispanic older adults who have challenges accessing preventive and diagnostic care, and who rely on emergency services to meet their healthcare needs. The goal of this dissertation is to advance our understanding of the individual, neighborhood, and structural-level factors that impact the provision of EMS to Hispanic older adults in the prehospital setting. The study findings can inform efforts to make EMS more accessible, age-friendly, and equitable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Excessive drinking is a significant public health problem that is intricately linked to stress. Although the stress response is a dynamic and widespread brain process, whether these unfolding changes help identify risky drinkers and explain changes in drinking-related cognition remains unclear. The proposed research integrates concurrent functional neuroimaging, neuroendocrine assays, cognitive tasks, and real-world monitoring together with the development of validated stress-predictive brain networks and novel dynamic algorithms to elucidate where, when, and how brain stress trajectories can be used to predict drinking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brain malformations are a diverse group of disorders that can cause epilepsy, intellectual disability, and other neurodevelopmental impacts, with substantial impact on patients, families, and the health care system. To date, variants in hundreds of different genes have been reported to cause brain malformations, sometimes present in all cells of the brain and sometimes only in a subset (somatic mosaicism). This project brings together a multidisciplinary team of experts to curate the growing body of genetic data (genes and specific variants) related to brain malformations, to help clinicians select appropriate genes for testing and interpret results, in route to establishing a diagnosis and informing care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: The heart pumps blood into the systemic system by contracting cardiac muscle during systole, which is initiated by a rise in intracellular calcium concentration that triggers sliding of the thick and thin filaments in the muscle sarcomere. Myosin is the molecular motor that uses the energy from ATP hydrolysis to drive filament sliding and mutations in myosin can lead to dilated cardiomyopathy, a common form of heart failure that disrupts systolic contraction. This proposal will investigate the impact of dilated cardiomyopathy mutations on several aspects of human beta-cardiac myosin structure and function, including the regulatory mechanism, structural mechanism of force generation, and ability to drive filament sliding in a calcium dependent manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a devastating neurodegenerative disorder affecting millions of elderly Americans but without a curative therapy, necessitating early detection for timely treatment before frank neurodegeneration occurs. The current proposal aims to examine subtle changes in language production in the earliest stages of AD progression by investigating the cognitive mechanisms underlying autocorrection, a type of speech error that is sensitive to AD biomarkers. The proposed studies will provide valuable insights into language impairments in cognitively healthy individuals at risk for AD, and will facilitate the development of simple, noninvasive, and low-cost diagnostic tools for preclinical AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Coronary artery disease, which can ultimately cause ischemia and myocardial infarction, accounts for 1 in 6 deaths in the U.S., or nearly 400,000 deaths per year, and is the leading cause of heart failure, for which there is no cure. Clinically, the current optimal therapy is reperfusion to restore blood flow to the heart, but reperfusion itself contributes to the irreversible loss of functional myocardium. Our proposed studies address a new molecular mechanism that could decrease this damage, and has not been targeted by any therapeutics to date, supporting the significance of investigating it with the ultimate objective of developing novel treatments for decreasing heart damage and preventing heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE One of the ways that osteocytes, cells embedded within bone, support skeletal health is by maintaining bone quality. An improved understanding of how osteocytes respond to stimuli, like exercise, to support bone quality will improve the success of clinical efforts to prevent bone fragility in aging or disease. Here we test the hypothesis that exercise directs changes in bone quality by modulating osteocyte cellular metabolism and remodeling of the matrix surrounding the osteocyte.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS RIO GRANDE VALLEY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with severe Hemophilia A (HA) experience frequent bleeding—often spontaneously—because they inherit an X-chromosome from their mother that has a mutation in the gene which makes a critical blood clotting protein called factor VIII (FVIII). As a result, they don’t make any (or only very little) of this essential blood clotting protein. Thus, bleeding in severe HA-patients (HAPs) is currently prevented by regular infusions of a therapeutic (t) FVIII protein (tFVIII) product. Unfortunately, ~30% of all severe HAPs develop antibodies called “FVIII inhibitors (FEIs)”, which neutralize tFVIIIs and greatly increase morbidity and mortality. FEIs develop in ~40-45% of severe HAPs with Mexican ancestry (MA) but in only ~20-25% of those with European ancestry. This research, which we refer to as the “Trans-omics for FVIII Inhibitor Causation (TRAFFIC)” study, seeks to identify genetic and environmental variables that underlie the high incidence of FEIs in HAPs with MA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project uses advanced methods in neuroimaging and machine learning to test whether individuals with overweight or obesity and high craving can learn to modulate their brain response to food cues using neurofeedback, to impact their craving and eating behavior. This project will improve our understanding of food cue-reactivity and craving and will inform a larger planned trial to study the effects of this approach on overweight and obesity treatment outcomes. Helping individuals with overweight and obesity learn skills to cope with craving to potentially improve their health could have a significant impact on reducing disease burden and improving public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Obtaining high quality pediatric brain MRIs with gadolinium (Gd) injection takes long (20+ minutes) time, and often necessitates sedation or anesthesia, which hinders normal brain development and poses increased risk for cognitive and behavioral problems later in life. We propose synergistic data acquisition, image reconstruction and deep learning enhancement strategies that improve pediatric brain imaging by enabling at most 5-fold reduction in Gd injection dosage and 3-fold acceleration of the typical pediatric brain MRI protocol. We aim to develop, validate and translate this imaging technology in clinical settings, thus enabling faster and safer pediatric brain exams with the potential to completely obviate the need for sedation or anesthesia and significantly reduce the dosage of Gd injections given during an MRI exam.

ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this research project, we will test whether inhibiting the sphingosine-1-phosphate pathway at either the point of synthesis (sphingosine kinase 2) or transport (Spns2) is useful in slowing the progression of kidney fibrosis, which is an important component of chronic kidney disease pathology. To date, there are no effective medicines to stop, or even slow, the fibrotic process. The goal of this program is to validate SphK2 and Spns2 inhibitors as experimental anti-renal fibrosis agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proper function of several vital organs in humans requires the activity of cilia and defects in ciliary assembly and motility are responsible for a wide variety of life-threatening genetic disorders, such as chronic respiratory disease, congenital heart disease, brain developmental defects, and primary ciliary dyskinesia. Using innovative methods, our work addresses fundamental questions about how the activity of dynein motors is regulated and coordinated to give rise to the normal movement of cilia. We expect that this research will provide new insights into the underlying mechanisms of ciliary-linked disorders (ciliopathies) in humans, which is a prerequisite to the development of therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Understanding how hormones are regulated is crucial for advancing the treatment of endocrine diseases. Many hormones are released in pulses, rather than continuously, but reproducing this pulsatile environment in the lab is challenging. This project will develop a microfluidic platform that can mimic the natural pulsatile secretion of hormones, allowing scientists to study their regulation and develop new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP) is the leading cause of death in patients with refractory epilepsy and is two to four times as common as sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS). Inhibition of serotonin neurons by seizures may impair the body’s ability to regulate breathing, autonomic function, and arousal during a vulnerable period. The proposed research is relevant to public health and the NIH’s mission because a better understanding of how inhibition of CO2 chemoreception by seizures causes respiratory depression, autonomic dysfunction, and impaired arousal is expected to lead to the identification of novel candidate biomarkers for SUDEP risk and to the development of new preventive treatments for SUDEP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Different kinds of cells in the body express different genes from the genome, because they not only express different gene regulating proteins (transcription factors), but also pack the genes in their nuclei in different ways that make certain genes easier or harder for the regulatory proteins to reach. It is still poorly understood how to predict how the regulatory proteins distribute their influence among different genes, and how to predict when these regulatory proteins will prevail in reaching a particular target gene. This proposal is to shed light on the underlying rules needed to determine these predictions, focusing on cells in early stages of becoming immune- system T cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  High doses of intensive rehabilitation therapy can reduce disability after stroke, but most people do not receive this for reasons that include limited access and low motivation. We have found that a 6-week course of intensive home-based telerehabilitation focused on arm movement after stroke improves arm function and reduces overall disability. The currently proposed clinical trial will definitively establish the value of this treatment approach, evaluate an imaging-based measure of stroke injury that is useful for anticipating individual benefits from intensive rehabilitation therapy, and evaluate the health economic impact of home- based telerehabilitation in patients with recent stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding how signal transduction pathways drive specific genetic circuits is a fundamental goal of biology. The thousands of dynamic signaling events and gene expression changes that occur upon cell stimulation have made linking these two processes challenging. Here, we propose a novel, interdisciplinary analytical framework to link gene expression programs to specific phosphorylation events using genome-wide data with the goal of expanding strategies for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH
PHR: EHS-Net Food Safety Project Narrative Foodborne illness has been, and continues to be, a tremendously important public health problem in Minnesota. Case-control studies have implicated eating at restaurants as a source of nonoutbreak-associated infections with several disease agents (e.g., Salmonella, Campylobacter, and E. coli O157:H7). These studies, along with the substantial burden of foodborne illness outbreaks associated with commercial food establishments, were primary reasons for the formation of the Environmental Health Specialist Network (EHS-Net). Foodborne outbreaks associated with commercial food establishments still occur commonly. In the last 20 years, EHS-Net has made great strides in characterizing and publishing contributing factors and antecedents to foodborne illness in these establishments. The Minnesota Department proposes to synthesize completed EHS-Net work; conduct additional contributing factor and antecedent studies; and, develop, implement, and evaluate intervention studies at commercial food establishments.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: EH20-001, Environmental Health Specialists Network (EHS-Net) - Practice based research to improve food safety

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Environmental Health Specialists Network (EHS-Net) – Practice Based Research to  Improve Food Safety in New York State RFA-EH-20-001 Project Narrative The New York State Department of Health (NYSDOH) has been a leader in protecting and advancing the health of New Yorkers through a comprehensive network of public health activities and services. The complexity of the state, from densely populated urban, to rural and suburban areas, the diversity of the state with respect to race, ethnicity, and socioeconomic status, warrants a public health system that is comprehensive and flexible to govern the state's public health successfully. The NYSDOH is seeking support for the Environmental Health Specialists Network (EHS-Net) – Practice Based Research to Improve Food Safety Cooperative Agreement.

PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-EH-20-001 : Environmental Health Specialists Network (EHS-Net) - Practice Based Research to Improve Food Safety In New York State

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Significance/Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because improving upon the surveillance and response of foodborne illness complaints, and prevention efforts to reduce future ones, has the effect of reducing potentially catastrophic foodborne illness outbreaks that can lead to significant human and economic loss. Thus, this proposal is relevant to the established CDC Food Safety Winnable Battle for Food Safety priority to discover high impact and innovative research strategies that will ultimately assist in preventing foodborne illness.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: EH20-001 - Strengthening Foodborne Illness Surveillance and Response Capabilities in Harris County Using an Innovative System-Based Approach

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: RHODE ISLAND STATE DEPT OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Rhode Island EHS-Net Practice Based Research to Improve Food Safety The researched proposed by the Rhode Island Department of Health (RIDOH), Center for Food Protection (CFP) will increase the knowledge in the scientific community regarding risk factors that contribute to foodborne illness and interventions to address those risk factors. More specifically, the studies aim to evaluate Norovirus interventions and prevention efforts, quantify the impact of having a Certified Manager on at all times, and identify best practices for environmental assessments. The research conducted under this funding opportunity will improve environmental health practices in retail food establishments and reduce illnesses and disabilities associated foodborne pathogens.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: EH20-001 Rhode Island EHS-Net Practice Based Research to Improve Food Safety

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because a better understanding of how certified kitchen managers impact foodborne illness risk factors in food service operations and retail food establishments could improve food safety in these facilities. Additional collaboration on other EHS-Net projects could result in further advancements in environmental health practice. Thus, the proposed activities are relevant to the EHS-Net’s aim to develop a cross-cutting network of public health professionals that conduct practice- based retail food safety research to improve food safety.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: EH20-001 - Franklin County Public Health practice-based research to identify and prevent environmental risk factors contributing to foodborne illness

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Recent research has proposed that negative food safety culture be considered an emerging risk factor for foodborne illness outbreaks due to its significant impact on outbreaks (Griffith, Livesey, & Clayton, 2010a). SNHD proposes to explore food safety culture as experienced by food handlers and restaurant managers and share findings by creating resources geared toward restaurants. This study aims to foster positive food safety culture which may improve adherence to food safety practices, thereby potentially reducing foodborne illness transmission at the retail food establishment level.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: EH20-001 SNHD Food Safety Culture

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: FUND FOR PUBLIC HEALTH IN NEW YORK, INC.
PHR: Project Narrative The NYC EHS-Net Program will use data and informatics tools to improve measurement and surveillance of foodborne illness risk factors in the NYC retail food service environment. We anticipate three outcomes associated with the work we propose: 1) faster and more accurate identification of risk factors, 2) interventions or policies that effectively address those risk factors and thereby reduce incidence of FBI, and 3) improved public health practice, including implementation of evidence-based food safety regulations and policy, distribution of effective educational resources to food service workers, and more efficient and effective inspectional programs.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Advancing Foodborne Illness Prevention and Outbreak Response in the New York City Retail Food Service Environment

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: Rates of cannabis use and Cannabis Use Disorder (CUD) are increasing among women; epidemiological reports document a telescoping effect where women transition from first use to CUD at a faster rate than men. To understand cannabis’s acute effects that underlie the accelerated trajectory to CUD observed in women, the proposed study will compare smoked cannabis’s dose-dependent, abuse-related effects between men and women and variables that underlie these sex-dependent differences, including pharmacokinetics of THC and menstrual cycle effects. Findings from these studies will be instrumental in establishing sex as a biological variable in the prevention, intervention, and treatment of CUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project will test the safety and efficacy of Quadriga’s new small molecule drug, QBS72S, in a clinical trial of patients with triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) with brain metastases (tumor cells that have spread to the brain). TNBC is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer: almost half of all women with TNBC develop brain metastases, and those who do typically survive for only three to six months longer. If QBS-72S proves effective in treating brain metastatic TNBC patients, it will hold promise for treating patients with other brain metastatic cancers, including lung cancer and melanoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Macrophages, a component of our immune system, have a paradoxical role in cancer – they can promote metastasis. We previously discovered that macrophages spill their internal contents into cancer cells during metastasis, but what is the functionally important information in the contents? We recently discovered that mitochondria are transferred, and we seek to answer how thieving even small amounts of mitochondria can drive big changes in cancer cell metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol consumption is a leading cause of death and disability in the United States. Requiring evidence-based health warnings on alcohol containers could inform consumers and reduce unhealthy alcohol consumption, but there is little data on how such warnings influence alcohol consumption. The proposed research will optimize evidence-based warnings about the health harms of alcohol consumption and evaluate their effectiveness at reducing alcohol consumption among regular alcohol consumers in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: To investigate the pathophysiology of postoperative delirium (POD) in the long run, we propose to establish a new animal model in aged nonhuman primates by simultaneously measuring behaviors, neurophysiological markers, and blood biomarker (tau and phosphorylated tau) levels. We will set up the model by testing whether a general anesthetic sevoflurane promotes delirium-like behaviors, cortical neural changes, and alterations in plasma phosphorylated tau concentrations, as compared to propofol. Successful completion of the proposed studies will lead to a NIH R01 application to further study the POD pathophysiology using this animal model and may ultimately guide future perioperative care for high-risk elderly patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Nerve injuries with a gap to-be-crossed greater than 3cm generally require a graft to facilitate axonal regeneration across the space, and regeneration across larger gaps has very limited success. The Romero lab at UH has developed a combination of growth factors that can significantly enhance recovery of function. Here we propose to partner with Pioneer Neurotech to develop procedures and specifications to incorporate the growth factors into implantable devices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction affects a majority of heart failure patients, its prevalence is rising, and there are few effective therapies. Most patients today are also very obese, and this has altered the syndrome, worsening its prognosis and underlying pathobiology. This program elucidates how obesity has changed HFpEF at fundamental biological levels, including heart metabolism, gene expression and epigenetics, regulatory proteins, and the motors that make hearts contract.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this Program Project, we investigate how psychosocial stress affects cardiovascular disease by interfering with leukocyte dynamics. Over the course of our Type-1 Program, we substantially contributed to knowledge about the links between stress and cardiovascular disease by identifying tissular, cellular, and molecular pathways that connect nervous, immune, and vascular systems. The successful completion of this renewal application will not only lay the foundation for unique (i) scientific insights in immune mechanisms that are regulated neurologically and drive cardiovascular disease development but also yield (ii) a forward-thinking approach to managing cardiovascular disease in individuals experiencing prolonged episodes of psychosocial stress and identify novel (iii) therapeutic targets and treatments.
