IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic lung allograft dysfunction (CLAD) is a progressive fibrosis of the airway and/or lung parenchyma that is the primary limiting factor for long-term survival after lung transplantation. During acute cellular rejection, recipient-derived T cells infiltrate the lung allograft, migrate to the airways where CLAD predominantly occurs, and persist within the transplanted lungs as long-lived tissue resident memory T cells (TRM). This research project investigates the role of alloreactive recipient derived TRM in the development of CLAD after lung transplantation and explores the impact of commonly used immune modulators on TRM persistence, phenotype, and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal builds on the considerable strengths of a twenty-year partnership between NIDA and AMERSA to produce an annual addiction science conference that will further open the critical pipeline for a more diverse, equitable, and inclusive community of addiction health professionals and scientists grounded in evidence- based research, practice and policy. AMERSA members represent a wide array of multidisciplinary health professionals, many of whom are national and international leaders in substance use research and education. Given AMERSA’s strong track record in excellent, evidence-based conference training, the potential of this application for strengthening interdisciplinary substance use research, training, practice, and policy is substantial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This study is relevant to public health because it will help researchers design studies of targeted approaches to treatment of obstructive sleep apnea and obesity. The findings will guide the development of future drugs and devices for obstructive sleep apnea. Such results will have a positive impact on future diagnostics and interventions, and permit select interventions early on in the progression of all three disorders, thereby reducing cost and preventing adverse cardiovascular outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with malignancy of the digestive tract often experience severe and unremitting abdominal pain that negatively affects physical, emotional, and social function. Patients frequently turn to opioids when other treatments fail to provide adequate analgesia, yet often discover that opioids also fall short in delivering meaningful pain reduction or improving quality of life. This study will test the impact of therapeutic virtual reality (VR)—an evidence-based treatment for pain—as a non-pharmacologic adjunctive treatment for cancer-related pain in patients with malignancies of the digestive tract.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a deadly progressive disease without curative therapy. Because we found that syndecan-1 augmented lung fibrosis through miRNAs in extracellular vesicles (EVs), we propose to investigate how syndecan-1 regulates miRNA packaging into EVs to control fibroproliferation. The findings of the study will provide a novel knowledge that can potentially lead to new therapeutic options for this deadly disease. 8.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The cerebellum, a brain region implicated in fine-tuning of movements, also influences social interaction and updating of cognitive states such as reward and working memory. Cerebellar injury in humans and other animals leads to pronounced social and cognitive deficits, especially when it occurs early in life. The proposed studies will uncover how neural activity in the cerebellum modulates cognitive task performance in mice and thus contribute to understanding of syndromes marked by cerebellar dysfunction, including attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, and autism spectrum disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Health information technology tools such as secure messaging and diabetes apps have tremendous potential to decrease barriers to care and promote self-management for Type 2 Diabetes (T2D). This study will develop a method to leverage such tools for helping low socioeconomic status patients manage T2D through improved individualized education, problem-solving help, and remote monitoring by clinicians. Findings from this study have the potential to improve virtual diabetes care and outcomes for low socioeconomic status populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The research will provide valuable information to school administrators and government policy makers in the participating LMICs to document the burden of CMDs among university students, the extent of unmet need for treatment of these disorders, the effectiveness of inexpensive-scalable e-CBT interventions to treat these disorders, and for whom e-CBT is most effective. The technology transfer part of the study will build capacity to disseminate the methods used for screening, targeting, and intervention implementation so that they can be used in colleges and universities in LMICs throughout Latin America. Such an effort could have enormous public health implications for the region and serve as a model of evidence-based intervention planning and implementation for other parts of the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CD7-initiated signaling has long been regarded as inessential to T cell function. Here, we propose CD7 is an important adaptor protein responsible for recruiting PI3K and amplifying PI3K signaling upon T cell activation, a mechanoforce regulator that stabilizes TCR and peptide–MHC interactions, and a costimulatory molecule that can lower the reactive threshold of T cells. Characterization of CD7-involved signaling may suggest a novel immunomodulatory strategy to augment T cell effector function or subvert T cell exhaustion and senescence during chronic infection, cancer, and aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative For patients with gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST), our clinical capacity to predict the risk of recurrence following resection or the course of metastatic disease is limited and leads to significant uncertainties in patient care. The oncogenic program underlying GIST is driven by a core group of lineage-specific transcription factors and epigenetic regulators, with resulting disease behavior being dictated by additional disease state-specific accessory transcription factors. This proposal aims to understand the core transcriptional output of GIST, and how accessory transcription factors modify this central program to inculcate disease behavior, with implications for treatment strategies in this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The epidemic of childhood obesity disproportionately impacts low-income, minority communities, strongly predicts obesity and cardiometabolic disease in adulthood, and has few interventions that are scalable, begin early enough to be effective, and address socioeconomic and ethnic disparities. The purpose of this K23 proposal is to prepare the applicant for a career in developing and implementing interventions that begin in pregnancy to prevent child obesity using innovative and scalable delivery platforms, and to adapt and pilot test an evidence-based child obesity prevention intervention to be optimized for remote, virtual delivery. The knowledge gained from this proposal will help to address the critical need for scalable child obesity prevention programs that aim to eliminate disparities in child obesity and its adverse downstream consequences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Shift work increases the risk for diabetes possibly due to the adverse metabolic effects of circadian misalignment. As shift work is not foreseen to disappear, the development of individually-targeted therapies for metabolic health in these vulnerable shift workers is urgently needed. This research will determine whether restricting meal timing to the biological day – without disrupting sleep - can mitigate the adverse metabolic effects of circadian misalignment, which may help in the design of evidence-based dietary interventions to improve the metabolic health in shift workers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related death in the U.S. and worldwide. About 5% of lung cancers are caused by a mutant gene called anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK). Although there are several FDA- approved ALK inhibitor pills available for treating this disease, essentially all ALK-mutant lung cancers will develop resistance to these drugs. We have developed a novel ALK cancer vaccine which extends lifespan in mouse models of ALK-mutant lung cancer. In this project, we propose testing this vaccine in patients with ALK- mutant lung cancer with the intent of stimulating patients’ immune systems to recognize and obliterate ALK- mutant cancer cells and cure patients of their cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Loss of function of the SMARCA4/BRG1 gene occurs frequently in lung cancer, yet there is no targeted therapy available for patients with this tumor genotype. Current treatment modalities for these patients are usually ineffective, resulting in death of approximately 16,000 individuals this year in the United States alone. This work will define new precision medicine opportunities for these patients and define how targeting replication stress contributes to therapy response, which will be informative in a wide variety of cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic kidney disease (CKD) affects 15% of the US adult population and is independently associated with increased cardiovascular (CV) mortality and poor physical capacity. These studies will provide insight into mechanisms of abnormal hemodynamic responses during exercise that contribute to increased CV risk in CKD, and help develop therapeutic targets that are urgently needed to improve physical functioning, and ultimately reduce CV mortality. A multifaceted treatment combining aerobic exercise training with bicarbonate supplementation may be a novel therapeutic approach in CKD that has the potential to improve blood pressure reactivity and physical functioning, as well as impact long-term CV risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

We will then test strategies to exploit DTP vulnerabilities to improve outcomes for patients with EGFR mutation-positive NSCLC and other targetable driver abnormalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The intestinal immune system has a unique ability to discriminate harmless commensal microbes from pathogens, yet remarkably little is known about the cell types that initiate tolerance to commensal antigens at the time of colonization in early life. A developmental wave of antigen-presenting cells (APCs) seeds the intestine during the first week of life. This proposal seeks to determine how these APCs establish tolerance to commensal microbiota, the tissue signals that drive their development, and their role in susceptibility to intestinal immune mediated diseases in adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Inflammatory Bowel Disease is multifactorial and caused by the interplay of genetics, the microbiome and environmental factors. Diet is one of the most prominent environmental factors influencing IBD, however the major challenge for implementing dietary therapy for IBD is the lack of understanding of detailed mechanistic pathways to explain the impact of dietary interventions. The overall goal of this project is to discover relevant dietary fiber-microbe-immune cell interactions that prevent, induce or alter the course of gut inflammation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Many severe mental disorders are characterized by impairments in social interactions, yet these diseases are poorly understood, and current treatments are lacking to treat them effectively. Advanced molecular and genetic technologies allow for the dissection of dedicated neural pathways involved in specific behaviors, providing novel targets for diagnosis and therapeutic development. This proposal aims to leverage cutting edge molecular, electrophysiological and imaging approaches to uncover the molecular, biophysical and systems-level regulation of neural circuits underlying affiliative and agonistic behavior of males and females toward infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Non-small cell lung cancer is one of the most common neoplasms worldwide and associates with poor survival and high mutation rate. Despite the significant advances in the development of molecularly targeted therapy in last decade, tumors with the most prevalent KRAS mutations remain refractory to targeted therapy. Based on compelling preliminary data, we will dissect the functional roles of SETDB1, a major H3K9 methyltransferase in regulating malignant progression of KRAS mutant non-small cell lung cancer, determine the importance of its monoubiquitination and catalytic activity, and elucidate the underlying mechanisms. This innovative project will not only decipher epigenetic mechanisms contribute to oncogenic KRAS-induced transcription reprogramming in lung cancer progression, but also highlight novel therapeutic opportunities for targeting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will increase our understanding of how Salmonella enterica tolerates and distributes copper. Copper, as part of the innate immune response, is used as a bactericide agent by the human host to control/restrict/limit Salmonella infection. The links between copper and periplasmic redox stress response will be also identified. The proposed studies are relevant to public health because Salmonella enterica causes gastroenteritis and systemic diseases in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This research aims to contribute to the health of people with cancer by improving the treatment of depression in this population. The study will develop technology to optimize the delivery of an effective system of care for depression, called Collaborative Care Management. Improving the ability to effectively treat depression in people with cancer will reduce the disabling effects of cancer and its treatment and improve overall quality of life.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Hypoparathyroidism is a rare disorder with devastating complications, but there are no prospective natural history studies on the long-term effects of the disease. This study will provide a rigorous standardized approach to longitudinal data collection on end-organ damage in hypoparathyroidism. The findings will advance monitoring practice paradigms and support product development for this rare disease.

PROJECT_TITLE: Advancing Product Development for Hypoparathyroidism: A Prospective Natural History Study of the Clinical Outcomes and Regulation of Disordered Mineral Metabolism

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative--Overall The Mays Cancer Center (MCC) at the University of Texas Health San Antonio (UT Health SA) is the National Cancer Institute-designated Cancer Center (NCICC) for a 38-county region of Central and South Texas, a region of 45,926 square miles with 4.9 million individuals who have a unique set of cancer-related challenges. The population in this catchment area is predominantly Hispanic, the fastest growing demographic in the United States (U.S.). The mission of the MCC is to reduce the cancer burden in Central and South Texas through the highest quality cancer care with expanded treatment options from our early phase clinical trials, ground- breaking cancer research aimed at reducing the incidence and mortality of cancer as well as improving treatment options, education of the future leaders of cancer scientists and clinicians, and cancer prevention programs that focus on our unique population. The MCC strives to be the institution of choice for cancer care in South Texas, a highly-productive research institution that attracts and retains the best cancer scientists, is the institution of choice for cancer education, and an organization devoted to reducing the burden of cancer in our region. The MCC has continued its focus on serving our unique South Texas population which is predominantly Hispanic (69%). The population of San Antonio’s metropolitan area is about 63% Hispanic, while parts of South Texas included in our catchment area are more than 90% Hispanic. Our goal is for the MCC to be a national resource where personalized, culturally-sensitive clinical care and scientific discovery will be conducted, focusing on the unique population of San Antonio and South Texas, to be used as the precepts for cancer control for the U.S. which, with changing demographics, will face many of the current challenges of our region in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Clinical trials are a vital part of the research process. Access to oncology clinical trials remains essential to address the many unmet needs in cancer prevention, control, screening, and treatment. The bulk of cancer care takes place in community settings, so allowing patients from community hospitals to participate in national clinical research allows access to a larger, more diverse patient population to promote increased patient outcomes and reduce disparities. With this funding opportunity, the Metro-Minnesota Community Oncology Research Consortium (MMCORC) will continue to provide people in our community access to the newest therapies available for cancer treatment, symptom management, and cancer prevention, along with the opportunity to participate in trials that examine how the cancer care delivery process influences clinical outcomes and patient well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to provide biostatistical leadership and data management infrastructure for the BLOODSAFE initiative, an NHLBI initiative which seeks to increase the supply of safe blood available for transfusion in Sub-Saharan Africa. This leadership includes coordination of activities across multiple projects, collaboration with scientists at NHLBI on program oversight and provision of expertise regarding all aspects of study design and implementation. This expertise includes but is not limited to coordination with local experts, provision of training to local experts, assistance with study design, harmonization of data elements across multiple studies, assistance with implementation of interventions, data management, data quality assurance, data analysis and study finding dissemination to ensure that discoveries are communicated to the scientific community and translated into local best practices in a timely manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV incidence remains high among men who have sex with men (MSM) in Perú, and has not significantly changed despite the scale-up of antiretroviral treatment access over the last decade. New strategies are needed to increase access to HIV testing and promote timely linkage to treatment and prevention services in this population. In this project, we will develop, refine, and conduct feasibility testing of a multi-component intervention to support HIV testing and linkage to services among MSM in Perú.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Cocaine Use Disorder (CUD) is a significant public health and socioeconomic concern, but genetic factors that contribute to development of CUD remain poorly understood. Genetic studies of CUD are difficult to perform in humans due to inability to control environmental factors; the haplotype structure of the human genome limiting mapping precision; and small sample sizes as a result of difficulty recruiting participants due to the criminalization of cocaine use. I will take advantage of the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster, a powerful genetic model organism, to identify genetic variants associated with development of cocaine preference and construct genetic networks that can serve as a gene discovery template for candidate genes associated with human CUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vaccines are necessary to protect against harmful pathogens; however, their development has typically been empiric and their approval based on clinical, not immunological outcomes. The severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2) mRNA vaccines demonstrate varied efficacy across age and time post-vaccination, highlighting our lack of understanding of how, where, and in what quantity vaccine-specific immunity is induced. This proposed work will fill these gaps in knowledge so that more effective prevention strategies can be developed to manage the current pandemic and any future health crises.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute allograft rejection is a T cell mediated immune response that continues to undermine heart transplant outcomes. Endogenous (pre-existing) memory T cells infiltrate cardiac allografts early after graft reperfusion and the proposed experiments will test the mechanisms by which these memory T cells are activated to mediate increased graft tissue injury and rejection of allografts subjected to prolonged cold ischemic storage. Findings from these studies should reveal new therapeutic targets to dampen early post-transplant inflammation and inhibit endogenous memory CD8 T cell-mediated acute graft injury and rejection of high-risk allografts in unsensitized recipients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Effort-cost decision-making (ECDM) deficits are core to schizophrenia (SZ) and associated with poor functional outcomes. The proposed project seeks to integrate lab-based behavioral and neuroimaging paradigms with real- world measures of social motivation to investigate whether and how social influence may enhance ECDM in SZ. This project, which would provide the candidate with valuable training opportunities towards her goals as an independent researcher, could elucidate mechanisms at the intersection of social and motivational processes in SZ and pave the way for targeted interventions for these debilitating impairments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cardiac surgery-associated acute kidney injury (CSA-AKI) is a major public health burden, with no therapy that reliably prevents or treats it. Abundant data from animal models and humans suggest that hepcidin and other heme/iron regulatory proteins play a key role in CSA-AKI. We will investigate circulating levels and cellular expression of heme/iron regulatory proteins to assess whether they are risk factors and early markers of CSA-AKI, and could serve as therapeutic targets for CSA-AKI prevention in future trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rickettsia species are intracellular bacterial pathogens that cause mild to deadly vascular diseases in humans. Our overall goal in this project is to determine how a secretion system and secreted bacterial proteins hijack host cell function to promote pathogenesis. This work will improve our understanding of Rickettsia pathogenesis, provide insights into host cell biology, and may lead to improved diagnostics or treatments for infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The medial prefrontal cortex governs many aspects of cognitive control and is hypothesized to play a major role in individual differences in cognitive function both before and after alcohol exposure that drive maladaptive behaviors that characterize alcohol use disorder (AUD). The focus of this proposal is to gain insight into the contribution of a population of prefrontal cortical neurons that project to the midbrain in preexisting and alcohol induced cognitive dysfunction in order to understand more about this specific pathway in the vulnerability of AUD development. This research addresses a critical gap in knowledge regarding the cognitive factors that predispose certain individuals over others to AUD development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed pipeline program—Summer Health Academic Research Experience in Communication Sciences and Disorders (SHARE-CSD)—is a 6-week summer research experience for undergraduate students from backgrounds typically underrepresented in STEM and health fields. The proposal includes both an intensive, mentored summer research experience along with academic and career development training, and it also includes long-term continued peer and faculty mentoring, as research indicates that having a supportive network is an important component of success for students from underrepresented groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE NARRATIVE Neurotoxicity is the major adverse side effect limiting the efficacy of CAR T-cells, a type of cancer immunotherapy. Neurotoxicity cannot be prevented or treated adequately because our understanding of how it occurs is poor. This project employs a unique mouse model of CAR T-cell-induced neurotoxicity to test hypotheses about its etiology and strategies to prevent or blunt its effects.

PHR: Narrative: The prevalence of heart failure continues to rise, and for approximately half of all heart failure cases there are no approved therapies proven to modify the course of disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions of our youth suffer from pain and psychological symptoms that, when poorly managed, put youth at risk for poor health outcomes. Many teens try to self-manage symptoms by using and misusing prescribed drugs or other substances on their own without supervision. Our research will help explain how complex symptoms and other influences (family and environment) contribute to risky self-treatment behaviors and will evaluate the potential impact of interventions meant to protect against risky behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of morbidity in the United States and many Americans struggle with modifying health behaviors which could improve their overall health and life-expectancy. This K24 proposal focuses on using new and emerging digital data sources and methodologies (e.g. big data analytics, machine learning, natural language processing) to better phenotype health behaviors which can be modified to improve cardiovascular health. Through this K24, Dr. Merchant will develop and implement 1) a successful and high-impact research program focused on advancing CV health and digital data science and 2) a successful and enduring mentorship program focused on training and supporting the next generation of patient-oriented researchers who can advance this field to improve the CV health of individuals and communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The overarching goal of this project is to provide an explanatory analysis of coding by neural populations in midbrain and forebrain regions underlying sound localization functions. [This goal will be addressed by population recordings within and across midbrain and forebrain areas of the sound localization pathway of both awake and anesthetized barn owls supporting spatial discriminability and stimulus selection, and testing sound localizing behaviors.] The mechanistic hypotheses mediating these functions that will be specifically tested are a built-in representation of sensory statistics optimizing spatial discriminability and co-modulation of temporal spiking patterns by sound-identity features as well as brain oscillations underlying stimulus selection across space. Finally, simultaneous population recordings across brain regions involved in sound localization will provide a wide-ranging perspective of how populations interact across brain regions involved in sound localization. This research will contribute to explain population coding underlying implementation and optimization of relevant sound localization functions and elucidate the routing of activity along the central auditory system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Narrative Emerging evidence indicates that epigenetic mechanisms are centrally linked to the development of the mammalian central nervous system and go awry in neurological disorders. Here, we unravel the functional link between long-range 3D genome folding patterns and synaptic plasticity during the encoding of long-term memory in the mammalian brain. Because many key neurological disorders are thought to be diseases of the synapse, successful completion of this work will provide a foundation for future studies unraveling the role for misfolded genome topology on the onset and progression of neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anorexia nervosa (AN) has the highest mortality rate of any psychiatric illness, yet we have a poor understanding of the biological causes of this disorder. In this proposal we examine the basic question of whether individuals with AN have poorer “gut sensations” which enable them to fast and lose weight despite severe medical consequences. In this project, we use a novel probe, which may eventually be useful as a marker for diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment success in AN.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative TDP-43 protein is dysfunctional in various neurodegenerative diseases. Recent findings suggest that TDP-43 dysfunction alters innate antiviral responses in the brain, which may contribute to Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and other dementias. The exact causal relationship between TDP-43 and antiviral pathways will be examined in order to uncover potential therapeutic targets for AD and related neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this R25 program is to increase the participation of underrepresented minority groups in the fields of Biostatistics and quantitative Public Health, with a collaborative focus on the diseases and processes of aging. The program includes an intensive six-week summer program for 12 students, with formal and informal instruction, mentored research, and extensive professional development activities, with a culminating symposium. For lasting impact, follow-up mentoring, continuing research and professional development will occur on a regular basis, both via webcast platforms and return, in-person visits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE  Osteoporosis is a common bone disease, especially in elderly men and women, and it leads to thin bones that are more prone to fracture. We are studying the actions of important proteins in the bone cells that may be able to slow down bone loss while also rebuilding bone. Our long term goal is to develop new drugs that will make bones stronger so that we can prevent osteoporosis in men and women.

PHR: Telemetric Regenerative Bandage for Accelerating Wound Healing Narrative This project describes the development of a shape-conforming antioxidant dressing that upon exposure to body temperature transforms into a vasculoinductive, dermoconductive and dermoinductive scaffold that promotes new tissue formation in diabetic wounds. It also involves developing a wireless wound feedback system that involves tissue conforming temperature and pH microsensors to monitor potential bacterial infection and/or lack of healing to improve patient outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children orphaned in low-to-middle income countries experience high levels of food insecurity, economic adversity, and other social risk factors that impact their ability to engage in and benefit from mental health treatments. This project privileges the voice of Kenyan community members in co-creating strategies to address social risk factors that can be integrated into mental health treatment. Lay mental health counselors will learn to implement the strategies during treatment, and we will examine counselor perspectives on the strategies’ potential promise for addressing social risk factors and improving mental health care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Relevance  Osteoarthritis is the most common joint disease characterized by wear and tear of joint articular cartilage with no disease modifying drug available yet. This project will determine the novel role of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) signaling in controlling the structure and function of knee articular cartilage during osteoarthritis progression. Information garnered from these studies will be important for advancing our current knowledge of cartilage biology and designing novel therapeutic strategies to treat osteoarthritis.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Injuries and other surgically treated diseases comprise a significant burden of disease in Cameroon and other sub-Saharan African (SSA) countries with deep inequities that are particularly unmasked in acute care settings. D-SINE Africa Hub will focus on the intersection between injury and equity, leveraging data science to decrease the impact of trauma, surgical disease, and disparities on the population of Cameroon and SSA by promoting collaborative research, networking, and capacity building with an emphasis on equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A national challenge in the biomedical sciences is recruiting, training, and retaining the most diverse scientific talent pool possible. At the University of Utah, we are poised to tackle this challenge by leveraging our recent successes in recruiting underrepresented students to our graduate programs and redoubling our efforts to develop targeted training and pipeline programs for underrepresented students to strengthen our applicant pool for graduate programs. We will expand the Biomedical Research Inclusion & Diversity to Grow Excellence in Science – Undergraduate program in Pathology for HBCUs and solidify key relationships with our local community and Historically Black Colleges and Universities in order to foster an inclusive, research-intensive environment where underrepresented scientists can flourish and attain their goal of admission to top-notch PhD training programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Public health Relevance Polycystic Kidney Disease (PKD) is the most common inherited cause of renal failure worldwide. Despite significant progress in the field there is still no therapy that can reverse or cure PKD. That National Institutes of Health has established a PKD Research Consortium to accelerate research in PKD with the hope of identifying novel therapies. The goal of this proposal is to establish a National Coordinating Center that will provide administrative support to the PKD Research consortium with the goal of advancing translational science that will benefit patients with PKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Direct Targeting “loss-of-function” tumor suppressor is challenging and intuitively considered as “mission impossible”. In this proposal, using SMAD4 tumor suppressor as a case study, we propose to address the challenge in part through direct targeting a subgroup of “loss-of-interaction” SMAD4 mutations using small molecule mutant SMAD4-protein-protein-interaction inducers (MuSMADid). The small molecule MuSMADid discovery will provide a proof-of-concept for developing other small molecule PPI inducers for targeting the vast neglected tumor suppressor space.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Glial-neuronal interactions underlie a broad range of aging-associated disease phenotypes in the nervous system and beyond. Activation of the heat shock response (HSR) has been shown to extend lifespan and promote healthy aging, but until this proposal, glial signaling of the HSR has never been examined. This proposal studies the mechanism by which glial stress response induction can extend lifespan, and further proposes extending this work using microglia/neuronal interaction in tauopathies to interrogate the ways in which microglia signal aging-related stress responses to protect neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: STATEMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The proposed research is relevant to public health because, as our population ages, the financial and societal burden of neurodegenerative diseases will greatly expand over the coming decades. This proposal seeks to generate knowledge and resources around a broad-based understanding of tau metabolism. The proposed research is relevant to the NIH's mission of extending healthy life and reducing the burdens of illnesses like neurodegeneration, since its findings will enhance related efforts to target tau clearance and develop therapies for neurodegenerative diseases such as FTD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the microbial communities living in (and on) the human body play a key role in disease, understanding how the microbiome affects health has been limited by small sample sizes, which make it impractical to accurately detect complex ecological dynamics. We will compile and organize publicly available data to create the largest human microbiome dataset in the world, and use machine learning to uncover novel insights into human health that have until now been lost in the noise. The compendium and models will enable microbiome researchers to generate robust characterizations of the complex relationship between microbiota and their hosts, which can in turn support novel, more reliable diagnosis of disease and bring the field one step closer to developing microbiome-based therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The developing nervous system exhibits plasticity during formation of connections (synapses) between neuronal partners; disruption of which can lead to abnormal processing (dysfunction) of the brain. We observe synaptic reorganizations during development of connections in the inner retina and the main goal of this research is to determine the cell-autonomous and non-cell autonomous mechanisms that regulate the timing and occurrence of synaptic reorganizations during retinal circuit assembly. Our research will reveal the mechanisms driving developmental plasticity and circuit organization during establishment of sensory circuits and will determine circuit plasticity motifs that can be accentuated or curtailed as part of repair strategies for retinal degenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Expression of neoantigens in the patient' tumor is paramount for susceptibility to immune therapy. Given the paucity of neoantigens in many patients we propose to develop novel and clinically applicable methods to induce neoantigens in the patient' disseminated tumor lesion using a novel nucleic acid-based drug and drug delivery platform. The proposed approach forms the basis for the development of preventative cancer vaccines to prevent recurrence for patients in remission, and for individuals at high risk of developing cancer, such as individuals with precancerous lesions, individuals suffering from chronic infections or individuals with genetic predisposition to cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This is the first study to use both next-generation sequencing and genome-wide association study data to analyze the contribution of non-HLA genetic variants to mortality after allogeneic blood and marrow transplantation (BMT) for life-threatening hematologic cancers. Importantly, our study population includes multiple races and ethnicities which will allow us to investigate the role of genetics on BMT survival across diverse populations. The data generated by this project will be shared publicly to serve as a resource for additional research to improve survivorship after this therapy and enhance the public investment in this project.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is an academic industry partnership that will make available to neurosurgeons and neuro- oncologists a neuronavigation capability that will optimize treatment of patients with brain tumors by more efficiently and accurately localizing critical brain regions and providing prognostic information on the patient’s survival. This development is relevant to public health because it will assist clinicians to personalize patient treatment planning, including surgical strategy and subsequent oncologic care. Towards this end, we propose to create an imaging technology package that will integrate advanced machine learning techniques using resting state functional magnetic resonance imaging with an existing widely used neuro-anatomic navigation system currently used by neurosurgeons. The integrated system, which will include anatomic, functional, and prognostic information, will provide a more comprehensive patient assessment to maximize safe and effective treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Germinal matrix hemorrhage (GMH) is a leading cause of neonatal death and neurodevelopmental disorders. However, the mechanism leading to GMH remains unclear. This research project brings together unparallel expertise in neuropathology, single-cell transcriptomics, in vitro disease modeling, and neural stem cell biology, to rigorously investigate the role of neuroinflammation in the pathogenesis of GMH. Results from this project will provide important insights into disease mechanism of, and therapeutic targets for, GMH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative We will interrogate the developmental and genetic signature of pancreas tissue organization at unprecedented scales including spatially-resolved chromatin architecture, transcriptome, and in situ cellular function. Our results have the potential to identify key pathways including their context-specific regulatory elements, genes, and cell types, governing islet and pancreas development. If successful, these studies will provide new mechanistic insights about the functional maturation of human β cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Jails in the United States are hot spots for spread of SARS-CoV-2 infection, resulting in a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality among incarcerated persons and correctional staff. Despite potential for high impact, limited work has investigated SARS-CoV-2 transmission dynamics in jail populations or evaluated interventions in jails to reduce COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. To address this critical need, the proposed study will examine population movement, COVID-19 testing, and COVID-19 cases in North Carolina jails, and using mathematical modeling, project incidence of SARS-CoV-2 infection and the extent to which interventions will reduce COVID-19 morbidity and mortality in jails and their surrounding communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The epigenetic process safeguards cell identity during cell division through the inheritance of appropriate gene expression profiles. Little is known regarding the chromatin inheritance of a hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) state in normal human development. In this proposal, we will identify the molecular basis in constructing the heritable epigenome of HSCs and determine how chromatin dynamics confers HSC self-renewal and differentiation potential.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE  The proposed program aims to develop and sustain capacity to conduct neurological research and impart such knowledge in Africa, by offering in-depth formal training in the design, execution, and leadership of neurological research to 24 carefully selected African scholars. The fellowship, administered through a collaboration between African and US academic institutions, as well as professional societies, will train eligible individuals in a broad range of clinical research issues, such that they can eventually populate Africa’s academic institutions as faculty, and foster enduring capacity to engage in high quality neurological research, and mentor future generations of Africans in the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Posterior capsule opacification or secondary cataracts is a vision impeding complication after cataract surgery and requires laser treatment to restore vision, but laser treatment can inflict damage to retina. Moreover, secondary cataracts impose a significant burden on health care costs and diminish quality of life in the elderly. The goal of our proposed studies is to understand the biochemical mechanisms of secondary cataracts to inform development of future innovative therapies for this condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: U01 Application: The role of senescent beta cells in T1D and T2D Narrative  Recent reports suggest that the elimination of senescent insulin-producing beta cells can prevent or delay the onset of type 1 and type 2 diabetes in mouse models. Here, we will test this hypothesis using advanced genetic and genomic tools in human pancreatic islets to ascertain if this approach should be pursued for clinical practice.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Bacterial infections are highly prevalent and contribute significantly to morbidity and mortality across all age-groups but because appropriate bacterial diagnostic services are non- existent or very limited, finding the true cause of most infections and the true spread of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is a major challenge in Africa, where data is limited. Our proposal has three goals to comparatively study bacterial isolates to inform trends in AMR and dynamics of transmission, to incorporate markers of serious bacterial infection and gene products from resistant bacteria to create a portable screening tool for clinical care and to explore the antimicrobial propers, and to explore the potential benefit of an aminoglycoside-antimicrobial peptide complex for enhanced therapeutic efficacy against multidrug resistant bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The proposed research will lay a foundation for developing innovative, individualized interventions to improve nonverbal communication (NVC) experiences for autistic adults, based on the values and first-hand experiences of our target population. Improvements in NVC are necessary for downstream improvements in a range of func- tional contexts, resulting in overall improved life outcomes associated with autism in adulthood. This project is relevant to NIDCD’s mission pertaining to intervention, and to the NIH’s Interagency Autism Coordinating Com- mittee’s dual missions related to intervention and lifespan issues. This project will produce a set of specific, stakeholder-driven recommendations for designing and prioritizing NVC intervention development, opening new horizons for how NVC is conceptualized and addressed in autism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Patients infected with both HIV and tuberculosis (TB) are at extremely high risk of death and long-term morbidity if they survive. Early treatment of both infections vastly improves long-term survival but there is a risk of TB-associated immune reconstitution syndrome (TB-IRIS) in which the symptoms of disease improve but then recur sometimes more severely than before treatment. Give that very little is currently understood about this process of TB-IRIS, this proposal identifies the basic mechanism of this poorly understood disease process and develop better strategies for prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Biologic treatments of asthma are revolutionary, albeit expensive, new methods of severe asthma management; however, the current standard of care assesses individual patient response to treatment at 12 weeks following treatment initiation based on exacerbation count and patient responses to asthma questionnaires. Only an estimated 60-80% of patients treated with biologics demonstrate response. Patient- specific biomarkers of lung function which may predict response are an unmet clinical need in this patient cohort, and early detection of response to treatment could improve patient outcomes and reduce costs. In this proposal we will employ one of the most sensitive methods of assessing lung function – hyperpolarized 129Xe MRI (HPG) – to address our hypothesis that early responders to biologic treatment of severe asthma (mepolizumab in particular) can be detected by HPG.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune cells infiltrating cancers and chronically infected tissues acquire dysfunctional characteristics that prevent their effective reinvigoration with immunotherapy. Our lab and others have described a role for altered cellular metabolism in defining whether these immune cells become dysfunctional and short-lived or acquire long-lived characteristics associated with healthy immunity. In this proposal, we will identify precisely how the products of the mitochondria alter the course of immune differentiation to promote anti-cancer immunity, and develop strategies to metabolically manipulate this altered differentiation to improve immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Tendon overuse initiates mechanical damage that leads to chronic tendinosis (degeneration) and tendinopathy (clinical presentation with pain), which are common and notoriously difficult to treat. This study will determine the mechanisms responsible for the multiscale damage in overuse tendinosis and establish these in the context of key hallmarks of human tendinosis using a preclinical in vivo model. Quantifying multiscale damage and cellular mechanisms by which loading leads to tendinosis is critical for designing and evaluating interventions to prevent and treat tendinopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is significant uncertainty in the clinical diagnosis of Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) as compared to the neuropathological-based diagnosis. The proposed research aims to identify the effect of aging and APOE genotype on speech motor control and examine the diagnostic potential of cognitively-demanding speech measures to detect early signs of dementia when early intervention and treatment against AD could be most effective. We will examine the diagnostic efficacy of speech acoustic and kinematic indices in a longitudinal paradigm by identifying whether measures of speech motor control at baseline predicts cognitive change over time and further validate this association against neuroimaging testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The ability of lymphocytes (an immune cell type) to migrate, interact with other cells, and correctly localize within the body is essential to establish effective immune responses to pathogens or cancer, and plays a role in autoimmunity. We will determine if the Formin family of proteins of the lymphocyte cytoskeleton regulates how lymphocytes enter and move within tissues. This work has the potential to provide insight into novel ways to therapeutically modulate lymphocyte migration, such as in autoimmune settings and inflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Clathrin-mediated endocytosis is responsible for uptake of molecules from the plasma membrane and surrounding environment, and therefore is crucial for determining how a cell will interact with its surroundings. Actin assembly near the plasma membrane generates forces that are harnessed for a variety of cellular processes including clathrin- mediated endocytosis. Mechanistic understanding of clathrin-mediated endocytosis and actin assembly are crucial to understanding normal cell physiology and a variety of pathological conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance The Dot/Icm type IV secretion system is a versatile virulence nanomachine that has the amazing capacity to translocate into host cells a repertoire of over 300 different bacterial proteins during infection. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The RAW Brain - the effect of rumination, anxiety and worry on aging and dementia risk. This study will identify the pathways through which the anxiety phenotypes contribute to accelerated aging and increased dementia risk. We will follow the participants for two years and will use repeated measures of brain aging as well as measures of peripheral aging and chronic stress. The overall goal of the study is to identify neural and biological pathways leading from rumination, anxiety and worry to brain and body aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) has historically been treated with chemotherapy, but patients who do not respond to treatment face a dismal prognosis. The proposed research uses genetic technologies to better understand the metabolism of leukemia cells and advance desperately needed new approaches to leukemia therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Asthmatic bronchospasm compresses the airway epithelium which, in turn, triggers aberrant airway remodeling—a cardinal feature of asthma. Here we use genomic profiling together with modern systems biology to elucidate the molecular mechanisms that underlie this pivotal mechanotransduction event.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mechanical birth injury to maternal pelvic soft tissues, including pelvic skeletal muscles, is the strongest potentially preventable risk factor for long-term pelvic floor dysfunction. This project, conducted in a preclinical model validated for the studies of human pelvic muscles, will have an impact on public health by delineating the adaptive and repair mechanisms of the female pelvic muscles, with specific focus on the biological processes that regulate the functional state of endogenous muscle stem cells during pregnancy - one of the most transformative non-pathological periods along the lifespan of many women. The knowledge gained from this proposal will lead to potential new preventative strategies and therapies for enhancing pelvic skeletal muscle plasticity and improving muscle recovery following mechanical injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The spatial organization of biological processes is fundamental to life, and lipid membranes are central to this activity. In this proposal we will examine the contributions of lipids known as hopanoids to the organization of the bacterial cell, and examine how subcellular organization is affected during bacterial infection of a eukaryotic host. This work will help determine fundamental principles of bacterial cell organization that likely can be applied to a variety of human pathogenic microbes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Alterations in translation control is a “hallmark” of cancer. The PI has consistently made highly impactful contributions to our understanding of how oncogenic pathways highjack the cell’s translation apparatus to make their own tailored proteome to direct specific steps in cancer initiation and progression. The project described in this application will employ novel pharmacogenomics approaches to address major unanswered questions in the field of translation and cancer, providing the rationale and tools for a new paradigm to target human tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to deepen our understanding of the mechanisms of efficient pyocyanin-mediated extracellular electron transfer (EET) in Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilms and its consequences for antibiotic tolerance. We seek to test the hypothesis that modulation of EET efficiency can render biofilms more susceptible to commonly used clinical antibiotics. The work proposed here will inform the design of more effective treatment strategies for P. aeruginosa infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This genetic study focuses on type 1 diabetes mutations in the protein coding region of the human genome, which are potential biological targets for treatment. We are generating mice and human cell lines to understand how these mutations cause diabetes, as well as using these animals as preclinical models for evaluating possible precision therapies. The results from this study will enable better detection, prediction, and treatment for patients with type 1 diabetes, and may also benefit individuals with other autoimmune disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disorders of cell signaling cascades are known to cause developmental pathologies, inflammation, diabetes, and cancers, while the mechanisms of signaling in health and disease are not well understood. Transmembrane and juxtamembrane domains of the structurally diverse receptor tyrosine kinases are central to the signal passage into the cell and numerous point mutations of these domains are attributed to diseases, yet structures of their dimers are lacking. Our goals are to develop a versatile method that combines novel computational approaches with experimental data, and to capture long-overdue dynamic dimer structures of the wild type and the pathogenic mutated forms of representative receptor tyrosine kinase subfamilies, improving our understanding of the mechanisms of cell signaling in disease and leading to new treatments.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Iodine deficiency is one of the most common and preventable causes of neurodevelopmental impairment worldwide. In a randomized controlled trial of high-fidelity, iodized salt provision along the continuum of pregnancy and lactation, we will determine the effects of iodine on early human brain development utilizing novel, multi-modal measures of neural function. This study will generate foundational knowledge about the role of iodine in the first 1000 days of life and inform the design and delivery of interventions to optimize the potential of children worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Long-term maintenance of regular physical activity significantly lowers risks of cancer and chronic diseases. Public health guidelines recommend combinations of activity intensity, frequency, and duration to achieve a “dose” of at least 150 min/week of moderate-to-vigorous intensity physical activity. While this approach aims to produce measurable health benefits, it fails to address emotional experiences (i.e., how people feel) during behavior, which may contribute to long-term sustainability. This early-phase trial will test intervention strategies to influence affective mechanisms underlying physical activity and determine whether changes in those mechanisms result in change in physical activity behavior among inactive adults who are overweight or obese.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Osteoarthritis remains the leading cause of disability, and effective treatment will require efﬁcient assessment of disease risk-factors, onset, and progression, both for development and personalization of minimally invasive interventions. We propose a 5-minute 3D MRI exam of both knees without radiation or contrast injection, that will be combined with low-cost measures of knee motion and fully automated analysis methods to provide quan- titative measurements of cartilage, tendon, ligament, bone and ﬁbrocartilage health and asymmetries between knees. This low-cost, rapid, bilateral assessment will enable research studies in large populations, as well as adding quantitative bilateral information to clinical scans to dramatically improve understanding of onset of dif- ferent types of osteoarthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cisplatin-based combination chemotherapy is the standard-of-care treatment for muscle invasive bladder cancer but 70% of patients do not respond. We discovered a novel mechanism by which puromycin-sensitive aminopeptidase, NPEPPS, is upregulated, and we have strong evidence supporting its interaction with volume- regulated anion channels (VRACs) to block import of cisplatin and other platins into cancer cells. The focus of this proposal is to characterize this novel mechanism and evaluate pharmacological inhibition of NPEPPS in combination with platin drugs in preclinical models with the objective of eventually improving patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative The ultimate goal of the multi-institutional Weill Cornell Clinical and Translational Science Center (CTSC) is to transform the national translational research enterprise to improve human health by supporting high quality clinical and translational research and research training. In the upcoming funding period, the CTSC will, with its partners at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Hospital for Special Surgery, Hunter College, School of Nursing, School of Urban Public Health; of City University of New York), Cornell University at Ithaca and the Animal Medical Center will continue to develop the existing infrastructure and its initiatives, to add new ones, to enhance networking, and to improve diversity, equity, and inclusion. In so doing, we will continue to advance translational science to improve community health, enhancing informatics to improving health inequities, and preparing for health crises, like the COVID-19 pandemic. continuing to develop our highly successful clinical and translational education programs, creating Team Science initiatives that promote inclusion across the CTSC. Project Narrative Page 299

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Sex and gender disparities in the severity and frequency of asthma exacerbations have been extensively reported, yet the biological and hormonal basis of these differences have not been elucidated. Here, we investigate the mechanisms by which estrogen triggers inflammation in the male and female asthmatic lung. Our findings will determine the molecular basis of hormonal triggers of asthma exacerbations in cis and transgender women and lead to the future development of better personalized therapeutic options for lung disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Candida albicans is commonly found in the gastrointestinal tract where it is important for stimulation of immune responses, but it can also enter the bloodstream and cause life- threatening systemic infections. This project examines the transcriptional regulation of key cell fate decisions in C. albicans including those controlling filamentation, biofilm formation and phenotypic switching, and also addresses how this regulation contributes to commensal and pathogenic infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proper spatial and temporal organization of organelles underlies many cellular processes including cell division, migration, differentiation, and communication. Mitochondria are essential organelles that can adapt their morphology and spatial distribution to changing environmental conditions–but the molecular mechanisms governing these physiological processes are still poorly understood, especially in morphologically complex cells like muscles and neurons, which suffer disproportionately from mitochondrial dysfunction during disease- and age-related degeneration. This project will provide fundamental and much-needed knowledge on the molecular mechanisms of regulated mitochondrial morphology for developing a molecular understanding of mitochondrial function in human cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: RELEVANCE The work described in this proposal will elucidate fundamental mechanisms of protein translocation across membranes, the assembly of complex organelles, and virulence factor biogenesis at the bacterial outer membrane. The emergence of multidrug resistant bacteria represents a major health threat, for which new alternatives to traditional antibiotics are urgently needed. This proposal will identify novel anti-virulence compounds that inhibit assembly of adhesive pili by Gram-negative bacterial pathogens, selectively disrupting host-pathogen interactions required to initiate and sustain infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Interleukin 33 (IL-33) is a unique member of the IL-1 superfamily of cytokines that regulate innate and adaptive immunity against gastrointestinal pathogens. IL-33 serves as both a pro- and anti-inflammatory mediator of host protective immunity, but the mechanisms responsible remain unclear. This project will investigate the hypothesis that cellular source of IL-33 is a critical determinant in host protective immunity against helminth and protozoan pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Histone dependent gene regulation is frequently dysregulated in disease. We have identified a novel histone H3 modification and pathogenic H3 variants that modulate proximal histone modification and alter gene expression, and propose to investigate their molecular mechanisms of action. These studies will advance our understanding of how histone-dependent gene expression governs functional biological changes that may underlie human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERALL COMPONENT: Innovations for screening and prognosis in HIV+ cancers including Kaposi sarcoma, cervical cancer, and lymphoma in Malawi and South Africa In response to RFA-CA-20-001, this application proposes to establish the UNC-Malawi-South Africa Cancer Consortium (UMSACC), to develop capacity and conduct high-impact research focused on HIV-associated cancers. Our consortium will be led by principal investigators with highly complementary expertise using a team science approach and a high priority of the consortium is the training and support of junior investigators in the U.S. and Africa. UMSACC proposes innovations for screening and prognosis of Kaposi sarcoma, cervical cancer and lymphoma in persons living with HIV (PLWH) with the overall goal being to improve the health of PLWH.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: ADMINISTRATIVE CORE This application responds to RFA-CA-20-001 and will establish a HIV-Associated Malignancy Research Center in the U.S. and Low- and Middle-Income Countries (LMIC) named the UNC-Malawi-South Africa Cancer Consortium (UMSACC). This is a collaborative research center between sites in the USA, Malawi, and South Africa. The Administrative Core will oversee operation, coordination, management, evaluation of projects and cores, and collaborations of the consortium.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: PATHOLOGY CORE The growing focus on personalized medicine requires advanced infrastructure and professional skills, as well as close collaboration between clinicians and pathologists to ensure the accurate prognostication of patients and the selection of targeted therapies for HIV-associated malignancies. This Pathology Core will provide comprehensive diagnostic support to the proposed multi-institutional research projects, build a regional network for high-quality diagnostic services, and establish systems for pathology training and education.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: DEVELOPMENTAL CORE The Developmental and Mentoring Core of the UNC-Malawi-South Africa Cancer Consortium (UMSACC) aims to develop Malawian, South African, and U.S. investigators and build capacity to conduct high quality HIV- associated cancer research in Africa. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: ANALYTICAL CORE This application responds to RFA-CA-20-001 and will establish a HIV-Associated Malignancy Research Center in the U.S. and Low- and Middle-Income Countries (LMIC) named the UNC-Malawi-South Africa Cancer Consortium (UMSACC). This is a collaborative research center between sites in the USA, Malawi, and South Africa and builds upon strong prior collaborations. The Analytical Core will conduct analyses to support the research projects, assist Malawi and South African researchers to develop and advance their analytical skills through various training activities, and disseminate findings from consortium-sponsored research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: PROJECT 1: Urine sampling for HPV infection and methylation testing for cervical cancer screening among women living with HIV in Malawi and South Africa HIV-positive women are at markedly increased risk of human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, cervical precancer and invasive cervical cancer. Despite this, coverage levels for cervical cancer screening remain low, particularly across sub-Saharan Africa, the global epicenter of the HIV epidemic. We propose an innovative project to validate urine-based HPV screening followed by triage of HPV-positive women with a novel methylation test known as S5, which, if successful, could dramatically increase cervical cancer screening globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The identification of new focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) and nephrotic syndrome (NS) genes and further genetic characterization of known FSGS/NS genes will have significant implications for understanding, and ultimately, treating, common forms of kidney disease and progression to kidney failure. In the more immediate future, identification and characterization of FSGS/NS gene defects will have implications for the development of diagnostic tools. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: PROJECT 3: Tumor-associated biomarkers for HIV-associated Diffuse Large B- cell Lymphoma in Malawi and South Africa Diffuse Large B-cell Lymphoma (DLBCL), the most common lymphoma worldwide, is highly associated with HIV, but prognostic determinants and molecular analyses of HIV-associated DLBCL are notably lacking. Leveraging the unique clinical, diagnostic and sequencing infrastructure, and advanced bioinformatics expertise, we aim to comprehensively investigate key molecular determinants and characteristics of the tumor niche in DLBCL across the spectrum of HIV-associated immune dysfunction in South Africa and Malawi.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disability and deaths related to otolaryngologic diseases have a significant public health impact nationally; however, recent advances in molecular and cellular biology, pharmaceutics, bioengineering, inner ear physiology, and voice analysis are translating scientific discovery to impact health. The UCLA Department of Head and Neck Surgery is dedicated to the mentoring and interdisciplinary team-based training of a new generation of academic leaders in disease-related research. By employing the expertise and resources of our renowned multidisciplinary mentor faculty, we will fulfill the program mission of training a cadre of investigators who will discover novel underlying basic principles of otolaryngology-related diseases and translate these discoveries to improve health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Widespread variation exists between species in the size, shape, and number of chromosomes, and these differences can have profound influences on genetic variation and reproductive compatibility. This research will identify patterns of chromosome evolution and centromere- associated satellite DNA turnover in the well-established Drosophila model system to help us understand evolutionary transitions. I will also investigate a unique beetle model with an evolutionarily young sex chromosome system to analyze rapid Y chromosome degeneration and reproductive incompatibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on developing a clinical decision support tool for the identification, diagnosis, and treatment of hospitalized patients at high risk of clinical deterioration. This work will result in novel algorithms that can be implemented to deliver early, personalized care to decrease preventable morbidity and mortality from deterioration. Therefore, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to enhancing health, lengthening life, and reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This Program represents a cohesive approach motivated by the practical needs of very high-throughput radiation biodosimetry in a variety of very different large-scale exposure scenarios, to estimate past individual dose and to predict individual sensitivity to future injury. A central characteristic remains focus on three different approaches: fully automated cytogenetics, gene expression, and metabolomics; these have different balances of capabilities in terms of throughput, time-to-result, signal lifetime, dose reconstruction, exposure scenario identification and individual radiosensitivity prediction, and the final goal is to quantify their optimal integrated usage in each of the many different potential exposure scenarios.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Summary In this 3-year study, California’s Refugee Reproductive Health Network (ReproNet) will aim to (1) Create a publicly-available digital repository of multilingual reproductive health resources (Dari, Pashto, Arabic) for Afghan and Arab refugee populations (2) Enhance Afghan and Arab refugee’s reproductive health literacy in California through 24 in-person and on-line training sessions and (3) Increase the capacity of refugee programs to integrate RH literacy in their programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Improving written and subsequent spoken language outcomes of individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities, a historically under researched group, has important public health implications. The proposed research is a small, randomized controlled trial that examines the effect of written language intervention for functional texts on proximal and distal written and spoken language outcomes of 40 young adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities. Evaluating effective intervention strategies for individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities supports NIDCD’s mission of behavioral research aimed to remediate the disordered process of language development in individuals with communication disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Aneuploidy, the state of having too many or too few chromosomes, is a leading cause of developmental diseases, miscarriages, and failed pregnancies using assisted reproductive technology. The cell has many mechanisms to ensure correct chromosome segregation, including creating crossovers between chromosomes. This grant proposes to study how crossovers are made and the underlying causes of chromosome aneuploidy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative In addition to the characteristic motor symptoms, patients with Parkinson’s disease (PD) also experience significant neuropsychiatric symptoms. Using detailed behavioral testing and high-resolution brain imaging methods, this project aims to examine brain regions known to play an important role in memory function and hallucinations in participants with PD and shed light on the relationship between changes in these brain regions and the parallel clinical course of memory deficits and hallucinations in PD patients with memory impairment or hallucinations compared to PD patients without memory impairment or hallucinations, and healthy controls. Repeat clinical assessment two years after neuroimaging will determine whether changes on fMRI associated with memory impairment and hallucinations in PD are predictive of future cognitive or functional decline and may be a target for intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiotoxicity is a serious side effect that occurs in up to a third of cancer patients receiving anthracycline chemotherapy. This project will utilize cell and animal models to define how interactions between cardiac innate immune responses and mitochondrial dysfunction contribute to the development and progression of anthracycline-induced cardiotoxicity. This research may therefore have a positive impact on public health by identifying new biomarkers for cardiotoxicity and/or illuminating novel therapeutic approaches to prevent or slow chemotherapy-related heart damage.
