IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to develop a patient-facing cervical cancer behavioral intervention (mNav) to help African American women identify and overcome barriers to cervical cancer care by providing health education and promoting self-efficacy, health literacy, and communication with healthcare providers. mNav-D, an integrated dashboard, will help lay navigators focus on issues they are best suited to handle (e.g., problems with insurance or transportation). The ultimate goal of this suite of products is to eliminate cervical cancer disparities among African American women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria elimination remains a global health priority, but as regions near elimination they are often “vulnerable” to re-introduction of malaria from areas nearby with high transmission and “receptive” as they have the right ecology to support transmission. Evidence is needed to design interventions to help pre-elimination settings reach the last mile of elimination. This proposal seeks to provide the evidence base to help develop the tools needed for control programs to face this challenge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Activated naïve T cells differentiate into memory and effector populations with unique functional and molecular profiles, which express the key inhibitory receptor programmed cell death protein 1 (PD-1) to limit excessive T cell-mediated autoreactivity. PD-1 is a prime immunotherapeutic target and despite its well-established role in immune tolerance, little is known about the molecular programs that support PD-1 inhibition under the prism of vast cellular and molecular diversity within the T cell population. The proposed research aims to dissect the PD-1 signalosome across the trajectory of diverse functional T cell states and to identify the cellular and molecular mediators of PD-1 responsivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Of persons living with HIV, up to 90% have been infected with hepatitis B and up to 10% have chronic hepatitis B, but currently no cure is available. Using novel techniques and specimens, this proposal will provide data on the role of the humoral immune response including neutralizing antibodies in plasma, the B cell repertoire, and monoclonal antibodies in natural control of acute HBV and how these are affected by HIV. These data could lead to a functional cure for HBV in people with and without HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Cannabis use is extremely common and associated with clinically-significant negative outcomes for a subset of users, yet it is not currently possible to predict who is at highest risk for cannabis-related harms at the individual level. The current proposal aims to identify a neural network predictive of problem cannabis use, and to characterize the development of this network both before and after cannabis use onset. Elucidating the neural basis of problem cannabis use will facilitate the development of novel prevention and early intervention efforts to mitigate potential cannabis-related harms for individuals at highest risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cleft palate with or without cleft lip (CP±L) is among the most common of all congenital conditions, and individuals with CP±L require interdisciplinary care from infancy through adulthood to improve speech, facial appearance, and physical and psychosocial health. However, it remains unknown which children with CP±L are at greatest risk for poor health and psychosocial outcomes, thus inhibiting efforts to develop and provide timely interventions to support health and well-being. This multi-site study will evaluate demographic, medical, and contextual factors associated with psychosocial and health outcomes over time in a large, diverse sample of young children born with CP±L who are enrolled in the Cleft Palate Registry/Research Outcomes Network study, with the goal of advancing clinical care and improving outcomes for this at-risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: In this basic research proposal we will investigate how the mechanical forces across epithelial cell-cell junctions and the nucleus regulate the homeostasis of epithelial cells and tissues, including proliferation, migration, barrier function, and three-dimensional organization. A better understanding of these processes will provide insight into epithelial tissue development, homeostasis, and disease. Results from this study have the potential to identify new therapeutic targets for cancer, fibrosis, wound healing, and chronic inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: New medications to treat viral diseases are urgently needed, particularly, for deadly viruses such as Dengue and Zika, which infect tens of millions of people annually. We will develop a new approach for the design of antiviral drugs that can be applied to both Dengue and Zika.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Better understanding by researchers and cancer care providers of the unique health needs of sexual and gender minority (SGM) individuals could markedly reduce cancer risk and/or improve experience along the cancer care continuum, from prevention to survivorship. In this project, we will establish and promote a foundational course to help prepare early-career researchers who are developing their research agendas to engage in cancer research relevant to SGM groups. This innovative course will provide an overview of knowledge gaps and challenges in SGM cancer research, strategies and resources to address these issues, and opportunities to network with researchers with shared interests who will serve as role models, mentors, and collaborators, thereby enhancing participants' understanding and abilities to successfully engage in SGM cancer research.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Each year, millions of children experience significant pain and distress surrounding injury-related procedures in the emergency department (ED) and Latinx children may be particularly vulnerable to poor outcomes. This observational, longitudinal cohort study will assess sociocultural, psychological, environmental, and healthcare system factors associated procedural pain and distress and clinical, patient experience, and resource utilization outcome disparities in an ethnically diverse sample of children undergoing invasive injury-related procedures in the ED. Results will direct the development of effective, equitable interventions that reduce procedural pain and improve outcomes surrounding injury-related care in the ED in diverse pediatric populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Signaling networks, encoded in genetic networks, underlie the normal development of embryos and can cause developmental abnormalities when disrupted. To cure diseases, we need to understand how genes control signaling networks at multiple scales, and how these networks drive cells to form coherent functional tissues and organs through the process of morphogenesis; this is not simple, as these signaling networks are complex and perturbations at the molecular level propagate in a very complex way to the embryo level. We propose to study how complex genetic and cellular signaling networks function by developing computational and biological models mimicking their behavior, and by probing natural systems with higher-order perturbative tools, hoping to understand their function and logic from subsequent changes at the morphogenetic level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative New advances in the field of cancer immunology and genomics have transformed the way people are thinking about the importance of immunotherapy in cancer treatment; a remaining question of current immunotherapy is how the cancer cells and microenviroment immune cells evolve during therapy and how to increase the cancer patient response rate. Here, we propose to use novel single cell/genomics technologies to understand both the changes in cellular circuitry underlying malignancy initiation, progression, and transformation, and also the co- evolving changes in the tumor microenvironment. These aims will be pursued in the context of existing NCI-funded research programs in Translational Immunogenomics Laboratory directed by Dr. Catherine Wu at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The HEAL Data2Action (D2A) Modeling and Economic Resource Center (MERC) will support the HEAL D2A Innovation Projects by providing expertise in simulation modeling and economic evaluation methods and will consult with the HEAL D2A Innovation Grant recipients on applying these methods and insights in their local implementation activities. The MERC will also conduct original research applying state-of-the-art economic and simulation modeling expertise to understand and address the overdose crisis. The MERC will support the application of health economics and modeling research to real-world decision making about services to prevent or treat opioid use disorder and pain, will further scientific innovation in the field, and will establish a paradigm for integrating health economics and modeling into substance use treatment and prevention policies at the system level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Baylor Research Education Program in Neurosurgery Narrative The primary goal of this research education program is to provide neurosurgery residents with the opportunity to complete a cohesive, significant research project during their residency training. The program will mentor residents through the entire research process, from project conception to experimental design, data analysis and interpretation, to publication of results and finally to transitioning to a junior faculty position. This hands-on approach is the most effective way to prepare the next generation of young clinician scientists for a productive research career in neurosurgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative There is a critical need for a new generation of prostate cancer biomarkers capable of accurately detecting aggressive cancers at a localized, curable stage. The overarching goal of this project is to selectively identify those patients with potentially lethal prostate cancers that stand to benefit from early definitive treatment, while preventing unnecessary testing, overdiagnosis, and subsequent overtreatment in the remaining population. To achieve this goal, we have assembled the Michigan-Vanderbilt University Medical Center EDRN Biomarker Characterization Center, which represents a multi-disciplinary team of accomplished academic and industry investigators committed to discovering, developing, and scaling clinical-grade assays for the early detection of aggressive forms of prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Organisms are variably sensitive or resistant to oxidative stress, and this is largely determined by differential stability of their proteomes and specialized protein adaptations. This research leverages structural systems biology, proteomics, machine learning, synthetic biology, and molecular and cellular experimentation in E. coli and human cells to elucidate the properties that distinguish protein sensitivity to oxidative stress, identify key protein dysfunctions leading to deleterious cellular phenotypes, and engineer proteins to confer increased robustness to stress. Results from these studies will expand our understanding of fine-resolution protein structure-function relationships, environmental impact on biological systems, and lay a foundation for development of diagnostics and therapeutics for disorders involving oxidative stress.

PHR: Various adverse and protective environments may affect child development. The Healthy Brain and Child Development National Consortium (HBCD-NC) will follow 7,500 mothers and their children from 24 locations across the U.S. from before birth to 10 years of age to better understand which harmful and protective environments exert the greatest impact on child development. This study will help to improve the health and development of children across the nation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT SUMMARY/NARRATIVE Recent evidence from our groups raises the provocative possibility that pancreatic islets of patients with T1D, particularly at early stages of the disease, contain a significant number of ß cells that have lost insulin immunoreactivity. Using a novel technology for quantifying the presence of ß cell DNA (based on ß cell-specific methylation patterns), we have found that the pancreas of patients with T1D is enriched for cells that contain the unmistakable DNA methylation signature of ß cells, yet do not stain for insulin, as well as experiments using a genetically engineered mouse model for interferon-driven islet inflammation suggest that loss of insulin is associated with inflammatory cytokines. We propose to test the hypothesis that empty ß cells, lacking insulin, are present in patients with T1D; to determine the underlying molecular mechanisms; and to search for potential modulators of this response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Papillomaviruses cause medically important benign tumors in the nose, throat, genitalia, and eyes. The virus produces E6 and E7 oncoproteins that cause the tumors. This application has identified a new cellular target of the viral E6 oncoprotein common to both benign and malignant virus types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The material properties of subcellular structures are inextricably connected with their biological functions, just as the material properties of blood and bone underlie their distinct physiological functions. The purpose of this research is to discover what protein sequence features and molecular interactions determine the material properties of a class of intracellular compartments called membraneless organelles, which can be liquid-like, gel- like, or a combination thereof. Our vision is to understand how the material properties of membraneless organelles underlie their normal biological functions and their contributions to neurodegeneration and other disease processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVES Although recent developments in anti-cancer treatments have improved cancer patients’ outcome, a significant number of cancer survivors are now suffering from heart failure that is caused by cancer treatments as adverse side effects. Doxorubicin, one of the most common chemotherapy drugs, is well known for its cardiotoxicity, but currently it is still difficult to predict who will develop doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity (DIC) and to prevent it. Here, we will make a platform to develop “cardioprotective” therapy against DIC using 3D cardiac microtissues as a surrogate to mimic patients’ hearts, which will significantly improve the risk assessment and risk reduction of DIC, and furthermore can be applied to other cancer treatment-related cardiotoxicities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: LAY SUMMARY The overarching objective of the Kidney Mapping Atlas Project (KMAP) is to create and support the central data management, integration and dissemination platform for the Kidney Precision Medicine Project (KPMP). Our focus for KMAP will be centered around the key values established by us in the first funding cycle of KPMP: a collaborative environment committed to promoting participant safety and engagement, scientific rigor, and outreach to the global renal research community anchored in a concept of interdisciplinary team science necessary to drive disruptive advances in kidney precision medicine. For the second funding cycle our assembled team across ten leading US research institutions has expertise in 15 distinct knowledge domains to continue our uncompromising commitment to our patient partners co-leading our efforts to transform kidney disease research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Each adult human harbors hundreds of bacterial species in their intestine, but it is not clear how these species evolve competitive or cooperative relationships with one another, given the rapid and frequent mixing and redistribution of intestinal contents. We propose that bacteria adhere to certain types of food particles, and that this allows bacterial cells of different species to have sustained interactions with their co-adherent neighbors. We are using orally administered artificial food particles to uncover the bacterial genes required for this process and to generate a map of interacting bacterial species in the intestine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Combining a novel causal inference method with several statistical and machine-learning techniques, this New Innovator Award will develop and test a new study design for determining the causal effects of clinical interventions for sepsis in large-scale electronic health record data. If successful, this project will equip clinical sepsis researchers with a tool that uses a fundamentally different approach to causal effect estimation than current state-of-the-art methods, to reliably determine the effectiveness of clinical interventions for sepsis in routine care. This study design would constitute an important step towards providing more individualized care for sepsis because it would allow clinical researchers to take advantage of the large size of electronic health record data to establish how the effectiveness of different interventions for sepsis varies across highly granular patient subgroups defined by various combinations of sociodemographic and clinical characteristics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Macrophages and fibroblasts participate in many inflammatory processes that drive the development of human disease, such as inflammatory bowel diseases, fibrosis and cancer. We will employ a powerful bottom-up approach that reconstitutes the communication and interaction between macrophages and fibroblasts, to discovery how these two cell types impact immune functions collectively during tissue homeostasis and inflammation. This proposal aims to uncover the basic mechanisms of how macrophages function in tissues, which may ultimately allow us to program immune interactions to restore tissue homeostasis from disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  We have developed a high-resolution, moment-to-moment assessment that quantifies vascular sensitivity to the sympathetic nervous system, which becomes highly dysfunctional in obesity-related hypertension. By comprehensively examining the role of hyperglycemia and hyperlipidemia on vascular function, and the extent to which pharmacological reductions in sympathetic nerve activity mitigate the pro-inflammatory phenotype of obesity, we will identify unique mechanisms that can be targeted to limit increases in vascular dysfunction and reduce the high prevalence of hypertension and cardiovascular disease in this population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Unguez, G PROJECT NARRATIVE Choose Development! is the Society for Developmental Biology’s program to provide under- represented undergraduate students a research-intensive experience for two summers to complement their formal collegial education. Through continuous multilevel mentorship, hands- on laboratory experimentations, results presentation and meetings with leaders in the field the students will acquire knowledge, confidence and science identity. These approaches will contribute to broadening participation and retention of currently underrepresented populations in research areas of interest to the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development such as developmental, stem cell and regenerative biology, gene network and biomechanics in development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The intestine exerts the important function of maximizing nutrient uptake from the diet ingested during feeding periods. Maintenance of intestinal health requires the precise regulation of local immune responses against microbes and dietary components. However, there is a major gap in our understanding of how dietary-derived signals affect intestinal immune responses during feeding. Gut neurons have emerged as important regulators of intestinal immune responses, since they interact with immune cells and are quickly activated by the presence of food in the intestine. Our studies of how diet modulates gut neurons that control intestinal immunity are expected to uncover dietary and neuronal therapeutic targets to gut disturbances associated with dysregulation in immune responses, namely intestinal infections and inflammatory bowel disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Risk-based cancer screening seeks to maximize the benefits and minimize the harms of screening, and to achieve these goals, cancer risk prediction models need to be translated into risk assessment tools that are meaningful and useful for the public and in clinical practice. However, a critical barrier to implementing risk- based screening is that many people reject that their risk estimate is true for them personally. Therefore, our goal is to understand the reasons for risk rejection, and identify methods for communicating personalized risk information that people can both understand and accept.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to identify and study relevant patterns of post-irradiation morbidity and mortality in a controlled, well-defined NHP population, by collaborating and sharing data with qualified investigators. Data sharing and administrative oversight are designed to maximize use of the resource. The program will identify patterns of post-irradiation morbidity; identify characteristics of animals with differing radiation-induced disorders; assess late effects of prior mitigator treatment; and refine the cohort to balance age, sex, dose, and mitigator type.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: This proposal examines novel genetic and epigenetic mechanisms that enable immature cells in the embryo to form mature nephrons, the functional filtering units in the kidney. Our long-term goal is to harness these normal mechanisms of organ formation to increase nephron formation in preterm infants and babies born with small kidneys (hypoplasia) due to birth defects. Our studies should also provide insight into regeneration and repair in acquired kidney diseases that cause end stage organ failure in adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Shortly after birth, newborns are rapidly colonized by a complex and dynamic community of microorganisms. This initial colonization event plays an essential role in healthy development and perturbation to this process can have major consequences later in life. The ecological principles and molecular interactions that regulate succession of the microbial community during early life are not well understood. We will generate a comprehensive spatial map and molecular blueprint of metabolic interactions in the gut microbiota during early life colonization and perturbation to better understand the fundamental principles that mediate formation and maintenance of a stable community. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative - Public Health Relevance Statement: Small molecules of medicinal interests generally contain carbon-carbon (C−C) bonds in their skeletons, thus methods that selectively edit specific C−C bonds are highly desirable as syntheses of biologically important compounds could be simplified or streamlined. However, broadly applicable C−C activation approaches remain largely elusive. The outlined proposal exploits several unique modes of transition-metal- mediated C−C bond activation discovered in our laboratory in developing a suite of catalytic methods that are useful for preparing complex molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE School-based health programs provide essential access to preventive services for rural underserved and minority American children, but loss to follow-up and limited numbers of specialists are problematic. This study will prospectively evaluate a new virtual specialty triage model in Alaska schools to reduce loss to follow-up from school hearing screening and improve access to specialty care in rural environments. This telehealth model to address preventable childhood hearing loss could be translated to other rural underserved and minority populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple myeloma (MM) is the second most common hematological malignancy. Despite the incorporation of novel agents in the autologous stem cell transplant (ASCT) backbone for MM treatment, MM remains incurable. In this application, we propose to target a novel immune regulatory pathway, the versican (VCAN) pathway, in order to optimize post-ASCT therapy for myeloma, and thus to prevent or delay relapses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Disadvantage indices—statistical measures to describe the economic, social and health-related vulnerability of residents in a specific geographic area as small as neighborhoods—were used for Covid-19 vaccine allocation planning for the first time in US' history. This is important because policymakers recognized that traditional frameworks can contribute to, and worsen, structural racism and discrimination, and that disadvantage indices offer a way of mitigating or avoiding such an impact. In this study, we will analyze whether and how different types and uses of disadvantage indices reduced structural racism and discrimination in Covid-19 vaccine allocation, and explore how disadvantage indices can be used in other areas of health care to reduce differences in health and life expectancy across racial and ethnic groups that are due to structural racism and discrimination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative. We propose to use a combination of large-sample, lifespan functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data from the Human Connectome Project and advanced statistical modeling to provide (1) optimized methods for estimating the hemodynamic response function (HRF), (2) a large-sample HRF atlas capturing variation across the lifespan, and (3) methods and results estimating a neural connectome after taking the HRF into account. Successful completion of the project will provide more accurate and precise estimates of task-related fMRI activity and brain connectivity in studies of mental health, healthy and pathological aging, substance use, and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Arms races with viruses have shaped human genomic adaptation, not only in immune genes, but also across the entire human genome. Over the coming years, my lab will exploit host genomic adaptation to detect, date, and functionally characterize ancient viral epidemics that plagued ancestral human populations. Because past viral threats are more likely to become threats again in the future, ancient epidemics will provide a better assessment of the viruses with the potential to cause future epidemics.

PROJECT_TITLE: Ancient viral threats through the lens of adaptation in human genomes

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative There is an increasing number of patients with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia (ADRD) using prescription opioids chronically or concurrently with other central nervous system medications, but evidence on the clinical and safety outcomes of these common opioid prescribing practices in this fast-growing, vulnerable population is lacking. There is also a poor understanding of the role of opioids on cognition in older adults with chronic pain. The proposed research, which is responsive to the priorities of the National Plan to Address Alzheimer’s Disease, will contribute to informing optimal use and safe opioid prescribing for chronic pain that is commonly comorbid in patients with ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Opioid use and addiction among chronic pain population is a serious public health concern with significant economic and social burden. The current proposal addresses a critical gap in our knowledge relating to pain avoidance behavior which when maladaptive in the chronic pain state is a major driver for opioid abuse. Knowledge about behavioral and neurophysiological constructs of pain avoidance behavior in chronic pain patients will help identify and treat those at risk for opioid use disorder, and develop long-term non-addictive therapeutic interventions.
